editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE WARS IN ENGLAND, Scotland and Ireland. OR An Impartial Account of all the Battels, Sieges, and other Remarkable Tran≈øactions, Revolutions and Accidents, which have heppened from the beginning of the Reign of King CHARLESI. in 1625, to His Maje≈øties happy Re≈øtauration, 1660.

p.hi: Illu≈øtrated with Pictures of ≈øome Con≈øiderable matters curiou≈øly Ingraven on Copper Plates.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Nath. Crouch and John How, at the Seven Stars in Sweetings Alley near the Royal Exchange in Cornhill. 1681.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: THis ≈ømall Volume is intended for the u≈øe of tho≈øe who cannot go to the price of a greater, and yet would willingly be informed of tho≈øe wonderful Tran≈øactions and Revolutions which have happened in the≈øe Three Kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland, in this la≈øt Age, and within the memory of many now living: And though it cannot be expected that a large Account of every particular Accident can be comprehended in this little Compendium, yet I have endeavoured, without the lea≈øt pa≈ø≈øion or partiality, briefly to compri≈øe the mo≈øt con≈øiderable Matters.

Now as the Things here in≈øerted are more remarkable, both for their Variety and Quality, than it may be ever happened at any time heretofore in ≈øo ≈øhort a ≈øpace; ≈øo the ≈øerious peru≈øal and con≈øideration thereof may be very u≈øeful and nece≈ø≈øary for quieting the pre≈øent Di≈øcontents and deplorable Di≈øtractions that are now among≈øt us; ≈øince the≈øe were the Forerunners of tho≈øe mi≈øerable Wars, Ruins, and De≈øolations which are herein related; wherein all Bonds of Religion, Alliance and Friend≈øhip,
were utterly de≈øtroyed: Wherein Fathers and Children, Kindred and Acquaintance, became unnatural Enemies to each other; ≈øo that with ≈øome little Variation we may apply what Lucan writes of the Civil Wars of Rome to England in tho≈øe times,
Wars more than Civil on the Britti≈øh Plains
Then happened; and England Di≈øtzins
In her own Bowels her Victorious Swords;
Where Kindred Ho≈øts Encounter, all Accords
Of Empire broke; where arm'd to Impious War,
The ≈øtrength of all the ≈øhaken Land from far
Is met; known En≈øigns, En≈øigns do de≈øie,
Fathers by Sons, and Sons by Fathers die.
What fury Countrey-men, what madne≈øs cou'd
Move you to fea≈øt your Foes with Engli≈øh Blood,
And chu≈øe ≈øuch Wars as could no Triumphs yield
Whil≈øt yet proud Babylon unconquer'd held.
Alas what ≈øeas, what lands might you have ta'ne,
VVith that bloods lo≈øs, which your own hands have drawn.

Let us all therefore who pretend to the name of Chri≈øtians, ≈øtudy to be quiet, and follow Peace with all men; which is the mo≈øt Effectual means to prevent tho≈øe Confu≈øions and Mi≈øeries which we have lately ≈øuffered, and under the effects whereof we ≈øtill groan: and that this ≈øhort Narrative may be u≈øeful to this purpo≈øe, is the earne≈øt and hearty de≈øire of

closer.signed: Your Countrey-man and Well-wi≈øher RICHARD B∆≤RTON.

div.head: THE WARS IN England, Scotland, and Ireland, &c.
div.p: BEfore we proceed to give an Account of tho≈øe Unnatural Wars, Ruins, and Deva≈øtations, which have happened in the≈øe Kingdoms in this La≈øt Age, it may ≈øeem nece≈ø≈øary, by way of Introduction, to give a Relation of ≈øeveral previous Tran≈øactions before the≈øe Woful Calamities befel us.

Upon the 27th. day of March, in the year 1625, King James departed this life at Theobalds in the Fifty ninth year of his Age, when he had reigned Twenty two years compleat: And in the Afternoon of the ≈øame day Charles Prince of Wales, his only Son then living, was proclaimed
King of Great Britain, France and Ireland.

The fir≈øt thing he did, was performing the Ceremonies of his Fathers Funeral, in which the King him≈øelf in Per≈øon followed as chief Mourner immediately after the Her≈øe; having his Train of black Velvetborn up by the Twelve Peers of the Realm; at his right hand the Earl of Arundel, and at his left the Earl of Pembroke. He then proceeded to his Coronation, and after that he con≈øummated the Marriage with Henrietta Maria, younger Daughter of the Great Henry the Fourth, King of France, whom he had formerly ≈øeen in his Journey through that Countrey into Spain; his fir≈øt Complement to her, when he went to meet her at Dover, was, That he de≈øired to be no longer Ma≈øter of him≈øelf, then he was Servant to her, which indeed he made good: for on the day before his deplorable death, he de≈øired his Daughter, the Lady Elizabeth, to a≈ø≈øure her Mother, if ever he ≈øaw her again, That his Thoughts had never ≈øtrayed from her, and that his Affections ≈øhould be the ≈øame to the la≈øt.

The King then called a Parliament, which A≈ø≈øembled the Eighteenth of June follwoing, to whom he repre≈øented in a ≈øhort Speech, The urgent nece≈ø≈øity of rai≈øing a Sub≈øidy, ≈øince it would not agree with his Kingly honour to ≈øhrink from the War with Spain, which his Father upon ≈øolid Con≈øiderations had by con≈øent of both Hou≈øes undertaken; although prevented by death from putting it in Execution: That Money, the ≈øinews of War mu≈øt be levied, without which neither Army nor Fleet could move; former Contributions being already disbur≈øed to a penny: That he ≈øhould ≈øeem ridiculous to all Europe, if he did not now at length proceed to Action: That it was his
fir≈øt Enterprize, the ≈øucce≈øs whereof would have influence upon his following Reign: That it concerned their own Reputations herein to A≈ø≈øi≈øt him effectually, lea≈øt the world ≈øhould judge them to have betray'd their King: That Celerity was nece≈ø≈øary becau≈øe of Winter then approaching, a ≈øea≈øon prejudicial to Martial Attempts: the Pe≈øtilence at that time Reigning in the City, which in all probability might cau≈øe a ≈øudden Di≈ø≈øolution of their Meeting: All which Arguments, if duly con≈øidered, did evidently demon≈øtrate, That it was mo≈øt Honourable, Opportune and ≈øafe, to u≈øe Expedition in the bu≈øine≈øs. As for Religion and Manner of Government, he was re≈øolved to tread in his Fathers ≈øteps, hoping that his former life had mini≈øtred, no ju≈øt grounds for them to ≈øu≈øpect the contrary.

The Parliament acknowledged the≈øe Arguments for a Sub≈øidy to be very rational, but yet would not ≈øuddenly re≈øolve upon it, till they had fir≈øt pre≈øented their two Petitions, concerning Bea≈øons of Religion and Complaint of their Sufferings, which points had been offered to his Father King James, in the clo≈øe of his la≈øt Parliament, and by his death were left hitherto unan≈øwered.

In both which they received competent ≈øatisfaction, and likewi≈øe an account of the Arrears which were due to the Forces both by Sea and Land, together with an E≈øtimate of the future Charge and Expence of the Spani≈øh War; upon which the King obtained of the Laity freely and ab≈øolutely, Two Sub≈øidies to be paid by Prote≈øtants, and four from Papi≈øts; and three Sub≈øidies, from the Clergy. In this Parliament Dr. Montague the Kings Chaplain was que≈øtioned for certain Tenets in his An≈øwer to a Book called the Romi≈øh Gagger
and his defence thereof; Intituled Appello ad Cae≈øarem: And he being brought before the Bar of the Hou≈øe, the Speaker declared their plea≈øure; That they would refer his Cen≈øure till the next meeting; and in the mean time he ≈øhould ≈øtand committed to the Serjeants Ward, till Two Thou≈øand Pound Bail could be procured for his appearance next Se≈ø≈øions: And though the King took him into Protection, as his Servant, yet his Bail-bond remained uncancelled.

Divers Laws were Enacted in this Parliament, as one about Ob≈øervation of the Lord's day; another for re≈øtraint of Tipling in Inns, Alehou≈øes, &c. The≈øe pa≈ø≈øed likewi≈øe in the Hou≈øe of Commons, A Bill for Tunnage and Poundage; but this mi≈øcarried in the Hou≈øe of Lords, becau≈øe the Commons had limited it to a year, whereas it was formerly granted to the Kings Predece≈ø≈øors during their lives; it being intended to reduce the Cu≈øtoms to the Rate, at which they were ≈øettled in the Reign of Queen Mary.

During the fitting of the Parliament, the Lord Mordant a Papi≈øt, and his Wife a Prote≈øtant, being both de≈øirous of each others Conver≈øion, they put their cau≈øe upon a di≈øpute between James U≈øher L. Archbi≈øhop of Amargh, and one Rookwood a Je≈øuite, who called him≈øelf Beaumont; this was acted at Drayton in Northampton≈øhire, the points di≈øputed on were, Tran≈øub≈øtantiation, Praying to Saints, Images, and the Vi≈øibility of the Church; wherein the Learned Primate ≈øo foil'd his Adver≈øary, that the Lord Mordant was Convinced and Converted to the Prote≈øtant Religion, and his Lady further confirmed therein.

On the Eleventh of July, 1626, the Parliament by rea≈øon of the ≈øickne≈øs, Adjourned till Augu≈øt 1. and then met again at Oxford, where the King fir≈øt
by him≈øelf, and next by his two Secretaries, the Lord Conway and Sir John Cook, declared to them the nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øetting forth a Fleet, for the recovery of the Palatinate, which was the Countrey of the Prince Palatine of the Rhyns, who married the Kings Si≈øter, and was then unju≈øtly detained from him by the Emperour of Germany, and the King of Spain; the Lord Trea≈øurer likewi≈øe in≈øtanced the ≈øeveral Sums of Money, which King James died indebted to the City of London.

This occa≈øioned very warm Debates in the Hou≈øe of Commons, who alledged, That evil Councels guided the Kings De≈øigns; That the Trea≈øury was mi≈øimployed, That our nece≈ø≈øties aro≈øe through Imprevidence: That it would be nece≈ø≈øary to Petition the King for a stricter hand and better Councel to manage his Affairs: That though a former Parliament engaged the King in a War, yet if things were managed with Contrary de≈øigns; and the Trea≈øure mi≈øimployed, this Parliament was not bound to be carried blind≈øold in De≈øigns, not guided by ≈øound Council: That it was not u≈øual to grant Sub≈øidies upon Sub≈øidies in one Parliament, and no Grievances redne≈ø≈øed. With ≈øeveral other Pa≈ø≈øages of the like Nature.

They likewi≈øe very much reflected upon the mi≈øcarriages of the Duke of Buckingham. who was then a per≈øon of very con≈øiderable Tru≈øt: but however they promi≈øed to con≈øider of the Kings de≈øires, and pre≈øented him a Petition again≈øt Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, giving an Account of their damage, a≈øcribing certain Cau≈øes of their growth, and offering divers Remedies thereunto; unto which a ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer (if any thing would have ≈øatisfied) was returned: And hereupon there followed a Debate about Supplies; ≈øome were for contributing pre≈øently, others demurr'd, as di≈øliking the de≈øign in
hand; and in conclu≈øion the Major part agreed not to give: And being incen≈øed again≈øt the Duke of Buckingham, they began to think of dive≈øting him of his Offices, and to require an Account of the Publick Moneys wherewith he had been intru≈øted; all which they intended to include in an humble Remon≈øtrance: to prevent which, the King re≈øolved to Di≈ø≈øolve the Parliament; and accordingly the U≈øher of the Black Rod was ≈øent from the Hou≈øe of Lords to the Commons, who were then re≈øolved into a Grand Committee; and under≈øtanding the Kings plea≈øure, they cau≈øed the Speaker to keep his Seat, while they agreed upon a Me≈ø≈øage of Thanks to his Maje≈øty for his Gracious An≈øwer to their Petition for Religion, and for his care of their Health, in giving them leave to depart this dangerous time of Sickne≈øs; with a dutiful Declaration of their Affection and Loyalty, and of their purpo≈øing to ≈øupply him in a Parliamentary way, in fit and convenient time: After which they were accordingly di≈ø≈øolved.

Now the War with Spain being intended both for the recovery of the Palatinate, and to prevent di≈øturbance in our Civil E≈øtate, the Councel hereupon re≈øolve with all ≈øpeed to ≈øet forth a Fleet, and to pre≈øerve ≈øtrict Unity and Peace with France, Denmark, and the United Provinces, and with the Hollanders the King had already entered into a League Offen≈øive and Defen≈øive again≈øt the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, and likewi≈øe had promi≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in ≈øoliciting other Princes to enter into the ≈øame Confederation, upon Condition that they ≈øhould bear a Fourth part of the Charge of the Fleet; and in pur≈øuance hereof, the Duke of Buckingham and the Earl of Holland were ≈øent to the Hague, and there meeting with the Amba≈ø≈øadors of France
and Denmark, they concluded a League for re≈øtoring the Liberties of Germany; the two la≈øt Amba≈ø≈øadors having no further power from their Supteams.

A while after the Di≈ø≈øolution of the Parliament, the King publi≈øhed a Proclamation, Commanding the return of all Children of Noble-men, which had been ≈øent to be Educated in Seminaries and Popi≈øh Schools beyond Sea; that none who had received Orders from Rome, ≈øhould pre≈øume to confer Orders, or Exerci≈øe Eccle≈øia≈øtical Functions in any of his Dominions; and likewi≈øe that the Statute be put in Execution for the departure of Prie≈øts and Je≈øuites, out of his Maje≈øties Dominions.

By rea≈øon of the Di≈ø≈øolving the Parliament, the Act of Sub≈øidies was prevented, and the King was nece≈ø≈øitated to take up Money upon Loan of ≈øuch Per≈øons as were of Ability to lend; and to that end he directed his Letters to the Lord Leiutenants of the ≈øeveral Counties, To return the Names of tho≈øe Men whom they thought mo≈øt ≈øufficient, The places of their Habitations, and what Sums each might be judged able to lend; and to the per≈øons returned, Letters were I≈ø≈øued forth in the Kings Name to this purpo≈øe,

That his Maje≈øty having ob≈øerved in the Pre≈øidents and Customs of former times. That all the Kings and Queens of this Realm, upon extraordinary occa≈øions have u≈øed either to re≈øort to tho≈øe Contributions which ari≈øe from the generality of Subjects, or to the private helps of ≈øome well affected in particular, by way of Loan; in the former of which, as his Maje≈øty has no doubt in the Love and affection of his People, when they ≈øhall again A≈ø≈øemble in Parliament; ≈øo for the pre≈øent he was inforced to proceed in the latter cour≈øe for ≈øupply of ≈øome Portions of Trea≈øure for divers publick
Services, which without manifold Inconveniences to his Majesty, and his Kingdoms cannot be deferr'd: and therefore this being the first time that his Maje≈øty hath required any thing of this kind, he doubts not but he ≈øhall receive ≈øuch a Te≈øtimony of good affection from them among other of his Subjects, and that with ≈øuch alacrity and readine≈øs as may make the ≈øame ≈øo much the more acceptable; e≈øpecially ≈øince his Maje≈øty required but the Sum which few men would deny a Friend, and has a mind re≈øolved to expo≈øe all his Earthly Fortune for Pre≈øervation of the General: The Sum which His Maje≈øty requires by the≈øe pre≈øents is‚Äî which His Maje≈øty promi≈øeth in the Name of him≈øelf, his Heirs, and Succe≈ø≈øors, to repay to them or their A≈ø≈øigns, within Eighteen Months after the payment thereof to the Collector: The Per≈øon whom his Majesty hath appointed is ‚Äî to who≈øe hands his Maje≈øty doth require them to ≈øend it within Twelve days after they have received this Privy Seal; which together with the Collectors Acquittance, ≈øhall be ≈øufficient Warrant to the Officers of Receipt for their payment thereof at the time limited: And the Collectors of the Loan were ordered to pay the Sums received into the Exchequer, and to return the Names of ≈øuch as went about to delay or excu≈øe the Payment of the Sums required.

And now about the beginning of October the Fleet ≈øet to Sea, the Lord Cecill, ≈øecond Son to the Earl of Exeter, commanding the Land Forces, and the Earl of E≈ø≈øex being Vice Admiral at Sea; but they were ≈øurprized by ≈øo violent a Storm, that the greate≈øt part of the Navy, which in all made up Four≈øcore Ships (≈øome being Dutch) were di≈ø≈øipated and ≈øcattered for ≈øeven days together, and an excellent Ship with an 170 Pa≈ø≈øengers in her, were all ca≈øt away, and lo≈øt;
the De≈øign was to have furprized Cadiz in Spain, to burn the Ships in the Harbour, and to have taken the Spani≈øh Plate Fleet, which was daily expected from the Indies; but by rea≈øon of the Plague among≈øt them, and ≈øome other mi≈øcarriages of the Commanders, the bu≈øine≈øs was wholly di≈øappointed, and the Fleet returned home but four days before the Plate Fleet came.

Upon the Second of February was the Coronation, at which the King did not pa≈øs through the City in State from the Tower, as was u≈øual, but went by Water from Whitehall to We≈øtmin≈øter, for fear of the danger of a Concour≈øe of People; the Pe≈øtilence which raged the year before not being quite cea≈øed: The Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, as Dean of We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øhould have performed the chief part of the Ceremony, but being under di≈øplea≈øure, Dr. Laud, then Bi≈øhop of St. Davids ≈øupplied his place.

Divers con≈øiderable Forces had been rai≈øed both for Sea and Land, for the better Di≈øcipline of whom, 150 old Souldiers were ≈øent for from the Netherlands, by who≈øe Indu≈øtry they were brought into ≈øome good order again≈øt the meeting of the next Parliament, which was ≈øummoned to ≈øit Feb. 6. And being met accordingly, the Hou≈øe of Commons cho≈øe Sir Henage Finch for their Speaker.

The fir≈øt bu≈øine≈øs they in≈øi≈øted upon, was the rendring thanks to the King for his gracious An≈øwer to their late Petition concerning Religion, then they debated of the Publick Grievances, viz. The mi≈øcarrying of the Fleet at Cadiz; the evil Councellors about the King; mi≈øimploying the Kings Revenue; an Account of the Sub≈øidies and three Fifteens, granted in the 21 Year of King James: And in the Committee of Grievances, the≈øe four particulars were in≈øi≈øted on: 1. The ≈øtate of the
King in the con≈øtant Revenue of the Crown, and how much it had been dimini≈øhed by Gifts of Lands, Grants of Pen≈øions, Fruitle≈øs Emba≈ø≈øies, the Privy Pur≈øe, and other ways. 2. The Condition of the Subject in his Freedom, about laying new impo≈øitions, multiplying Monopolies, Leuying of Cu≈øtoms without Act of Parliament, and wa≈øting the Trea≈øure. 3. The Cau≈øe of the Nations good ≈øucce≈øs in former times, whereby it was feared, Victorious and Renowned abroad; which they judged was occa≈øioned by the Wi≈ødom and Gravity of Coun≈øel, who ordered nothing but by publick Debate; whereby there aro≈øe a readine≈øs in the People to A≈ø≈øi≈øt their Soveraign in Pur≈øe and Per≈øon. 4. The pre≈øent Condition of the Kingdom, wherein was repre≈øented the lo≈øs of its wonted Reputation, through the ill ≈øucce≈øs at Algier in the Palatinate, in Count Manfields Expedition, and at Cadiz; and this was imputed to the want of ≈øuch Coun≈øels as were formerly u≈øed; ≈øince for fear of not ≈øucceeding, men were now afraid of venturing either there Per≈øons or Pur≈øes.

There was likewi≈øe a Committe concerning Religion and the growth of Popery, wherein Mr. Richard Montagues two Books before mentioned were again que≈øtioned, and Articles drawn up again≈øt him, charging him with ≈øeveral Pa≈ø≈øages for encouraging Popery, and drawing his Maje≈øties Subjects from the true Religion E≈øtabli≈øhed into Error and Super≈øtition, with other pa≈ø≈øages di≈øhonourable to the late King, and full of injurious and railing Language again≈øt other Per≈øons; as likewi≈øe that he endeavoured to rai≈øe Factions in the Kingdom, by ca≈øting the ≈øcandalous Name of Puritan, upon ≈øuch of his Maje≈øties Subjects as conformed them≈øelves to the Doctrine of the Church of
England: upon which the Hou≈øe of Commons ordered that he ≈øhould be brought to Exemplary Puni≈øhment, and to have his Books burnt; nor do we find that he ever made any Defence or An≈øwer to tho≈øe Articles that were brought again≈øt him: It is affirmed that a while before the ≈øitting of the Parliament, Dr. Laud under≈øtanding from the D. of Buckingham that the King intended to leave Mr. Montague to a Tryal, was heard to utter the≈øe words, I≈øeem to ≈øee a Cloud ari≈øing and threatning the Church of England, God in his Mercy di≈ø≈øipate it.

After this the Commons que≈øtioned ≈øeveral per≈øons who were of the Council of War, upon the Affairs of the Palatinate, concerning the management of that bu≈øine≈øs, complaint was likewi≈øe made in the Hou≈øe of the Scotch and Iri≈øh Nobility, for claiming precedency of the Peers of England, of which redre≈øs was promi≈øed; but a while after the Lord Martrevers, Elde≈øt Son and Heir to the Earl of Arundel, Married the Daughter of the late Duke of Lenox, contrary to the Kings Mind, who intended her for the Lord Lorn, Son and Heir of the Earl of Argile; whereupon the Earl of Arundel was committed to the Tower; which upon the Peers Petitioned to the King, alledging, That no Peer ≈øitting in the Parliament, is to be impri≈øoned without Order from the Hou≈øe of Lords, unle≈øs for Felony, Trea≈øon, or denying to give ≈øecurity for the Peace. Upon this there aro≈øe a Di≈øpute, which la≈øted for the ≈øpace of two Months, and then the Earl was ≈øet at Liberty.

In which time the Hou≈øe of Commons were very bu≈øie in ≈øearching the Signet Office, for the Original of a Letter under the Signet, written to the Mayor of York, for reprieving divers Je≈øuites, Prie≈øts, and other Popi≈øh Recu≈øants: This was reported by Mr.
Pim Chairman to the Committee for Religion; but their proceedings therein were interrupted by a Meffage from the King, ≈øent by Sr. Richard Weston, Chancellor of the Exchequer; demanding a ≈øupply for the Engli≈øh and Iri≈øh Forces. This was ≈øo highly re≈øented, that Mr. Clement Cook, one of the Members openly Prote≈øted, That it was better to die by a Forreign Enemy, than to be de≈øtroyed at home: And Dr. Turner another of the Hou≈øe ≈øeconded him with the≈øe Queries.

1. Whether the King had not lo≈øt the Regality of the Narrow Seas ≈øince the D. of Buckingham was Admixal? 2. Whether his going as Admiral in this la≈øt Fleet, was not the cau≈øe of its ill Succe≈øs, and return without any con≈øiderable Action? 3. Whether the Kings Trea≈øure hath not been impaired by the Dukes Immen≈øe Liberality? 4. Whether he hath not Ingro≈ø≈øed all Offices, and prefer'd his Kindred to mo≈øt places? 5. Whether he hath not ≈øold places of Judicature? 6. Whether Popi≈øh Recu≈øants have not dependance upon his Mother and Father in Law.

The≈øe bold Expre≈ø≈øions ≈øo provoked the King, that he immediately ≈øent Sir Richard Weston to demand Satisfaction of the Hou≈øe of Commons, whereupon Dr. Turner pre≈øently after made a Speech in Vindication, and for explaining him≈øelf, alledging, That what he had ≈øaid was for the good of the Kingdom, and not reflecting upon any one in patticular. That to accu≈øe upon common Fame, he thought to be a Parliamentary way, and warranted by the Cannons of the Church, the Imperial Laws, and by Ancient Pre≈øidents. The Duke of Suffolk in King Hen. the Sixths time, having been accu≈øed upon Common Fame. He added likewi≈øe, That Mr. Chancellor him≈øelf had pre≈øented ≈øome per≈øons upon particular Fame, and that he knew no rea≈øon why him≈øelf might not in that place have as
ample Priviledge; and the further debate of the matter being referr'd till another time, Dr. Turner in the mean ≈øpace writ a Letter to the Speaker to excu≈øe his ab≈øence, by rea≈øon of ≈øome Indi≈øpo≈øition, and to ≈øignify his de≈øire of putting him≈øelf wholly upon the Judgment and Cen≈øure of Parliament.

Sir William Waller, ≈øpeaking his Opinion concerning Grievances, ≈øaid, That the True Cau≈øe of them, was, becau≈øe (as was ≈øaid of Lewes the 11th of France) all the Kings Council Rode upon one Hor≈øe, And that therefore His Maje≈øty was to be advi≈øed, as Mo≈øes was by Jethro, to make choice of Councellors, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him that ≈øhould be thus qualified: 1. Noble, not Up≈øtarts, and of a Nights Growth. 2. Men of Courage, ≈øuch as would execute their own places, and not commit them to unde≈øerving Deputies. 3. Fearing God, not inclining to fal≈øe Wor≈øhip or halting between two Opinions. 4. Dealing truly, not given to Flattery, or favouring Court≈øhip; but ≈øuch as might be ≈øafely tru≈øted by the King and Kingdom. 5. Hating Covetou≈øne≈øs, not ≈øuch as lived upon other Mens Means, or that would take Bribes, or ≈øell places in Church or State, or about the King. 6. To be many, in the multitude of Councellors there being ≈øafety. 7. To judg of ≈ømall matters as well as great (the greate≈øt being to be referr'd to the King) much le≈øs any one Councellor alone to manage all bu≈øine≈øs. 8. Elders, not young and unexperienced Men, through who≈øe ra≈øh and unadvi≈øed proceedings, great De≈øigns many times mi≈øcarry.

And herein he was ≈øeconded by Sr. John Eliot, who repre≈øented to the Hou≈øe, The pre≈øent State of the Kingdom, and the great di≈øhonour the King and Kingdom had ≈øu≈øtained by ≈øeveral mi≈øcarriages,
and ill management of Matters of the highe≈øt Tru≈øt; he likewi≈øe mentioned Two Pre≈øidents, the fir≈øt in the 16 year of Hen. 3. when the Parliament denied the Sub≈øidies demanded till the great Officers were Examined; and Hugh de Burg being found guilty of Corruption was di≈øplaced. Another Example was in the 10th year of Rich. 2. when Supply was required, and the Commons complaining that the Earl of Suffolk then over-ruled all, they returned An≈øwer, That they could not give.

But notwith≈øtanding the≈øe Di≈øcour≈øes, the Commons taking the Kings Nece≈ø≈øities into Con≈øideration, Voted Three Sub≈øidies, and Three Fifteens, and that the Bill ≈øhould be brought in, as ≈øoon as the Grievances which were repre≈øented, were redre≈ø≈øed. They likewi≈øe con≈øidered of the matter of the Duke of Buckingham, and the mi≈øimploying the Revenue; and ordered that the Duke ≈øhould again have notice of their Intentions therein: But the King ob≈øerving they did not make ≈øuch ha≈øt as he expected, to an≈øwer his la≈øt Me≈ø≈øage, ≈øummons both Hou≈øes together; and by the Lord Keeper complains to them, For not puni≈øhing Dr. Turner, and Mr. Cook, and likewi≈øe for ≈øearching his Signet Office, and al≈øo ju≈øtified the D. of Buckingham to have acted nothing of Publick Imployment without his Special Warrant, and therefore forbid them to concern them≈øelves any further therein, as looking upon it to be Libelling his own Government; la≈øtly he blamed them for being too ≈øparing in the matter of Supply, and for ordering the Bill not to be brought in till their Grievances were heard and an≈øwered, which he would not admit of. This was the ≈øub≈øtance of the Lord Keepers Speech, to which the King him≈øelf added.

He must al≈øo put them in mind that his Father moved by their Coun≈øel and won by their Per≈øwa≈øions, broke the Treaties; and that he him≈øelf was their In≈øtrument towards his Father, and was glad to be In≈øtrumental in any thing which might plea≈øe the whole Body of the Realm, nor was there any then in greater Favour than the Duke, whom they now traduced; but that now finding him ≈øo far intangled in a War, that he could make no honourable nor ≈øafe Retreat, they made nece≈ø≈øity their Priviledge, and ≈øet what rate they plea≈øed upon their Supplies, a Practi≈øe not very obliging towards Kings: and whereas Mr. Cook told them, That it was better for them to die by a Forreign Enemy, than to be de≈øtroyed at home: Indeed he thought it to be more Honourable for a King to be Invaded, and almost de≈øtroyed by a Forreign Enemy, than to be de≈øpi≈øed at home.

After this, at a Conference of both Hou≈øes in the Painted Chamber, the Duke of Buckingham was commanded by the King, to explain ≈øome Expre≈ø≈øions in the Kings and the Lord Chancellors Speeches, which might be ≈øubject to mi≈øunder≈øtanding, which the Duke performed accordingly, and then gave a large Account of his Negotiation in the Low Countreys; as ≈øoon as the Duke had ended, the Lord Conway di≈øcour≈øed of the Treaties of Denmark and France, and the bu≈øine≈øs of the Navy, and affirmed they were not done by ≈øingle Councel, ≈øince King James him≈øelf commanded it.

The Commons in An≈øwer to the Kings la≈øt Speech, pre≈øented him with a Remon≈øtrance to this purpo≈øe; That they gratefully acknowledged His Maje≈øties Expre≈ø≈øions of Affection to his People and Parliament, That they had taken Mr. Cooks and Dr. Turners words into Con≈øideration, and might
have given a good Account thereof by this time, if his Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage had not interrupted them; That they had the Pre≈øidents of former Parliaments for ≈øearching the Letters of his Majesty and his Secretary of State, the Signet Office, and other Records, upon the like occa≈øions. That it was the unque≈øtionable Priviledge of Parliaments to complain of any Per≈øon of any degree, and their proceedings in relation to the Duke ≈øhould not prejudice either Crown or Kingdom: That they were willing to Supply his Nece≈ø≈øities Liberally and Faithfully, if Additions might be made of other things which concerned his Service, and were now in Con≈øultation among them.

His Maje≈øty having received it, returned this ≈øhort An≈øwer thereunto, That he would have them in the fir≈øt place, Con≈øult about Matters of the greate≈øt Importance, and that they ≈øhould have time enough for other things afterward.

This happened in the year 1626, and in the Second Year of his Maje≈øties Reign; about which time the Earl of Bri≈øtoll (being ordered by the King to be Examined by a Committee of Lords, concerning his Negotiation in Spain, and having been in Pri≈øon and prohibited acce≈øs to His Maje≈øty ever ≈øince his return) received a Letter from the Lord Conway, wherein, in order to his Relief he propounded to him from His Maje≈øty this Choice, Whether he would be quiet, and not be que≈øtioned for what was pa≈øt, and enjoy the benefit of the late Gracious Pardon? or whether he would ≈øtand upon his Ju≈øtification? To which he An≈øwered, That he did humbly acknowledge and accept of his Majesties Grace and Favour; And at the ≈øame time he Petitioned the Hou≈øe of Lords for his Liberty, or to come to a Tryal; who apylying them≈øelves to his Maje≈øty, he granted a Writ for the Earls coming to Parliament,
but with a Provi≈øo, That his Per≈øonal Attendance ≈øhould be forborn; whereupon the Earl ≈øent another Petition to the Lords that he might be heard, both as to his Re≈øtraint, and of what he had to ≈øay again≈øt the Duke. At which the King was much concerned, and ≈øignified to the Lords, That it was his Royal Plea≈øure, that the Earl of Bri≈øtol might be ≈øent for as a Delinquent to an≈øwer his Offences to the Hou≈øe, and his ≈øcandalizing the Duke of Buckingham and his Majesty likewi≈øe by Reflection.

Upon this the Earl was accordingly brought to the Bar, and being ready to be impeacht of High Trea≈øon by the Attorney General, he be≈øought their Lord≈øhips, That as he was a Freeman and Peer of this Realm untainted, and had ≈øomething to ≈øay of high Con≈øequence for his Maje≈øties Service, he might have liberty to ≈øpeak. Which being granted him, he ≈øaid, I accu≈øe that Man the Duke of Buckingham of High Trea≈øon. This unexpected procedure of the Earl, occa≈øioned the Attorney General to draw up a Charge again≈øt him, con≈øi≈øting of Eleven Articles containing Matters of divers Natures; whereupon the Earl afterwards gave a large Account of the Duke of Buckinghams proceedings towards him, and then preferr'd Twelve Articles again≈øt him; and be≈øides the≈øe Articles again≈øt the Duke, the Earl of Bri≈øtol exhibited Eleven others again≈øt the Lord Conway: the Earl likewi≈øe gave in his An≈øwer to each particular Article of his Impeachment.

Now whil≈øt the≈øe two Peers were thus conte≈øting, the Hou≈øe of Commons pre≈øented an Impeachment to the Lords again≈øt the Duke, con≈øi≈øting of Twelve Articles, to each of which the Duke made Replies, and the la≈øt of them being a matter of general Di≈øcour≈øe, it may ≈øeem nece≈ø≈øary to in≈øert
it, with the Dukes An≈øwer thereto.

p.q: That the Duke being a Sworn Servant of the the late King, did cau≈øe and provide certain Plai≈øters and Potions for his late Maje≈øty K. James in in his la≈øt Sickne≈øs without the Privity of his Maje≈øties Phy≈øicians, and that although tho≈øe Plai≈øters and Potions formerly applied, produced ≈øuch ill Effects, as many of his Sworn Phi≈øicians did di≈øallow, as prejudicial to his Maie≈øties Health, yet the Duke did apply them again to his Maje≈øty; whereupon great Di≈øtempers, and dangerous Symptoms appeared in him, which the Phy≈øitians imputed to tho≈øe Admini≈øtrations of the Duke, whereof his late Maje≈øty al≈øo complained: which is an Offence and Mi≈ødemeanor of ≈øo high a Nature as may be called an Act of Tran≈øcendent Pre≈øumption: And the ≈øaid Commons by Prote≈øtation, ≈øaving to them≈øelves the liberties of exhibiting hereafter any other Accu≈øation, or Impeachment again≈øt the Duke, and al≈øo of Replying unto what the Duke ≈øhall An≈øwer unto the ≈øaid Articles, do pray, That the ≈øaid Duke may be put to An≈øwer all and every the Premi≈øes, and that ≈øuch Proceeding, Examinations, Tryals and Judgments, may be upon every of them had as is agreeable to Law and Ju≈øtice.

div.p:
To this Article the Duke of Buckingham Replyed, That his late Maje≈øty being ≈øick of an Ague, a Di≈øea≈øe out of which the Duke recovered not long before, asked the Duke what he found mo≈øt Advantagious to his Health? The Duke replyed, a Plai≈øter, and Po≈ø≈øit Drink administred unto him by the Earl of Warwick's Phy≈øician, whereupon the King much de≈øired the Plai≈øter and Po≈ø≈øit drink to be ≈øent for, and the Duke delaying it, the King commanded a Servant of the Dukes to go for it, again≈øt the Dukes earnest reque≈øt; he humbly
Duke of Buckingham stabbed by John Felton
D: Buckingham ≈øtab'd by Felton
William Prynne, Henry Burton, and John Bastwick in pillories; crowd in foreground, buildings in background
Mr Pryn, Burton & Ba≈øtnich in ye Pillory
crowd waving sticks and throwing chairs in church; preacher in pulpit
The Tumult in Scotland upon Reading ye Comon prayr
craving his Majesty not to make u≈øe of it, without the Advice of his own Phy≈øicians and Experiment upon others; which the King ≈øaid he would do, and in confidence thereof the Duke left him, and went to London, and in the mean time he being ab≈øent, the ≈øaid Plai≈øter and Po≈ø≈øet Drink were brought; and at the Dukes return, his Maje≈øty commanded the Duke to give him the Po≈ø≈øet Drink, which he did, the Phy≈øicians then pre≈øent not ≈øeeming to mi≈ølike it; afterwards the Kings Health declining, and the Duke hearing a Rumour as if his Phy≈øick had done his Maje≈øty hurt, and that he had admini≈øtred Phy≈øick without Advice, the Duke acquainted the King therewith, who with much di≈øcontent replyed, They are wor≈øe then Devils that ≈øay ≈øo.

About this time the King again earne≈øtly pre≈ø≈øed the Hou≈øe of Commons for a ≈øpeedy Supply, by their Speaker Sir Heneage Finch; giving them to under≈øtand, That if there did not pa≈øs the Bill of Sub≈øidy by the end of the week following, it would inforce him to take other Re≈øolutions; and if by their denial, or delay, any thing of ill con≈øequence ≈øhould fall out either at home, or abroad, he called God and Man to witne≈øs, that he had done his part to prevent it, by calling his People together to advi≈øe with him; who≈øe ≈øitting (if they di≈øpatched this according to his de≈øire) he re≈øolved to continue, for the di≈øpatch of other Affairs, and after their Rece≈øs to bring them again together the next Winter.

Before the Commons ≈øent an An≈øwer, they drew up a Petition to his Maje≈øty. That he would be plea≈øed to Remove from all places of Tru≈øt and Authority, all ≈øuch Per≈øons as were either Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, or according to the Direction of former Acts of State, ju≈øtly to be ≈øu≈øpected to be ≈øuch. And herewith they likewi≈øe ≈øent a large Scrowl of the Names of all ≈øuch Noblemen and others
as continued in places of high Tru≈øt in the ≈øeveral Counties of England.

The An≈øwer to the late Articles again≈øt the Duke of Buckingham, being by him delivered into the Lords Hou≈øe, he de≈øired their Lord≈øhips to ≈øend to the Commons for a ≈øpeedy Reply; whereupon the Commons required a Copy of his An≈øwer. But the Duke fearing what might be the Effect thereof humbly applyed him≈øelf to the Lords, whom he intreated to allow him the benefit of a free and general Pardon granted by King James in Parliament in the 21≈øt. Year of his Reign, and likewi≈øe that of the Coronation.

Pre≈øently after the Commons drew up another Declaration of Grievances again≈øt the Duke, whom they re≈øolved utterly to overthrow, though contrary to the Inclination of the King; who being thereat incen≈øed, di≈ø≈øolved the Parliament the very next day, June 15. 1626. and committed the Earl of Bri≈øtol to the Tower, Publi≈øhing a Proclamation for burning all Copies of the ≈øaid Declaration. After which the King Publi≈øhed a Declaration, ≈øhewing the Grounds and Rea≈øons of his Di≈ø≈øolving this and the former Parliament.

Then ≈øeveral ways were Re≈øolved on for advancing the Kings Revenue, and ≈øpecial care was taken by the Councel for the levying of Cu≈øtoms and Impo≈øts upon all Merchandizes Imported and Exported, as being intended to have been ≈øettled by the Two la≈øt Parliaments, but prevented by their ≈øudden Di≈ø≈øolution: The Forfeitures of Papi≈øts likewi≈øe, which had been mi≈øimployed, were now taken into a more ≈øtrict Account; Privy Seals al≈øo were i≈ø≈øued out, and Benevolence propo≈øed, and at length a Commi≈ø≈øion for a General Loan was re≈øolved upon, as the mo≈øt convenient Method, ≈øince the
pre≈øent ≈øtate of Affairs admitted not of the way of a Parliament, and private In≈øtructions were given to the Commi≈ø≈øioners how to manage the bu≈øine≈øs, which upon their Faith and Allegiance they were commanded to keep Secret, and not to di≈øclo≈øe to any.

About this time ≈øome Souldiers returned from Cadiz, and were Quattered in the Countreys, and Money was rai≈øed for them, which made this Loan the more unwelcome; and Sir Randolph Crew for not appearing vigorous in promoting the Loan, was di≈øplaced from being L. Chief Ju≈øtice, and Sir Nich. Hyde advanced in his place; the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln was likewi≈øe informed again≈øt in the Star Chamber by Sir John Lamb, and Dr. Sybthorp, for ≈øpeaking again≈øt the Loan, and ≈øeeming to favour the Puritans and Nonconformi≈øts: Not long before which Bi≈øhop Laud (hearing that the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln endeavoured to ingratiate him≈øelf with the D. of Buckingham) Dreamed, That the Bi≈øhop came to him with Iron Chains, but returned free from them, that he leaped upon a Hor≈øe, departed and he could not overtake him; which was afterwards interpreted concerning the Bi≈øhop of Lincolns taking Arms for the Parliament in Wales, and his being at liberty, when Bi≈øhop Laud was impri≈øoned in the Tower.

There were ≈øeveral Occa≈øions at this time which required con≈øiderable Supplies of Money, for be≈øides that of the Palatinate, there was great probability of a War with France upon this Occa≈øion; the French King, Lewis the 13. had borrowed of his Brother in Law, the King of England, a Man of War called the Vauntguard, and ≈øix other Merchants Ships in pur≈øuance of a De≈øign again≈øt Italy, but with this expre≈øs Condition that they ≈øhould not be imployed again≈øt the Prote≈øtants at Rochel;
there having been an Agreement lately made between them and their King by the Mediation of the Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øadors: But Moun≈øieur Soulize, who was for the Prote≈øtants, taking the Advantage of the French Armies going into Italy, ≈øuddenly broke that Agreement; for getting ≈øome ≈ømall Ships together, he Surprized the I≈øle of Rhe, and ≈øome Ships in the Harbour, at which the French King being offended, turns his whole De≈øign from Italy to Rochel; and with the Seven Engli≈øh Ships under Admiral Pennington, Twenty Dutch Ships, and the French Navy, he furiou≈øly falls upon Soulize, forceth him from his Fa≈øtne≈øs, and cha≈øeth him to the I≈øle of Oleron: The King of England was much concerned at this Action of the French King, as a breach of his Royal Word, and demanded Satisfaction; which the French King deferring to give, the King Seized a Rich French Ship, and the French King Arre≈øted the Goods of the Engli≈øh Merchants in France, to the value of Three Hundred Thou≈øand Pounds; but at length all was Reconciled and Re≈øtored on both ≈øides.

Thus all ≈øeemed quiet at pre≈øent, till the In≈øolent deportment of the Queens Prie≈øts and Confe≈ø≈øor made another Rupture; who Impo≈øed upon her to go bare-foot, to Spin, to wait upon her Servants at their Dinners, nay to walk on Foot on a Rainy Morning, from Somer≈øet-Hou≈øe to St. Jame≈øes, and from thence as far as Tybourn Gallows, to offer up her Prayers for the Souls of ≈øome Je≈øuits, whom they ≈øtiled Martyrs who were formerly Executed there; her Confe≈ø≈øor him≈øelf Riding by her in a Coach. The≈øe and ≈øeveral other Arrogancies, being ju≈øtly charged upon the Queens French Dome≈øtick Servants, they were paid off, di≈øcharged, and ≈øent home: Upon which the French Arre≈øted
the Ships of the Engli≈øh Wine Merchants at Blay Ca≈øtle, which was ≈øo ill Re≈øented by his Maje≈øty of Great Britain; that he re≈øolved upon a Breach with France: But about the ≈øame time the Engli≈øh Fleet under the L. Willoughby, which were ≈øent to the Aid of the Rochellers, were ≈øo ≈øcattered by a Storm, that they could ≈øcarce get into ≈øafe Harbour.

The A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øment of the Loan was generally oppo≈øed, whereupon the People of the lower Rank were ordered to appear in the Military Yard near St. Martins in the Fields, before the Lieutenant of the Tower, to be Li≈øted for Souldiers; it being thought fit, that tho≈øe who refu≈øed to a≈ø≈øi≈øt with their Pur≈øes in Common Defence, ≈øhould be forced to ≈øerve in their Per≈øons; others of better Quality, were bound to appear at the Council Table; ≈øeveral of whom were committed Pri≈øoners to the Fleet, Mar≈øhal≈øea, Gatehou≈øe, and other Pri≈øons, and among them Sir John Eliot, who Petitioned his Maje≈øty and repeated many Pre≈øidents, That all manner of Aids and Taxes informer Kings Reigns were never levied but by the general Con≈øent of the Nobility and Commons A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament. However he was committed Pri≈øoner to the Gatehou≈øe, and upon the ≈øame Account Sir Peter Hayman was commanded to Serve his Maje≈øty in the Palatinate, which after he had ≈øettled his E≈øtate he did acordingly.

Doctor Sybthorp and Dr. Maynwaring, two Eminent Preachers at Court, about this time preached up the Nece≈ø≈øity and Duty of the Loan; one of them A≈ø≈øerting, That the Prince hath Power to Direct his Councel, and make Laws, and that Subjects, if they cannot Exhibit Active Obedience, in Ca≈øe the thing commanded ≈øhould be again≈øt the Law of God, or Nature, or more Impo≈ø≈øible, yet neverthele≈øs they ought
to yield Pa≈ø≈øive Obedience; and in all other Ca≈øes they were bound to Active Obedience. The other Affirmed, That the Kings Royal Command in Impo≈øing of Loans and Taxes, though without common con≈øent in Parliament, did Oblige the Subjects Con≈øcience upon Pain of Eternal Damnation. Which Po≈øitions being entertained by the Court with Applau≈øe, the Sermon of Dr. Sybthorp, call'd Apo≈øtolick Obedience, was Licen≈øed and Approved of by Dr. Laud B. of London; and an expre≈øs Command was ≈øent from the King to Archbi≈øhop Abbot to Licen≈øe it, which he refu≈øed, whereupon having been under ≈øome disfavour before, this Increa≈øed it, and he was ≈øu≈øpended from his Archiepi≈øcopal See, and a Commi≈ø≈øion was granted to Five Bi≈øhops to Execute his Office: After which the Bi≈øhop Publi≈øhed a Narrative of the Cau≈øe and Manner of his Su≈øpen≈øion.

Five of tho≈øe Gentlemen who were Impri≈øoned about the Loan; had their Habeas Corpus granted, and were brought to their Tryal before Sir Nicholas Hyde Lord Chief Ju≈øtice; where, after arguing the Ca≈øe between Council on both ≈øides, the L. Chief Ju≈øtice concluded, That ≈øince they were Committed by the Kings Authority, the Court could not Free them, ≈øo that they were remanded to Pri≈øon, till the Order came out for a General Relea≈øe.

The Iri≈øh Papists, in hope of ≈øome Remi≈ø≈øion of the Penal Laws, offered to Furni≈øh the King at their own Charge with a ≈øtanding Army of 5000 Foot and 500 Hor≈øe, and a large Contribution for ≈øecuring the Narrow Seas, which was oppo≈øed in England by Sir John Savil, and in Ireland by the Lord Primate of Armagh and divers others, as tending to pre≈øerve the Papists Intere≈øts, and ≈øinking the Prote≈øtants; upon which the L. Deputy moved
the Primate to endeavour to prevail with the Prote≈øtants to ≈øupply the Kings Nece≈ø≈øities; which he attempted to do in a very learned Speech, though not with the expected Succe≈øs.

In 1627, being the Third Year of his Maje≈øties Reign, the Duke of Buckingham, to clear his Reputation, as to the Charge of Negligence in his Admiral≈øhip, with much ado compleated his Naval Forces, con≈øi≈øting of Six Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot in Ten Ships Royal, and Ninety Merchant Men; with which he ≈øet Sail from Port≈ømouth June 27, and publi≈øhed a Manife≈øto of the Kings Affection to the Reformed Churches in France, and his di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt the la≈øt mi≈øimploying of his Ships again≈øt the Rochellers. But by ≈øeveral Accidents this great De≈øign mi≈øcarried, with the Death of near Two Thou≈øand common Souldiers, Thirty Pri≈øoners of Note and Fourty four Colours taken: But notwith≈øtanding this Expedition of the I≈øle of Rhe mi≈øcarried, yet at Sea there was ≈øomewhat better Succe≈øs; a great French Ship was taken upon the Coa≈øts of Holland, Laden with great Guns, Arms, and Ammunition of all ≈øorts, to a very con≈øiderable value; Sir John Pennington likewi≈øe took Thirty Four Rich French Merchantmen, homeward bound, which were all ≈øafely brought to England; the poor remains of the Army which came from the I≈øle of Rhe, mo≈øt of them Iri≈øh and Scots, and con≈øequently rude and boi≈øterous, were quartered in the Countrey Villages, which was very trouble≈øome to the People.

At this time the Exchequer was very low, and ≈øeveral late Enterprizes having mi≈øcarried, the Rochellers being al≈øo now more di≈øtre≈ø≈øed than ever; the cau≈øes of the≈øe evils were gravely repre≈øented by Sir Robert Cotton to ≈øeveral Lords of the Councill;
whereupon it was re≈øolved on by the Council, that a Parliament ≈øhould be called, and Writs were pre≈øently I≈ø≈øued out; A Commi≈ø≈øion likewi≈øe pa≈ø≈øed under the Great Seal, for rai≈øing Moneys through the Kingdome in Nature of an Exci≈øe; and the Lord Trea≈øurer was ordered to pay Thirty Thou≈øand Pound to Philip Burmelack, a Dutch Merchant, to be returned to Sir William Balfour and John Dalbier in the Low Countreys, for rai≈øing a Thou≈øand Hor≈øe; which cau≈øed ≈øtrange jealou≈øies and ≈øu≈øpicions among the People, as if the≈øe German Hor≈øe were de≈øigned to inforce the payment of the Exci≈øe. There was ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe about Levying Ship money, but it was declined at that time, becau≈øe of the Parliament approaching.

In the mean time a company of Je≈øuites were apprehended in an Hou≈øe at Clerkenwell, which was de≈øigned for a Colledge of that Order; where among other Papers, a Letter was found, di≈øcovering their ≈øecret De≈øigns they had laid for imbroiling Church and State.

Upon the 17th of March 1627, the Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, the Commons chu≈øing Sin John Finch Speaker, the King in a Speech tells the two Hou≈øes, That the greatne≈øs of the danger was ≈øuch, as required a ≈øpeedy Supply, and that therefore they might re≈øt a≈ø≈øured it was the principal cau≈øe of their Meeting; wherein he hoped they would ≈øhew them≈øelves ≈øuch true Patriots of the true Religion, the Laws and Liberties of this State, and the ju≈øt defence of their Friends and Allies, now in ≈øuch hazard by Popi≈øh Enemies, as not to deceive his Expectations, which were very great, though indeed ≈øomewhat nipt, by Remembrance of the Di≈øtractions of the la≈øt Meeting. The Lord Keeper likewi≈øe Inforc'd the Kings Speech, and earne≈øtly pre≈ø≈øed them, to con≈øider of ≈øome ≈øpeedy way for
Supplying his Maje≈øties Nece≈ø≈øities.

Before the Parliament began any debate, a Letter came to them Directed, To the Members of the Hou≈øe of Commons, called A Speech without Doors; di≈øcovering the Grievances and Inconveniences of the State, from one who had been a Member of the former Parliament. The fir≈øt thing taken into Con≈øideration by the Commons, was the Grievances of the Kingdom, and the fir≈øt thing In≈øi≈øted on was the Ca≈øe of tho≈øe Gentlemen for refu≈øing the Loan, and who notwith≈øtanding their Habeas Corpus, were Remanded to Pri≈øon; and after a long Debate between ≈øeveral Members, who a≈ø≈øerted the Illegality of the Loan, and al≈øo their Impri≈øonment for refu≈øing it; the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Hyde and ≈øeveral other Judges were de≈øired to declare them≈øelves; who ju≈øtified their own proceedings, alledging, That if they had granted them Bail upon Habeas Corpus, it would have reflected upon the King, as if he had unju≈øtly Impri≈øoned them: But in conclu≈øion it was re≈øolved upon the Que≈øtion in the Hou≈øe of Commons, Nemine Contradicente: 1. That no man ought to be restrained by the Command of the King or Privy Council, without ≈øome Cau≈øe of the Commitment. 2. That the Writ of Habeas Corpus ought to be granted upon Reque≈øt to every Man that is re≈øtrained, though by the Command of the King, the Privy Council, or any other. 3. That if a Freeman be impri≈øoned by the Command of the King, the Privy Council, or any other, and no Cau≈øe of ≈øuch Commitment expre≈ø≈øed, and the ≈øame be returned upon an Habeas Corpus granted for the ≈øaid Party, then he ought to be delivered or Bailed.

Then the Parliament proceeded to draw up a Petition again≈øt Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, con≈øi≈øting of the≈øe particulars. 1. That all Laws and Statutes again≈øt Je≈øuites and Popi≈øh Prie≈øts, be put in power and Execution. 2. That a ≈øtrict cour≈øe be taken for the Apprehending
and Di≈øcovering of them. 3. That all Popi≈øh Recu≈øants be prohibited from coming to Court, or within Ten Miles of London. 4. That no place of Trust or Authority ≈øhall be committed to Popi≈øh Recu≈øants; with ≈øeveral other particulars to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; which Petition was pre≈øented from the Lords and Commons to the King by the Lord Keeper, who gave a full and ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer to every Article; after which Five Sub≈øidies were granted to the King, which gave ≈øo great ≈øatisfaction to his Maje≈øty, that he ≈øent them Word; He would deny them nothing of their Liberties which any of his Predece≈ø≈øors had granted: A Petition was then pre≈øented again≈øt Quartering Souldiers in the Countries, to which the King promi≈øed an An≈øwer in convenient time; whereupon the Commons fell upon the memorable Petition of Right, and after ≈øeveral of the Members had delivered their Opinions at large concerning ≈øome Clau≈øes in it, the Lords agreed that without any Addition or Preface it ≈øhould be pre≈øented to the King; the Sub≈øtance whereof was.

1. They do pray his mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, That no man hereafter be compelled to make or yield any Gift, Loan, Benevolence, Tax, or ≈øuch like Charge, without common con≈øent by Act of Parliament, and that none be called to make An≈øwer, or to take? ≈øuch Oath, or to give Attendance, or be confined, or otherwi≈øe be mole≈øted or di≈øquieted concerning the ≈øame, or for Refu≈øal thereof. 2. That no Freeman be taken and impri≈øoned or be di≈ø≈øei≈øed of his Freehold of Liberty, or his free Customs, or be outlawed, or exiled, but by the lawful Judgment of his Peers, or by the Laws of the Land. 2. That your Majesty would be plea≈øed to remove the Souldiers and Marriners now Billeted in ≈øeveral Counties; and that your People may not be ≈øo burdened for
the time to come. 4. That the late Commi≈ø≈øions for proceeding by Martial Law, may be revoked and annulled, and that hereafter no Commi≈ø≈øion of like Nature may I≈ø≈øue forth to any Per≈øon or Per≈øons what≈øoever, to be Executed, lea≈øt by colour of them, any of your Maje≈øties Subjects be de≈øtroyed, or put to death contrary to Law and the Franchi≈øes of the Law.

p.hi: All which we most humbly pray your mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty as their Rights and Liberties according to the Laws and Statutes of this Realm; And that your Maje≈øty would al≈øo vouch≈øafe to declare, That all Awards, Doings, or proceedings, to the prejudice of your People, ≈øhall not be drawn hereafter into con≈øequence and Example.

div.p: After this there came a Letter from the King to the Hou≈øe of Lords, wherein among other things, His Maje≈øty declared it to be his Royal plea≈øure, which God willing he would ever continue and con≈øtantly maintain; That neither he, nor his Privy Council, ≈øhould or would hereafter, command to Pri≈øon, or otherwi≈øe restrain the Per≈øons of any for not lending Money: nor for any Cau≈øe which in his Con≈øcience did not concern the publick good; nor would he be drawn to pretend any cau≈øe, wherein his judgment was not fully ≈øatisfied.

This, Sir Thomas Wentworth (afterwards Earl of Strafford) ≈øaid, Was a Letter of Grace, but that the People were not ≈øo ≈øatisfied but by a Parliamentary way, That the debate would ≈øpend much time, That it was not directed to the Hou≈øe of Commons, and that the Petition it ≈øelf would rectify all mi≈øtakes. When the Petition of Right was pre≈øented to the King, the An≈øwer following was quickly returned; The King willeth that Right be done according to the Laws and Customs of the Realm; and that the Statutes be put in due Execution, that his Subjects may have no cau≈øe to complain of any wrong or Oppre≈ø≈øions, contrary
to their just Rights and Liberties; to the Pre≈øervation Whereof he holds him≈øelf in Con≈øcience as well obliged, as to that of his Prerogative.

This An≈øwer being Read in the Hou≈øe of Commons, was not judged Satisfactory; and therefore upon their Humble Petition for a clear and ≈øatisfactory An≈øwer to the Petition of Right, His Maje≈øty to ≈øhew how free and candid his Conce≈ø≈øions were to his Subjects, ≈øent them this ≈øhort but full An≈øwer; Soit Droit Lait come il e≈øt de≈øire, Let it be done according to your de≈øire. Which An≈øwer was Received with the general joy and Satisfaction of both Hou≈øes; and the Citizens made Bonefires, and Rung Bells, and his Maje≈øty for further Satisfaction was plea≈øed to receive into Favour Abbot, Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, Bi≈øhop Williams, and ≈øeveral others: His Maje≈øty likewi≈øe ≈øuffered the Commi≈ø≈øion of Loan and Exci≈øe to be cancelled in his pre≈øence, ≈øo that all di≈øcontents of every ≈øide ≈øeemed to be bani≈øhed.

In 1628 the Fourth year of his Maje≈øties Reign, the Parliament not being ≈øatisfied of their former di≈øappointment about the Duke of Buckingham, drew up another Remon≈øtrance again≈øt him, and likewi≈øe again≈øt Bi≈øhop Neal, and Bi≈øhop Laud, which they pre≈øented to the King with the Bill of Sub≈øidies: His Maje≈øty telling them, That he expected not ≈øuch a Return for his favourable An≈øwer to the petition of Right, and as for the Grievances he would take time to con≈øider of them.

An Information being likewi≈øe Exhibited again≈øt the Duke in the Star Chamber, for divers Offences and Mi≈ødemeanors, an Order was made in that Court, that all proceedings thereupon ≈øhould be taken off the File, by the Kings expre≈øs Will and Plea≈øure: And becau≈øe it had been reported by a
Member of Parliament that the Duke ≈øhould ≈øay at his Table, Pi≈øh, it matters not what the Parliament doth, for without my leave and Authority, they ≈øhall not be able to touch the Hair of a Dog: The Duke made Prote≈øtation in the Hou≈øe of Lords, That be never had tho≈øe words ≈øo much as in his Thoughts. But the King being re≈øolved to hold up the Duke, ≈øent ≈øo brisk an An≈øwer to their Remon≈øtrances, as provoked the Commons (who had ≈øoon forgot his Maje≈øties late Act of Grace) to que≈øtion his taking Tunnage and Poundage; which being of too valuable con≈øideration to be hazarded, his Maje≈øty obviated by Adjourning the Parliament to the 20th. of October, there being ≈øeveral Acts pa≈ø≈øed by them, One About the Lords day, Another To re≈øtrain the ≈øending any to be Popi≈øhly bread beyond the Seas, Another for Confirmation of the Sub≈øidies granted by the Clergie, and for the grant of Five Entire Sub≈øidies upon the Temporality, and divers more.

Much about this time Dr. Lamb, who was in great Favour with the Duke of Buckingham (and had been formerly twice Arraigned, once for Necromancy, and another time for a Rape) was killed by the furious Multitude in Lothbury, who hated him both for his own ≈øake and the Dukes, he being called the Dukes Devil; and though he were guarded by four Con≈øtables and their Attendants, yet the Rabble ≈øtruk him down, beat out one of his eyes, and left him half dead on the Ground, from whence he was called to the Poultrey Counter, where he died, according to his own Prediction the year before; being pitied by few, and loved of none.

The Earl of Denbigh having a while ≈øince ≈øailed with Fifty Ships to the relief of Rochel, was repelled with much lo≈øs; ≈øo that de≈øpairing of Succe≈øs, he returned back to Plymouth; whereupon another
Expedition was re≈øolved on, with a more con≈øiderable Navy, and the Duke of Buckingham was de≈øigned Admiral, who going to Port≈ømouth, in order to ha≈øtning of bu≈øine≈øs, one John Felton a Leiutenant ≈øtabbed him to the heart with a Knife; which the Murtherer flying, left ≈øticking in his Body, till the Duke him≈øelf dragg'd it out, and immediately after died: Felton was ≈øoon apprehended by the Servants, and laden with Irons, and being asked, what inclined him to commit ≈øo horrid an Action? He boldly an≈øwered, He killed him for the cau≈øe of God and his Countrey: He likewi≈øe fa≈øtned a Paper in the Crown of his Hart, which intimated, That his only Motive to this Fact, was the late Remon≈øtrance of the Commons again≈øt the Duke, and that he could not ≈øacrifice his Life in a nobler Cau≈øe, than by delivering his Countrey from ≈øo great an Enemy. Felton was afterwards Condemned and Hanged at Tybourn, and his Body hanged upon a Gibbet at Port≈ømouth.

There was ob≈øervation made of divers Pa≈ø≈øages pre≈øaging the Dukes Death, as that his Picture fell down in the high Commi≈ø≈øion Chamber at Lambeth, That the Lady Davis reputed a Prophete≈øs, had foretold in June, that the Dukes fatal time would not come till Augu≈øt; and la≈øtly, that Mr. Tower≈øon of the Cu≈øtomhou≈øe was charged by a Phanta≈øm or Gho≈øt, re≈øembling the Dukes Father, to tell him, That if he changed not his cour≈øes, he ≈øhould ≈øhortly become a great Fairing to the City of London; which was afterwards judg'd to be accompli≈øhed by his death, which happened the day before the Fair, that is Augu≈øt 23. 1628.

However the Fleet ≈øet Sail under the Command of the Earl of Lind≈øey, and came to the Bar of Rochel Haven, where there was a wonderful Barracado
contrived by Cardinal Richlieu, of Fourteen Hundred Yards, cro≈øs the Channel; however the Earl adventured in, pa≈ø≈øing the Forts and Outworks, but the Wind changing, drove the Ships upon each other, which unhappy Accident made the Rochellers de≈øpair of Relief, and occa≈øioned the pre≈øent ≈øurrender of the Town; after which the Earl of Lind≈øey brought the Fleet ≈øafe home again.

The Parliament was to have met in October, but by rea≈øon of ≈øome ill news during this Expedition, they were again Adjourned to January 20th; in which time the Merchants refu≈øing to pay Cu≈øtom, had their goods ≈øeized; Complaint whereof being made to the Parliament, the King ≈øummons the two Hou≈øes to the Banquetting Hou≈øe at White-hall, and requires them to pa≈øs the promi≈øed Bill of Tunnage and Poundage, for ending all differences, ≈øince it was too precious a Jewel of the Crown to be ≈øo lightly forgone.

But the Commons being forward enough to take all occa≈øions to put of the Kings Reque≈øts, An≈øwered, That Gods Cau≈øe was to be preferr'd before the Kings, and they would therefore in the fir≈øt place con≈øult concerning Religion; and thereupon appointed one Committee for Religion, and another for Civil Matters; in the la≈øt wherof there was a complaint that the Petition of Right, had been Printed with the Kings fir≈øt An≈øwer only, and not with the la≈øt which was judged Satisfactory: Another complaint was likewi≈øe made about the Cu≈øtoms, and Mr. Rolls a Member of the Hou≈øe affirmed, That it was reported ≈øome of the Officers of the Cu≈øtom-hou≈øe ≈øhould ≈øay, Though all the Parliament were in you, we would take your Goods; Mr. Richard Chambers was likewi≈øe impri≈øoned for ≈øaying at the Council Table, That ≈øuch great Customs and Impo≈øitions were required
of the Merchants in England, as were in no other Place and that they were more ≈øcrewed up than under the Turk After which a Form of Submi≈ø≈øion being ≈øent him from the Star Chamber to ≈øub≈øcribe his name there to, he in≈øtead of owning it as a fault underwrit the≈øe words, All the above≈øaid Contents I Richard Chambers do utterly abhor and dete≈øt, as mo≈øt unju≈øt and fal≈øe: and never to death will acknowledge any par ‚Ä¢ thereof; and quoted divers Scriptures again≈øt Oppre≈ø≈øion and Inju≈øtice.

As to the Printing the Petition of Right, the Printer was que≈øtioned, and for the other, the Farmer ‚Ä¢
of the Cu≈øtoms were challenged to An≈øwer it, bu ‚Ä¢ the King excu≈øed them, as Acting by his Command! yet this not being clear to the Parliament they would have proceeded again≈øt them as Delinquents, whereupon the King ≈øent them Word, That in honour he could not, nor would give way there to: Which ≈øo increa≈øed the Parliament, that they Adjourned them≈øelves for ≈øome days, and the ‚Ä¢ meeting again, the King Adjourned them further till March 1. upon which Sir John Eliot ≈øtood up, and accu≈øed the Lord Trea ≈øurer Weston, as an Enemy to the Engli≈øh Trade, and de≈øigning to transfer it to Forreigners; which Speech cau≈øed a further Adjournment to March 10. The Commons inraged hereat, blamed their Speaker for admitting the Me≈ø≈øage, and ordered Sir John Eliot to read their Remon≈øtrance (the Speaker and Clerk refu≈øing to do it) which was to this purpo≈øe;

That the Hou≈øe had con≈øidered of the Bill for Tunnage and Poundage, but being overprest with other bu≈øine≈øs, and that of it ≈øelf ≈øo perplext, as would require much lei≈øure to di≈øcharge, could not at that time fini≈øh it; this pre≈øent Se≈ø≈øion moving ha≈øtily to an end; and lea≈øt his Majesty ≈øhould hereafter, as he had done heretofore,
encline to Evil Spirits, or to be abu≈øed to believe, that might justly receive the Sub≈øidies of Tonnage and Poundage, which they humbly declare to be again≈øt the Fundamental Law of the Nation, and contrary to the Kings late An≈øwer to the Petition of Right) therefore they crave that his Majesty would for the future forbear ≈øuch Taxes, and not take it ill, if his Subjects refu≈øe what is demanded by Arbitrary and unwarrantable Power.

A Report was likewi≈øe made from the Committee of Pardons by Oliver Cromwell, (a fatal name afterward) that Dr. Neal Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, was cheifly In≈øtrumental, in procuring the Kings hand to the Pardons of Dr. Sybthorp, Dr. Maynwaring. Mr. Cou≈øens, and Mr. Montague, and that he had likewi≈øe preferr'd Dr. Maynwaring to a rich Living, though cen≈øured by the former Parliament, and di≈øabled from holding any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Dignity; and al≈øo that he was a Countenancer not only of Arminiani≈øm, but flat Popery.

The Commons having prepared their Remon≈øtrance about the Bill of Tonnage and Poundage, they required their Speaker to put it to the Vote, whether it ≈øhould be pre≈øented to the King, or not; but the Speaker refu≈øed it, and accordingly to the Kings order would have gone away; but Mr. Hollis would not ≈øuffer him to ≈øtir till him≈øelf had read the Prote≈øtation of the Hou≈øe, con≈øi≈øting of 3 Heads.

1. Whoever ≈øhall bring in any Innovation of Religion, or by favour ≈øeek to introduce Popery, or Arminiani≈øm, or other Opinions, di≈øagreeing from the True and Orthodox Church, ≈øhall be reputed a Capital Enemy to this Kingdom and Common-wealth. 2. Who≈øoever ≈øhall Coun≈øel or Advi≈øe, the taking, or levying the Sub≈øidies of Tonnage and Poundage; not being granted by Parliament, or ≈øhall be an Actor or In≈øtrument therein, ≈øhall be likewi≈øe reputed a Capital Enemy to the Commonwealth. 3. If any man ≈øhall yield voluntarily, or
pay the ≈øame; not being granted by Parliament, he ≈øhall be reputed a Betrayer of the Liberties of England, and an Enemy to the Commonwealth.

The≈øe Articles were entertained with the general Approbation of the Members, but were much di≈øliked by the King, who immediately ≈øent for the Serjeant of the Mace out of the Hou≈øe of Commons, but Sir Miles Hobart took the Key from him, and locking the door would not ≈øuffer him to go forth, at which the King being very much offended, he ≈øends the U≈øher of the Black Rod to di≈ø≈øolve them, who was not admitted in, whereupon the King, with his Guard of Pen≈øioners, were re≈øolved to force their Entrance; which the Commons having notice of, they ≈øuddenly went all out of the Hou≈øe; and this was the end of this Parliament.

After their Di≈ø≈øolution, the King publi≈øheth a Declaration of the Cau≈øes thereof; and then que≈øtion'd Eleven of the Refractory Members at the Council Table, who were all committed to divers Pri≈øons. About the ≈øame time the Marquis of Huntley, Sheriff of the greate≈øt part of Scotland, neglecting the Order of the Council for ≈øeizing ≈øome Prie≈øts and Je≈øuites, who publickly ≈øaid Ma≈øs and committed other In≈øolences at Aberdeen, with ≈øeveral other Lords, who joyned with him, and refu≈øed to appear upon Summons, and had likewi≈øe given notice to the Prie≈øts and Je≈øuites to e≈øcape, were proclaimed Rebels and Traitors to the King and Kingdom; upon which they fled into England, The French King having had much lo≈øs by the War with England, did now therefore propo≈øe and conclude a Peace with the King, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeveral Articles.

A Paper was about this time di≈øper≈øed abroad, containing ≈øome Projects how the King might Augment
his Revenues without the help of Parliaments upon which the Earls of Bedford, Somer≈øet, and Clare with others, where committed upon Information that they had di≈øper≈øed ≈øome Copies of them; but Sir David Fowls ≈øoon cleared them, who depo≈øed upon Oath, that it was contrived near Sixteen years before, by Sir Robert-Dudley Son to the Earl of Leice≈øter, when he was in Italy.

The di≈ø≈øolving the la≈øt Parliament procured great Animo≈øities in the People again≈øt the Prime Mini≈øters of State, which occa≈øioned divers Invective Libels to be di≈øper≈øed abroad, whereof one again≈øt Bi≈øhop Laud was found in the Dean of St. Pauls Yard to this Effect. Laud look to thy ≈øelf, be a≈ø≈øured thy life is ≈øought; as thou art the Fountain of Wickedne≈øs, repent of thy mon≈øtrous ≈øin before thou be taken out of the World; and a≈ø≈øure thy ≈øelf, Neither God, nor the World, can endure ≈øuch a vile Councellor, or Whi≈øperer. Another very bitter Libel was ≈øcattered again≈øt the Lord Trea≈øurer We≈øton: On the other ≈øide ≈øome con≈øidering the un≈øuccesfulne≈øs of this and the two former Parliaments, advi≈øed never for the future to call any more Parliaments; and to that end the forementioned Book of Projects was publi≈øhed, and addre≈øt to the King, propo≈øing ≈øome methods to prevent the Impertinency of Parliaments (as he called them) for time to come, by the Example of Lewes 11th. of France; who pretended that the Commons or Third E≈øtate, did incroach too much upon the Nobility and Clergy, di≈ø≈øolved it; and never after ≈øuffered the People freely to Elect their Repre≈øentatives: but nominated certain Eminent Per≈øons him≈øelf in≈øtead thereof, which is called, L' A≈ø≈øembly des Notabiles, or the A≈ø≈øembly of Chief, or Principal Men; and the Methods propo≈øed to avoid Parliaments were:

1. To have a Fortre≈øs in every con≈øiderable Town. 2. To cau≈øe high-ways to be made through all ≈øuch Towns. 3. To make none of the Inhabitants Governors of tho≈øe Fortre≈ø≈øes. 4. To let none pa≈øs through tho≈øe Towns without a Ticket. 5. To have the Names of all Lodgers taken by Innkeepers. 6. To impo≈øe a general Oath upon the Subjects, not to oppo≈øe any of the≈øe Contrivances. And to increa≈øe the Kings Revenue, the Advice was, 1. To demand the Tenth part of every Mans E≈øtate. 2. To buy all Lea≈øes upon the Crown Lands. 3. To take the benefit of Salt into his own hands. 4. To demand a Rate for Sealing the Weights every year. 5. To lay a Taxe upon Wools. 6. Upon every Lawyers Fee. 7. Upon Inns and Victualling Hou≈øes for a Licence. 8. Upon all Cattle, Fle≈øh, and Hor≈øes ≈øold in the Market. 9. Upon all Lands Alienated. 10. To ≈øet a Rate upon all Offices in his Majesties Grant. 11. To Reduce his Majesties Hou≈øhold to board wages. 12. To lay a Taxe upon White Meats on fasting days. 13. To lay an Impo≈øition upon the Papi≈øts Lands. 14. To Advance ≈øome Hundreds of Per≈øons to Honours. 15. To prohibit exce≈øs in Apparel, which would ≈øave the Gentry more Money, then what they were Taxed would amount to.

figure.figDesc: crowd attacking Lambeth Palace with sticks or spears
figure.head: The In≈øurection of the Apprentices at Lambeth

figure.figDesc: Earl of Strafford beheaded on Tower Hill: executioner preparing to use ax on prone figure on scaffold, surrounded by a crowd;Tower of London in background
figure.head: The E: of Strafford beheaded on Towerhill.
