figure.head: Cheap≈øide Cro≈øs pulled down in 1643.

div.p: Upon May 29. 1630, the Queen was delivered of a Son at St. James's, who was Chri≈øtened Charles; and Pre≈øerved by Providence, to Succeed his Father in the≈øe Three Kingdoms, as his Rightful Inheritance, after the Mi≈øeries of a long and tedious Exile from his Native Countrey, unto which he was at length happily Re≈øtored, with the general Con≈øent and Acclamations of the whole Kingdom, The King of France, and the Prince Elector Yalatine, repre≈øented by the Duke of Lenox, and the Marquis Hamilton, were his Godfathers, and the Queen Mother of France, repre≈øented by the Dutche≈øs of Richmond, his Godmother, It was ob≈øerved that at his Nativity a Star was ≈øeen at Noonday, which might portend ≈øome extraordinary Pa≈ø≈øages of this Princes Life.

About this time Dr. Leighton was ≈øentenced in the Star Chamber, to have his Body Whipt, his Fore-head Stigmatized, his Ears Cropt, his No≈øe Slit; for publi≈øhing a Book called Sions Plea: wherein he exhorted the late Parliament to ≈ømite the Bi≈øhops under the Fifth Rib; and called the Queen the Daughter of Heth, a Canaanite and Idolatre≈øs: which Sentence was accordingly inflicted on him.

In Ireland the Papi≈øts pre≈øumed on St. Stephens day to ≈øay Ma≈øs in Dublin, while the Lords Chief Ju≈øtices were at Church; who having notice thereof, ordered the Prei≈øts, Crucifixes, and Ve≈øtments, to be ≈øeized; and Eight Popi≈øh Aldermen
were likewi≈øe Impri≈øoned for not A≈ø≈øi≈øting the Mayor; but ≈øome Papi≈øts making a Tumult, re≈øcued the Prie≈øts, whom the Guards again forced to deliver back. Upon Information of this Riot and In≈øolency, Fifteen Hou≈øes were by ≈øpecial Order from the Council ≈øeized upon for his Maje≈øties u≈øe; and the Prie≈øts and Fryers ≈øo di≈øturbed, that two of them hanged them≈øelves: Neither did the Papi≈øts agree together, for there were great Conte≈øts in England between the Je≈øuites and Secular Priests.

The Earl of E≈ø≈øex had many years before married the Lady Howard, who complaining of his In≈øufficiency for Marriage Duties, the Cau≈øe was brought to a Tryal; and it being made appear by a Jury of Midwives and the Earls own Confe≈ø≈øion, That he never could, and believed he never ≈øhould, carnally know her: Thereupon Sentence of Divorce between him and his Lady was pronounced by the Bi≈øhops: However the Earl was re≈øolved to try his Fortune once more, and therefore upon his return out of the Low Countreys, where he had been for ≈øome time a Souldier, he now Married a Daughter of Sir William Paulet of Wilt≈øhire; but a while after ≈øhe objecting the ≈øame cau≈øe of complaint, de≈øired likewi≈øe to be Divorced from him; which the Earl ea≈øily cou≈øented to, and it was done accordingly.

In the year 1631, and the 7th of his Maje≈øties Reign, Mervin Lord Audly, and Earl of Ca≈øtlehaven, was Tryed by his Peers upon the Petition of his own Son and Heir, for Rape and Sodomy; many unnatural and bea≈øtly Actions being proved again≈øt him: whereupon he received Sentence to be Hanged, but had the Favour to be Beheaded at Tower-hill. This Earl was born of a very honourable
Family, and educated in the Prote≈øtant Religion, but turned Papi≈øt to have the more liberty to commit wickedne≈øs; in which he grew to ≈øo great aheight, that he impudently declared in the pre≈øence of ≈øome Lords, As others had their ≈øeveral Delights, ≈øome in one thing, ≈øome in another; ≈øo his whole Delight was in damning Souls, by enticing Men to ≈øuch Acts as might ≈øurely effect it.

About this time Sir Giles Allington was Convented for Marrying his own Niece, and was fined Twelve thou≈øand Pound to the King, and to give Twenty thou≈øand Pound Bond never to cohabit, or come in private with his Niece again; and both of them to do Penance at St. Pauls Cro≈øs, or St. Maries in Cambridge. which they accordingly did.

The Protestants were very much di≈øcontented in Ireland, that the Papi≈øts were di≈øcharged from paying the State Penalty of Twelve Pence a Sunday for not going to Church; whereby their Number was wonderfully increa≈øed: Whereupon the King recalled the Lords Ju≈øtices, who then governed that Kingdom, and ≈øent Vi≈øcount Wentworth (afterward Earl of Strafford) thither as Lord Deputy, as judging that the≈øe di≈øtempers would be better compo≈øed under a ≈øingle Government.

In the year 1633, and the 9th of his Maje≈øties Reign, the King made a Journey into Scotland, attended with ≈øeveral of the Nobility and Per≈øons of Quality; and June 18 was ≈øolemnly Crowned King at Edenbourgh, which Solemnity being fini≈øhed, the King calls a Parliament, and pa≈ø≈øeth an Act for Ratification of the old Acts; though ≈øome affirmed, That the Confirmation of Epi≈øcopacy was intended thereby, and therefore (though in vain) oppo≈øed it; upon which ≈øome of tho≈øe Per≈øons
became a while after principal Men among the Covenanters: In this Scotti≈øh Parliament, that Nation ≈øhewed then ≈øome ≈øigns of diaffection to the King, by Rea≈øon of ≈øeveral Acts which then pa≈ø≈øed; and the generality of the People (who without doubt were influenced by the greater Malecontents) would not ≈øuffer the Bi≈øhop of Dumblain, Dean of the Kings Private Chappel there, to perform Prayers twice a day after the Engli≈øh manner; neither dur≈øt they receive the Communiou on their knees, nor wear a Surplice upon Sundays and Holy days.

Not long before his Maje≈øty went to Scotland, being de≈øirous, if po≈ø≈øible to have prevented that Trouble, the King writ to a Scotti≈øh Lord who was intru≈øted with that Crown, to bring it into England, that he might be Crowned here; but the Lord returned An≈øwer, That he dur≈øt not be ≈øo fal≈øe to his Tru≈øt, but if his Maje≈øty would be plea≈øed to accept thereof in Scotland, he ≈øhould find tho≈øe his People ready to yield him the highe≈øt Honour; but if he ≈øhould long defer that Duty, they might perbaps be inclined to make choice of another King. A very ≈øtrange and unu≈øual An≈øwer from a Subject to a Prince.

October 13, 1633. The Queen was delivered of her Second Son, who was Baptized James, and de≈øigned Duke of York; and about that time died George Abbot L. Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, and William Laud Bi≈øhop of London was Elected into his place.

In the Year 1634 the Engli≈øh Coa≈øts were very much Infe≈øted by Pyrates, and the Fi≈øhing Trade almo≈øt ingro≈ø≈øed by the Hollanders; and his Maje≈øty having occa≈øion for Money to Regain his Ab≈øolute Dominion over the Britti≈øh Seas, the De≈øign
of Shipmoney was fir≈øt ≈øet on foot; and Attorney General Noy being con≈øulted about it, he out of ≈øome old Records finds an Ancient Pre≈øident of Rai≈øing a Tax upon the Nation, by the Authority of the King alone, for ≈øetting out a Navy in ca≈øe of danger; which was thereupon accordingly put in Execution, and by this Tax the King rai≈øed by Writ above Twenty thou≈øand pound a Month, though not without great di≈øcontent both among the Clergy and Laiety.

The Di≈øcontents in Scotland began to increa≈øe, and a Book was publi≈øhed charging the King with indirect proceedings in the la≈øt Parliament and a tendancy to the Romi≈øh Belief, and to blow up the≈øe Scoth Sparks to a Flame, Cardinal Richlieu ≈øent over his Chaplain and another Gentleman, to heighten their Di≈øcontents: The Author of that Book was ≈øeized, and found to be abbetted by the Lord Balmerino, the Treacherous Son of a perfidious Father; who was thereupon Arraigned by his Peers, and Sentenced to Death, but Pardoned by the King.

At this time Gregory Panzani a Prie≈øt, was ≈øen over by the Pope with a Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyer and Terminer to decide the difference between the Je≈øuites and Secular Prie≈øts, and In≈øinuating him≈øelf into the Favour of the Lord Cottington, and Secretary Windebank, he endeavours to di≈øcover how far the King might be per≈øwaded about giving Toleration to the Popi≈øh Religion; as to allow them a Popi≈øh Bi≈øhop to re≈øide here, but nominated and limited by the King; and that the Pope might ≈øend a Nuncio to the Queen; but having made ≈øome agreement between the Je≈øuites and Prie≈øts Panzani returned to Rome, and left the further tran≈øacting of Bu≈øine≈øs to Seignior Con, who ≈øtaid in his room.

In the year 1635, A Noble Fleet was fitted out, by the Supply of Shipmoney, con≈øi≈øting of Forty Sail, under the Earl of Lind≈øey, to ≈øcour the Seas from Pyrates; at which time the French and Hollanders had confederated again≈øt the Spaniard in Flanders both by Land and Sea; but the Engli≈øh Fleet removed the Hollanders from before Dunkirk, and the Common People inraged by the French in≈øolencies at Land, ro≈øe up again≈øt them, and A≈ø≈øi≈øted the Spaniard to expel them the Countrey.

One Robert Par of Shrop≈øhire, a Man almo≈øt an Hundred and three≈øcore years old, was this year brought to London by the Earl of Arundel as a Rarity or Miracle, where he dyed ≈øoon after; though it is very probable he might have lived much longer, if he had continued at home; for his removal from his own Air, change of Diet, and the tediou≈øne≈øs of ≈øo long a Journey, may be ≈øuppo≈øed to have ha≈øtned his end.

December, 23, 1635. the Lady Elizabeth the Kings Second Daughter was born, and to Congratulate the Queens happy delivery, the Hollander ≈øent an Amba≈ø≈øador with a pre≈øent of an extraordinary value; that is, a Ma≈ø≈øy Piece of Ambergreece, Two large and almo≈øt Tran≈øparent China Di≈øhes; a Clock of mo≈øt excellent Workman≈øhip, which was made by Rodulphus Emperour of Germany; and likewi≈øe ≈øeveral curious pieces of Painting.

Dr. William Juxon, Bi≈øhop of London, about this time was made Lord Trea≈øurer in the place of the L. We≈øton Earl of Portland, decea≈øed: And now great differences aro≈øe about Church matters, chiefly occa≈øioned by Arch Bi≈øhop Lauds ≈øtrict and zealous Enjoyning of Ceremonies, as placing the Communion Table at the Ea≈øt end of the Church, upon an A≈øcent with Rails, Altar fa≈øhion; with
many other things not formerly ≈øtrictly in≈øi≈øted on, and now vehemently oppo≈øed by tho≈øe who were u≈øually called Puritans and Non-conformists, which cau≈øed them to be charged with Faction; yet ≈øome of the Epi≈øcopal Party A≈ø≈øerted, That the Communion Table ought to ≈øtand in the middle of the Quire, according to the Primitive Example; and a Book ≈øuppo≈øed to be written by Dr. Williams B. of Lincoln, was Publi≈øhed to this purpo≈øe.

His Maje≈øty con≈øidering the good Succe≈øs of his former Fleet, fits out another in the year 1636, under the command of the Earl of Northumberland, who going Northward, ≈øcowred the Seas of the Holland Bu≈ø≈øes, and reduced them to de≈øire leave of his Maie≈øty to Fi≈øh there, which the King upon divers Con≈øiderations granted them.

Several Gentlemen of Quality had refu≈øed to pay the Impo≈øition of Ship-money and among the re≈øt Mr. Hamden of Buckingham≈øhire, upon which his Maje≈øty refers the whole bu≈øine≈øs to his Twelve Judges in Michaelmas Term 1636; Ten of whom that is, Brampton, Finch, Davenport, Denham, Jones, Trever, Vernon, Berkly, Crawly, We≈øton, gave their Judgments again≈øt Hamden and his A≈ø≈øociates, and ≈øub≈øcribed their Names to be Inrolled in all the Courts ol We≈øtmin≈øter Hall; but Hutton and Crook refu≈øed it: This year March the 17. the Kings Kings Third Daughter, the Prince≈øs Ann was born.

In the Thirteenth year of his Maje≈øties Reign 1637, Dr. Ba≈øtwick, Mr. Pryn, and Mr. Burton received a ≈øevere Cen≈øure for writing again≈øt Bi≈øhops and their Government; they being all three Sentenced to pay Five Thou≈øand Pounds Fine to the King, to lo≈øe their Ears in the Pillory, and to be Impri≈øoned, which they accordingly ≈øuffered.

Bi≈øhop Williams of Lincoln having the great Seal
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
taken from him in the fir≈øt year of his Maje≈øties Reign, he ≈øo deeply re≈øented it, that ever after he ≈øtudied Revenge; and a Bill being preferr'd again≈øt him in the Star Chamber for ≈øome di≈øhonourable Speeches of the King, he endeavoured by ≈øome indirect means to clear his Innocence, and was therefore this year ≈øentenced Ten thou≈øand Pounds Fine to the King, Impri≈øonment in the Tower, during Plea≈øure, to be ≈øu≈øpended ab Officiis, et Beneficiis, from his Bi≈øhoprick, and the Profits thereof, and to be referred to the High Commi≈ø≈øion Court as to what concerned them.

His Maje≈øty de≈øiring an Uniformity in Religion in England and Scotland (a thing before de≈øigned by King James) in pur≈øuance thereof enjoyned the Scots the u≈øe of the Engli≈øh Liturgy, the Surplice, and other Habiliments, and began fir≈øt at his own Chappel; and in this year 1637, Proclamation was made that the ≈øame Order ≈øhould be ob≈øerved in all Churches, wherewith the Bi≈øhops were contented, but not the Kirk, nor the People; who were ≈øo inraged thereat, that when the Dean of Edenbourgh began to Read the Common Prayer in St. Giles Church with his Surplice on July 13. the Council, Bi≈øhops, Lords, and Magi≈øtrates, being pre≈øent: the Women, and then the ordinary ≈øort of men, made ≈øuch a di≈øturbance and noi≈øe with Cur≈øing, Clapping their hands, and ≈øo great Rudene≈øs, that nothing could be heard, but their Clamours; upon which the Bi≈øhop of Edenbourgh, who was to preach that day, ≈øtept up into the Pulpit to reprove them; which increa≈øing their Fury, they a≈ø≈øault him with ≈øuch a ≈øhower of Stones, Seats, Stools, Cudgels, and whatever el≈øe was near; that his life was much indangered thereby, and the Arch-bi≈øhop of St. Andrews Lord Chancellor, interpo≈øing,
was like to have been as rudely handled, had not the Provo≈øt, Bayliffs and others with much trouble turned the≈øe Rioters out of the Church, the Dean then proceeding to read the Service Book, though not without great noi≈øe from the Multitude about the Church. The like di≈øturbance happened in other places, but in the Afternoon the Book was again read without much trouble; after which ≈øome of the Di≈øturbers were ≈øeized and puni≈øhed, but with no great Severity; and the Mini≈øters were promi≈øed Protection and Maintenance in Reading it; ≈øo that all at pre≈øent ≈øeemed calm and quiet, till after Harve≈øt; at which time ≈øuch a confluence of People came to Edenbourgh, as gave ju≈øt cau≈øe to the Council to fear an In≈øurrection; to prevent which they I≈ø≈øued out ≈øeveral Proclamations, That no Church matters ≈øhould be re≈øolved on, but that all per≈øons depart home, unle≈øs they can ≈øhew ≈øome cau≈øe to the Council, upon pain of Rebellion.

Yet this was ≈øo little regarded by the People, that the B. of Galloway going the next day to the Council was pur≈øued and a≈ø≈øaulted by them even to the Council Chamber; and being with difficulty got in, the Hou≈øe was pre≈øently incompa≈ø≈øed, and his Per≈øon peremptorily demanded; upon which tho≈øe within required Aid of the Provo≈øt and Council of Edenbourgh; but their Condition was as bad, being likewi≈øe be≈øet in their Town hou≈øe by the People, who would not let them go out till they had ≈øub≈øcribed, 1. To joyn in Oppo≈øition to the Service Book, and in Petitioning to that purpo≈øe. 2. To restore two or three of their ≈øilenced Ministers. Which being related to the Council, the Lord Traqnair and another, went in Per≈øon to the Town Hou≈øe, where they found the Tumult ≈øomewhat quieted by tho≈øe Conce≈ø≈øions; but in coming back, they were furiou≈øly
a≈ø≈øaulted in the Gra≈øs-≈øtreet, and the L. Traquair was trodden under foot, his Hat, Cloak, and white Wand, was taken away, and him≈øelf halled to the Council Hou≈øe: The Lords whereof weighing their own danger, ≈øent ≈øecretly to ≈øome of tho≈øe Noblemen and Gentlemen who di≈øliked the Service Book, and were then a≈ø≈øembled in the common cau≈øe again≈øt it; by whom they were ≈øafely guarded through the multitude, to their ≈øeveral Hou≈øes.

And now judging them≈øelves ≈øecure, they make Proclamation for breaking up all Conventions and keeping the Peace, which had the contrary effect. Two Petitions being pre≈øented to them. One from the Common ≈øort of Men, Women and Children, the other in the Name of the Noblemen, Gentlemen and Mini≈øtry again≈øt the Service Book and Canons: the≈øe Petitions were ≈øent to the King, who being offended therewith, adjourned the Term to Sterling, and by Proclamation forbid upon extreame≈øt Penalty, ≈øuch Tumultuous Meetings: Again≈øt which Proclamation the Earl of Hume, the Lord Lind≈øey, and divers others, made Prote≈øtation; and in pur≈øuance thereof they ≈øet up Four Tables or Committees, 1. Of the Nobility. 2. Of the Gentry. 3. Of the Barons. 4. of the Mini≈øtry; to prepare Matters for the General Council, con≈øi≈øting of ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øioners taken out of the other.

The next year 1638, the Scots entred inta a Solemn League and Covenant to pre≈øerve the Religion there prote≈øt, re≈øolving to maintain it; and to that purpo≈øe, they ≈øent for General Le≈øly and other Officers from beyond Sea, providing them≈øelves likewi≈øe with Arms and Ammunition; whil≈øt D. Hamilton, who was appointed to allay the≈øe heats and Di≈øtempers, ≈øeemed ≈øecretly to foment them, by ≈øpending a great deal of time in Declarations,
Proclamations, Me≈ø≈øages and Letters; and afterwards makes ≈øuch Propo≈øitions to the Confederates about calling a General A≈ø≈øembly, as were very di≈øta≈øteful to the Covenanters and increa≈øed their Fury: Whereupon Hamilton obtained of the King the Sole and Unlimited Power of Managing that Affair, and then acquainted them with a Declaration which he had procured of the King; That he did di≈øcharge the Service Book, Book of Canons, and high Commi≈ø≈øion and likewi≈øe did annul and re≈øcind all Acts for e≈øtabli≈øhing them, and did di≈øcharge the urging the Practice of the Five Articles of Perth: and that all Per≈øons whom≈øoever ≈øhall be liable to the Cen≈øure of Parliament, General A≈ø≈øembly, or any other Judicatories; according to the Nature of the Offence, That the Ancient Confel≈øion of Faith and Band annexed, ≈øhall be ≈øub≈øcribed and received as in K. James time. That a General A≈ø≈øembly be holden at Glafcow, Nov. 21. 1638, and a Parliament at Edenbourgh May, 15. 1639, All former Offences to be pardoned, and a General Fa≈øt appointed.

This Declaration being publi≈øhed, the Marque≈øs and Council ≈øub≈øcribed the Covenanters Confe≈ø≈øion of Faith, &c. yet ≈øtill ≈øome matter remained for a Prote≈øtation, which was read by one John≈øon; wherein the People were exhorted to con≈øider with whom they had to deal: and exceptions were made again≈øt Bi≈øhops, and their Voting in the A≈ø≈øembly: After this they Elect Commi≈ø≈øioners for the A≈ø≈øembly, whom they moved to cite the Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops to appear there, as Guilty Per≈øons; which being refu≈øed, they them≈øelves pre≈øent a Bill of Complaint again≈øt them to the Presbytery at Edenbourgh, who accordingly warned them to appear at the next General A≈ø≈øembly: At their Meeting the Bi≈øhops ≈øent in a Prote≈øtation again≈øt
their A≈ø≈øembly, which the Covenanters would not vouch≈øafe to read, but pre≈øumed to forbid Six Lords of the Privy Council to fit in their A≈ø≈øembly, though nominated by the King. His Maje≈øty having notice of their proceedings, as to the Bi≈øhops, and other matters, ordered their A≈ø≈øembly to be di≈ø≈øolved, which was done accordingly Nov. 21. 1638; and the Covenanters immediately according to their u≈øual method, I≈ø≈øued out a Prote≈øtation again≈øt it, and likewi≈øe declared 6 former Meetings (which were oppo≈øite to their ways) to be void and of none Effect; and ≈øoon after they aboli≈øhed Epi≈øcopacy, and then prepared for a War, as being ≈øen≈øible that the King would maintain the Rights of the Bi≈øhops, and would likewi≈øe ≈øtrictly call them to Account for their late Tran≈øactions.

About this time a Letter was ≈øent by the Scots to the King of France, to implore his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, Signed by ≈øeveral of the Nobility. The King of England prepares an Army for Scotland, with which in the year 1639 he marcheth in Per≈øon into the North; but while he ≈øtayed at York ≈øome of the Scots Nobility tampered with the Eagli≈øh, telling them that the ruin of the Scots would enable the King to be more ≈øevere toward his Engli≈øh Subjects; by which Intelligence and Corre≈øpondence it was evident that the Engli≈øh had no mind to Fight, though their Army was much ≈øtronger than the Scots; whereupon by the Mediation of ≈øome Per≈øons a Treaty of Peace was begun, and ≈øoon fini≈øhed; wherein it was agreed, That His Maje≈øty ≈øhould publi≈øh a Declaration, whereby all ≈øhould be confirmed which his Commi≈ø≈øioners had promi≈øed in his Name, That a General A≈ø≈øembly and a Parliament be held at Edenbourgh in a ≈øhort time. And la≈øtly, That upon disbanding their Forces,
di≈ø≈øolving their Councils, and re≈øtoring the King to his Forts and Ca≈øtles, &c. the King was to recall his Fleet and Forces, and make re≈øtitution of their Goods ≈øince the Breach.

The Kings Declaration was no ≈øooner publi≈øhed, but the Covenanters ≈øet forth another Prote≈øtation, for adhereing to there A≈ø≈øembly at Gla≈øco, and their Covenant; whereupon the King, who intended to be pre≈øent at their General A≈ø≈øembly, not finding the Scots punctual in performing Articles, and perceiving they would treat of ≈øome matters di≈øta≈øteful to him, goes into England; after which the A≈ø≈øembly ≈øate at Edenbourgh, and aboli≈øhed Epi≈øcopacy, the Liturgy, High Commi≈ø≈øion, and Book of Canons; and then made ≈øeveral demands of the King of a various nature.

His Maje≈øty under≈øtanding how things went, and that the Scots levyed Taxes and prepared Arms, he commanded by his Commi≈ø≈øioner, the Earl of Traquair, that their Parliament ≈øhould be Adjourned for ≈øome time; but the Covenanters declared again≈øt this Command, and ≈øent a Remon≈øtrance to the King; and afterward Hamilton and Traquair, likewi≈øe came to London, where there were ≈øuch proceedings, as did the more exa≈øperate the jarring parties again≈øt each other.

In this year 1639, a Spani≈øh Fleet of near Seventy Sail, and Twenty five thou≈øand Men, de≈øigned to be landed at Dunkirk for the relief of Flanders, were ≈øet upon by the Dutch in the Downs, and Eleven of them taken and ≈øent into Holland; three peri≈øhed upon the Coa≈øt of France, one near Dover, and five were ≈øunk in the Fight. What the real intent of this Fleet was, is yet uncertain; for it ≈øeemed unlikely that Twenty five thou≈øand Men ≈øhould be ≈øent only for a Recruit, and the Admirals
refu≈øing to ≈øhew his Commi≈ø≈øion when required thereto by the King, makes it ≈øeem yet mon ≈øu≈øpicious.

The Scots Commi≈ø≈øioners having delivered their Me≈ø≈øage, return home to Edenbourgh, Nov. 19. 1639. the ≈øame night that a great part of the Ca≈øtle Walls fell down, and the Anniver≈øary of the King Birth day. A while after the King ≈øent the Lord E≈øtrich, and others, to tepair the Walls, who were re≈øi≈øted by the Covenanters; as not judging the Lord E≈øtrich to be a fit Governour for the Ca≈øtle; which Office was de≈øigned him by the King. The King being hereat extreamly offended, re≈øolved, ≈øince fair means would not prevail, to force the Scots to rea≈øon, and to that end con≈øiders how to make provi≈øions for Men and Money; and calling a ≈øecret Cabinet Council, con≈øi≈øting only of Archbi≈øhop Laud, the Earl of Strafford, and Duke Hamilton (who drove on his own particular intere≈øt) it was concluded. That for the Kings ≈øupply a Parliament mu≈øt be called in England, and another in Ireland; but becau≈øe the Debates of Parliament would take up ≈øome time, it was re≈øolved, that the Lords ≈øhould ≈øub≈øcribe to lend the King money. The Earl of Strafford ≈øub≈øcribed Twenty thou≈øand pound, the Duke of Richmond as much; but Hamilton pretended poverty. pre≈øerving his money for other u≈øes; the re≈øt of the Lords, Judges, Officers, and other Dependants, and many of the Gentry, yea, even ≈øeveral Popi≈øh Recu≈øants, contributed according to their ability.

The Scots on the other ≈øide fore-≈øeeing the ≈øtorm, prepared for their own Defence, making Treaties in Denmark, Sweden, Holland and Poland; and the Je≈øuits, who are never idle, did likewi≈øe endeavour to foment the differences; to which
end Con the Popes Nuncio, Sir Toby Matthews, Read and Maxwell, two Scots, endeavoured to per≈øwade the di≈øcontented People, That the King de≈øigned to iu≈ølave them to his will and plea≈øure. Which practices of theirs were di≈øcovered by Andreas Habern≈øfield, a Nobleman of Bohemia, who declared, That many of the Nobility of England, and chief Favourites at Court, were con≈øenting to the≈øe Tran≈øactions, and particularly the Earl and Counte≈øs of Arundel, Secretary Windebank, and Endymion Porter. Con al≈øo performed the part of a Firebrand, as all his Succe≈ø≈øors, the Popes Nuncio's that came after him, did likewi≈øe; and had formerly offered a Cardinals Cap to the Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, in the Popes Name.

In the year 1640, and the Sixteenth of the King, a Parliament was called at We≈øtminster, April 13. in which the Earl of Strafford was highly honoured for his good ≈øervice in Ireland, in obtaining four Sub≈øidies, to maintain Ten thou≈øand Foot, and Fifteen hundred Hor≈øe. And that England might follow this Example, the King tells the Parliament, that if they would ≈øupply him, ≈øo as to ≈øuppre≈øs the In≈øolencies of the Scots, he would acquit his claim to Shipmoney, and giue ≈øatisfaction to their ju≈øt Demands. By which Propo≈øals the Parliament were ≈øen≈øible of the Kings Nece≈ø≈øities, and therefore required ≈øatisfaction, 1. For clearing the Property of the Subject. 2. For e≈øtabli≈øhing the True Religion. 3. For Priviledges of Parliament.

But whil≈øt they were debating whether the Grievances of the People or the Kings Supply ≈øhould be fir≈øt con≈øidered, and Matters were in an hopeful po≈øture, Secretary Vane, either accidentally, or on purpo≈øe, overthrew all at once, by declaring
that the King required Twelve Sub≈øidies whereas he at that time only de≈øired Six; which ≈øo much inraged the Hou≈øe, and made things ≈øo ill that by the Advice of the Junto the Parliament was di≈ø≈øolved, having only ≈øate Twenty two days; however the Privy Councel likewi≈øe advi≈øed their Di≈ø≈øolving, being a≈ø≈øured the heats in the Hou≈øe of Commons were ≈øo great, that they intended that very day to have voted again≈øt the War with Scotland; whereby the King would have been in a wor≈øe condition than before their ≈øitting.

About the ≈øame time a Convocation of Bi≈øhops ≈øate, with Commi≈ø≈øion to make ≈øuch Canons as they judged for the peace of the Church; and among≈øt other things, they impo≈øed an Oath called, &c. (Et cetera) as an Anticovenant again≈øt the Scots; which becau≈øe it occa≈øioned much difference, may not be unfitly in≈øerted.

I A. B. Do ≈øwear that I do approve the Doctrine and Di≈øcipline or Government e≈øtabli≈øhed in the Church of England, as containing all things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation; and that I will not endeavour, by my ≈øelf, or any other, directly or indirectly, to bring in any Popi≈øh Doctrine, contrary to that ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed; nor will I ever give my con≈øent to alter the Government of this Church by Archbi≈øhops, Deans, and Arch Deacons ‚Äî &c. (Et cetera, and ≈øo forth) as it ≈øtands now e≈øtabli≈øhed, and as by right it ought to ≈øtand, nor yet ever to ≈øubject it to the U≈øurpations and Superstitions of the See of Rome: And all the≈øe things do I plainly and ≈øincerely acknowledge and ≈øwear, according to the plain and common ≈øen≈øe or under≈øtanding of the ≈øame words, without any Equivocation mental Eva≈øion, or ≈øecret Re≈øervation what≈øoever. And this I do heartily, willingly and truly, upon the faith of a Chri≈øtian. So help me God in Je≈øus Chri≈øt. This
Oath was impo≈øed upon all Mini≈øters, and gave great Offence. This was the chief bu≈øine≈øs of this Convocation, which ended May 26, 1640.

Arch Bi≈øhop Laud by his earne≈øt proceedings again≈øt Nonconformi≈øts and ≈øuch as were called Puritans, and by his ≈øtrict enjoyning of Ceremonies, e≈øpecially reviving old Ceremonies, which had not been lately ob≈øerved, procured much hatred to him≈øelf from the People, particularly the Londiners, who had a particular di≈øgu≈øt again≈øt him, for his ≈øeverity upon Mr. Burton, Pryn, and Ba≈øtwick; in≈øomuch, that upon May 9, 1640, a Paper was fixed upon the Royal Exchange, inciting the Apprentices to ri≈øe and ≈øack his Hou≈øe at Lambeth the Monday after; which they were the more inclined to do, becau≈øe it was reported that he was the chief in≈øtigator of the King to di≈ø≈øolve the la≈øt Parliament; but the Arch Bi≈øhop had notice of their De≈øign, and provided accordingly; however, upon Monday at midnight about Five Hundred of them be≈øet his Hou≈øe, and endeovoured to enter, but were repul≈øed, and forced to depart; having in ≈øome mea≈øure vented their Spleen in words, and breaking his Gla≈øs-Windows. The next day many of them were apprehended and impri≈øoned, but three days after they were forcibly re≈øcued from thence by their Companions, who broke open the Pri≈øon doors; for which one of the Ring-leaders was drawn, hanged and quartered, and his head and quarters ≈øet upon London-Bridge.

Le≈øly comes on with his Hor≈øe, and charges Commi≈ø≈øary General Wilmot, who maintained the ground very ≈øtoutly till overborn with multitude and Canon, they were put to a di≈øorderly Retreat, both Hor≈øe and Foot; upon which the L. Conway ha≈øtes to the King with the unwelcome News; Sir Jacob, Astly.
Governor of Newcastle finding him≈øelf unable to de
‚Ä¢ end the place, de≈øerts it, ≈øinking the great Guns ‚Ä¢ n the River, whereby Newca≈øtle and Durham, came ‚Ä¢ n a ≈øhort time into the hands of the Scots. And now Strafford comes up, with whom the King retreats ‚Ä¢ o York and ≈øtays there; while Strafford, who was ‚Ä¢ ow ≈øole Commander, charges the whole mi≈øcar
‚Ä¢ iage upon Conway, who as ≈øtoutly denies it.

The King had formerly declared the Scots to be Rebels and Traytors by Proclamation, and commanded that publick Prayers ≈øhould be put up again≈øt them in all Churches, but at this time he is contented to treat with them; and to that end he receives a Petition from them complaining of their Grievances: To which he an≈øwers by his Secretary of Scotland, that he expects their particular demands, which he receives in three days, all tending to require a Parliament to be called in England, without which there could be no ≈øatisfactory redre≈øs for them; they had likewi≈øe before their March into England publi≈øhed a Declaration, called, The Intentions of the Army, viz. Not to lay down Arms, till the Reformed Religion were ≈øetled in both Nations upon ≈øure grounds, and the Cau≈øes and Abbettors of their pre≈øent Troubles, that is Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud and the Earl of Strafford, were brought to publick Ju≈øtice in Parliament. At the ≈øame time Twelve Engli≈øh Peers, that is, the Earls of Bedford, Hartford, E≈ø≈øex, Warwick, Mulgrave, Bristol, Bullingbrook, Say and Seal, Mandevil, Howard, Brook and Paget drew up a Petition which they delivered to the King, for the ≈øitting of the Parliament: After which divers others were pre≈øented to the ≈øame purpo≈øe from the City of London, and ≈øeveral other parts of the Kingdom; all centring in this, that nothing could relieve the Pre≈ø≈øures of the Kingdom but a Parliament.

To this the King conde≈øcends in part, giving hope likewi≈øe of further ≈øatisfaction ere long; and „Äà‚óä„Äâ the pre≈øent Summons the Lords to appear at Yor ‚Ä¢ Sep. 24. which they did, and upon the fir≈øt day o ‚Ä¢ their meeting it was agreed, That a Parliame ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhould be called to meet November 3 following, an ‚Ä¢ then (for the relief of the North ≈øorely ≈øuffering under Le≈ølies Army, the Bi≈øhoprick of Durham bein ‚Ä¢ then taxed 360 l. and Northumberland 300 l. a day, it was re≈øolved, that a Treaty ≈øhould be ≈øet on Foo ‚Ä¢ and that Sixteen Engli≈øh Lords, ≈øhould meet with as many Scots, and York was propo≈øed for the plac ‚Ä¢ of Treaty, which the Scotch Commi≈ø≈øioners refu≈øed as not judging it ≈øafe by rea≈øon of the pre≈øence o ‚Ä¢ the Earl of Strafford, who hath proclaimed them Traytors in Ireland, and was now chief Commander of the Kings Army, and a Capital Enemy to their Nation, and again≈øt whom they had matter of high Complaint; therefore it was concluded to be held at Rippon, where among other things it was agreed that the Scotch Army ≈øhould be maintained by the Engli≈øh, till the Treaty was ended, and peace ≈øecured; that there ≈øhould be a ≈øafe Convoy for all Letters between the Scots and the Parliament of England. The fir≈øt of the≈øe Articles ≈øeemed unrea≈øonable and di≈øhonourable to the Engli≈øh Nation‚ñ™ and the Earl of Strafford was ≈øo offended thereat, that he de≈øired leave of the King to give them Battel, and was willing (as he writ to Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud to undertake upon the Peril of his Head with his Army of Engli≈øh Gra≈øhoppers to beat tho≈øe Sons of Anak home again, for ≈øo much Superlour were the Scots then accounted to the Engli≈øh as to matter of Souldiers; but October 16. the Engli≈øh Commanders, whether through Fear, Favour, or out of a Political Maxim not to fight again≈øt the Scots, conde≈øcended to Articles
of Agreement, which were afterward ≈øigned by the King him≈øelf:

This Treaty of Rippon was but previous to another of higher Importance at London for a general concluding and making up all differences between the King and his Subjects of Scotland; during which Treaty James Earl of Montro≈øs made ≈øeveral Applications to the King, and by Letters offered his ≈øervice to him, te≈øtifying his dis≈ølike of the Scot
‚Ä¢ i≈øh Proceedings; but the≈øe his Letters were ≈øaid to have been ≈øecretly taken out of the Kings Pockets, and conveyed to the Covenanters by the means of Hamilton; who under≈øtanding Montro≈øs his de≈øign, u≈øed all means to render him odious to the People, and ≈øo un≈øerviceable to the King.

And now the time approached for the ≈øitting of the Parliament, who accordingly met November 3. 1640, which was looked upon by Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud as a fatal day for Summoning of Parliaments, in reference to Church matters; the Parliament in King Henry the Eighths time, which pulled down Abbies and Mona≈øteries, being likewi≈øe A≈ø≈øembled upon November 3. Whereupon he advi≈øed the King for lucks ≈øake to put off their meeting for 2, or 3 dayes, but the King not minding any ≈øuch Ob≈øervations, did not regard it.

To give ≈øome Account of the temper of tho≈øe times it may not be ami≈øs to repeat the words of a Per≈øon of Honour, who was then a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, and hath lately publi≈øhed ≈øome Pa≈ø≈øages concerning that Parliament.

p.q:
Never Parliament (≈øaith he) was a≈ø≈øembled when the People were in an higher di≈øcontent then at this time, ≈øuch a general Diffidence there was, as they thought them≈øelves ≈øure of nothing; the increa≈øe of Ceremonies made them fear the approach
of a Religion hateful to them; the la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bu≈øine≈øs of Ship-money, together with ≈øome Imp ‚Ä¢
≈øitions, without the con≈øent of Parliament, cau≈øe ‚Ä¢ them to apprehend the lo≈øs of Property in the E≈øtates, and they had little hope of Redre≈øs „Äà‚óä„Äâ Parliaments, becau≈øe his then Maje≈øty had bee ‚Ä¢ ≈øo unhappy as to be put upon a ≈øudden Di≈ø≈øolutio ‚Ä¢ of all Parliaments formerly by him called: The ‚Ä¢ wanted not Per≈øons ill di≈øpo≈øed, and ≈øeditious „Äà‚óä„Äâ trumpet the≈øe things in the ears of the generalty, whereby they incen≈øed them ≈øo far, as there ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ they found means to rai≈øe a Power again≈øt the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Soveraign.

div.p:
Mr. William Lenthal was Cho≈øen Speaker of th ‚Ä¢ Hou≈øe of Commons, and the King in a Speech t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them that the Scotti≈øh Troubles were the Cau≈øe o ‚Ä¢ their pre≈øent Meeting, and therefore requires the ‚Ä¢ to con≈øider of the mo≈øt expedient means for ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ing them out, and then promi≈øes that he will hea ‚Ä¢
tily and clearly concurr with them for the ≈øatisfying their ju≈øt Grievances: After which, he ga ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them an Account of his want of Money for th ‚Ä¢ Maintaining of his Army, and how di≈øhonourabl ‚Ä¢ it would be to the Engli≈øh Nation, if his Arm ‚Ä¢ ≈øhould be disbanded before the Scots were put ou ‚Ä¢ of the Kingdom; and de≈øired them to con≈øider o ‚Ä¢ the Oppre≈ø≈øion of the Northern Countreys during th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Treaty.

It was ill re≈øented by many that the King ≈øhould call the Scots Rebels, whereupon he took occa≈øion to tell them that he mu≈øt needs call them Rebels as long as they have an Army which did invade England. The Commons then Voted down all Monopolies, and all ≈øuch Members as had any benefit by them were expelled out of the Hou≈øe; Complain ‚Ä¢ was made in the Hou≈øe of Lords again≈øt Sir William
Beecher one of the Clerks of the Council, for violating their Priviledges, in ≈øearching the Earl of Warwicks and the Lord Brooks Studies, Cabinets and Pockets, upon the di≈ø≈øolving the la≈øt Parliament; upon which he was committed Pri≈øoner to the Fleet, though he pleaded the Command of the Secretary of State for his ≈øo doing. The Earl of Strafford is Impeached of High Trea≈øon by the Commons in the Hou≈øe of Lords, whereupon he is ≈øeque≈øtred from the Hou≈øe and likewi≈øe his Friend Sir. George Ratcliff is ≈øent for out of Ireland by a Serjeant at Arms: In the mean time the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, who was Pri≈øoner in the Tower is relea≈øed; and likewi≈øe Mr. Pryn and Mr. Burton, who are brought in great Triumph to London; and December 3. they pre≈øented their Petition again≈øt their Pro≈øecutors.

And now the Papi≈øts began to fear a Cloud, for Ju≈øtice Howard was to deliver up a Catalogue of all Recu≈øants within the Liberties of We≈øtmin≈øter, to prevent which he was ≈øtabbed by one Mr. John James in Westminster hall; for which he was impri≈øoned in the Gate-hou≈øe in order to a more ≈øevere puni≈øhment: But Sir Francis Windebank Secretary of State, fearing to be called to Account by the Parliament for reprieving Je≈øuits and Prie≈øts, which he knew would be produced again≈øt him, if not wor≈øe matters; fled privately into France. December 7th the Commons Voted Ship-money, with the Opinion of the Judges thereupon, to be Illegal; and a Charge of High Trea≈øon was ordered to be drawn up again≈øt eight of them; and they re≈øolved to begin with the Lord Keeper Finch. December 11th Alderman Pennington and ≈øome hundreds of Citizens pre≈øented a Petition, ≈øub≈øcribed by 15000 Hands, again≈øt Church Di≈øcipline and Ceremonies,
and a while after the Hou≈øe of Commons Voted, That the Clergy in a Synod or Convocation have no power to make Canons or Laws without Parliaments; and that the Canons are again≈øt the Fundamental Laws of this Realm, the Kings Prerogative, the Property of the Subject, the Right of Parliaments and tend to Faction and Sedition.

In pur≈øuance hereof a Charge was ordered to be drawn up again≈øt Arch-bi≈øhop Laud as the principal framer of tho≈øe Canons, and other Delinquencies; which Impeachment was ≈øeconded with another from the Scotch Commi≈ø≈øioners; upon which he was committed to the Black Rod, and 10 weeks after Voted Guilty of High Trea≈øon and ≈øent to the Tower, The Scots likewi≈øe prefer a charge again≈øt the Earl of Strafford then in Cu≈øtody, requiring Ju≈øtice again≈øt them both, as the great Incendiaries, and Di≈øturbers of Church and State, and Sir George Ratcliff the Earls Bo≈øom Friend, had Articles al≈øo drawn again≈øt him to this purpo≈øe.

That he had con≈øpired with the Earl to bring Ireland under an Arbitrary Government, and to ≈øubvert the Fundamental Laws, and to bring an Army from Ireland to ≈øubdue the Subjects of England. That he per≈øwaded the Earl to u≈øe Regal Power and to deprive the Subjects of their Liberties and Properties. That he countenanced Papi≈øts, and built Mona≈øteries, to alienate the Affections of the Iri≈øh from England. That he withdrew the Subjects of Scotland from their King. And la≈øtly, That to pre≈øerve him≈øelf and the Earl of Strafford, he laboured to ≈øubvert the Liberties and Priviledges of Parliament in Ireland.

The Lord Keeper Finch was the next Per≈øon de≈øigned to be cen≈øured. and notwith≈øtanding a Speech made in his own Vindication, he was Voted a Traytor upon ≈øeveral Accounts; and among
the re≈øt, for ≈øoliciting, per≈øwading, and threatning the Judges to deliver their Opinions for rai≈øing Shipmoney, and for ≈øeveral ill Offices done in moving the King to Di≈ø≈øolve the la≈øt Parliament, and cau≈øing the publi≈øhing the Kings Declaration thereupon. Next day he was accu≈øed before the Lords, but he fore≈øaw the Storm, and went over into Holland.

The Parliament having now removed their Enemies, and increa≈øing in Reputation, were de≈øigning a Bill for a Triennial Parliament; for promoting which, Petitions came from divers places, one whereof was ≈øub≈øcribed with 800 Hands directly again≈øt Epi≈øcopacy, which the King took notice of; and calling both Hou≈øes together, tells them, Of their ≈ølowne≈øs and the charge of Two Armies in the Kingdom, and that he would have them avoid two Rocks, the one about the Hierachy of Bi≈øhops, which he was willing to Reform but not to alter; The other concerning frequent Parliaments, which he liked well, but not to give his Power to Sheriffs and Con≈øtables.

About this time one Goodman a Popi≈øh Prie≈øt, condemned at the Se≈ø≈øions in London, was reprieved by the King; upon which both Hou≈øes petitioned to know who were the In≈øtruments of it; and receiving an un≈øatisfactory An≈øwer, they Remon≈øtrated again≈øt the Toleration of Papi≈øts, and the Popes Nuncio Ro≈øetti, and this Goodman, whom they de≈øired might be left to the Ju≈øtice of the Law, To this the King an≈øwers, That the increa≈øe of Popery and Papi≈øts in his Dominions, is extreamly again≈øt his mind, and that he would u≈øe all po≈ø≈øible means for the re≈øtraining of it: As for the Popes Nuncio Ro≈øetti, he had no Commi≈ø≈øion, but only to pre≈øerve Corre≈øpondence between the Queen and the Pope, which was allowed her by the Articles of Marriage, however
he had prevailed with her to remove him and is contented to remit the particular Ca≈øe of Goodman to both Hou≈øes.

The Scots had been now quartered in England five months, during which a Ce≈ø≈øation had been concluded at Rippon, but the full Pacification was re≈øerved for London, where Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øate on both Parties to hear the Demands of the Scots, and to make an≈øwer thereunto. After which the Scots pre≈øented the great Account of their Charges, which was Five hundred fourteen thou≈øand, one hundred twenty eight pounds nine Shillings, be≈øides the lo≈øs of their Nation, which was Four hundred and forty thou≈øand pounds. This Reckoning ≈øtartled the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners, till the Scots told them, They did not give in that Account as expecting a Total Reparation of their Charges and Lo≈ø≈øes, but were content to bear a part of it; hoping for the rest, from the Ju≈øtice and Kindne≈øs of England, There was ≈øome oppo≈øition made to the Demands, however Moneys were rai≈øed for the pre≈øent from the City of London, for the Supply of both the Northern Armies, as the Parliament had done once before.

At this time a Match was propounded between the young Prince of Orange and the Lady Mary, Elde≈øt Daughter to the King, which his Maje≈øty liked well of, and communicated it to the Parliament; with whom it found an unanimous and general Reception, in regard of the Alliance to be thereupon concluded with the States General; and likewi≈øe that he was of the ≈øame Prote≈øtant Religion with England, ≈øo that the Marriage was ≈øoon concluded.

Pre≈øently after four Members of the Commons delivered a Me≈ø≈øage to the Lords of a Popi≈øh De≈øign
of Levying an Army of Fifteen thou≈øand in Lanca≈øhire, and Eight thou≈øand in Ireland, and that the main promoters thereof were the Earls of Strafford and Worce≈øter.

In February Sir Robert Berkly, one of the Judges about Ship-money, was accu≈øed of High Trea≈øon, and committed Pri≈øoner to the Black Rod. In this Month the King pa≈ø≈øed that Act for a Triennial Parliament, and to let them know what value he put upon this great favour his Maje≈øty told the Two Hou≈øes, That hitherto they had gone on in tho≈øe things which concerned them≈øelves, and now he expected they ≈øhould proceed upon what concerned him.

The King then likewi≈øe ≈øigned the Bill of Sub≈øidies, which gave them ≈øuch univer≈øal content, that Sir Edward Littleton Lord Keeper, was ordered To return the Humble Thanks of Both Hou≈øes to his Maje≈øty at Whitehall. Upon which there were Bonefires and Bells ringing in and about London, in the ≈øame manner as formerly upon granting the Petition of Right.

March 1, 1640, Archbi≈øhop Laud upon an Accu≈øation of High Trea≈øon by the Commons, was committed to the Tower: And now Epi≈øcopacy it ≈øelf was called in que≈øtion, and though the Lord Digby made a witty and weighty Speech in Defence of it, and Archbi≈øhop U≈øher gave his Judgment for the Moderation and Emendation of it and the Liturgy, not the Extirpation thereof; yet the Wings of Epi≈øcopacy were ≈øhrewdly clipt, for March 10 the Commons Voted, That no Bi≈øhop ≈øhould have any Vote in Parliament, nor any Judicial power in the Star Chamber, nor be concerned in any Temporal matters; and that no Clergy-man ≈øhould be a Ju≈øtice of Peace.

Upon Monday March 26, 1640. the Earl of Straffords Tryal began in Westmin≈øter-hall, the King, Queen, and Prince being pre≈øent; and the Commons likewi≈øe being there as a Committee at the managing their Accu≈øation; the Earl of Arundel was Lord High Steward, and the Earl of Lind≈øey Lord High Con≈øtable, the Earl of Strafford though he had but ≈øhort warning, yet had gotten his Defence ready again≈øt the time. The Accu≈øation was managed by Mr. Pym, con≈øi≈øting of Twenty eight Articles, to mo≈øt of which the Earl made Particular Replies.

But the Commons were re≈øolved to pro≈øecute him to the utmo≈øt, and had therefore procured the Parliament of Ireland to pro≈øecute him there al≈øo, as guilty of High Trea≈øon; which being unexpectedly produced, extorted from the Earl this pa≈ø≈øionate Expre≈ø≈øion, That there was a Con≈øpiracy again≈øt him, to take away his Life. At which the Commons cryed out again≈øt him, That standing Impeached of High Trea≈øon, he dur≈øt accu≈øe the Parliament of two Kingdoms of Con≈øpiracy again≈øt him. But be≈øides all the≈øe, certain notes were produced again≈øt him, which were taken by Sir H. Vane in a clo≈øe Committee of ≈øelect Coun≈øellors, whom the King had cho≈øen to con≈øult about his ≈øecond Expedition again≈øt the Scots; out of which it was alledged again≈øt the Earl, That he had given the King advice to borrow an Hundred thou≈øand pound of the City of London, To levy Ship-money rigorou≈øly; and that his Maje≈øty having tryed the Affections of his People, was ab≈øolved and loo≈øed from all Rules of Government, and might do what power would admit; and having an Army in Ireland, might imploy it for the reducing of this Kingdom, which he was ≈øure could not hold out five months: And London being full of the Nobility, the Commi≈ø≈øion
of Array was to be ≈øet on foot, and all Oppo≈øers thereof to be ≈øeverely dealt with.

To this the Earl replyed, That he conceived it lawful for a Privy Coun≈øellor to have freedom of Voting with others; and as to the matter of the Engli≈øh Army, he thought that the ≈øingle Te≈øtimony of one man (Secretary Vane) was not of Validity in Law, much le≈øs in Life and Death, and that the Depo≈øitions of Secretary Vane was doubtful, as appeared by ≈øeveral Examinations, and that there were pre≈øent at the Debate but eight Privy Coun≈øellors, whereof two were not to be produced, and four others declared upon their Honours that they never heard him ≈øpeak tho≈øe words, or any like them; and la≈øtly that if he had ≈øpoken them (which he yet granted not) that the word This Kingdom, could not imply England, the debate being concerning Scotland, there being not the lea≈øt intention of Landing the Iri≈øh Army in England; and concluded his Defence with telling the Lords, that he was accu≈øed as guilty of Trea≈øon for endeavouring to ≈øubvert the Fundamental Laws of the Land, but it ≈øeemed ≈øtrange to him that it ≈øhould be Trea≈øon together which was not Trea≈øon in any part; and la≈øtly, de≈øired the Lords to con≈øider how their own Priviledges, and other Mini≈øters of State, would ≈øuffer by his Condemnation.

The Commons mu≈øt now ju≈øtifie their Charge by Law, to which end they produced the Salvo annexed to the Stat. of 25 Ed. 3. The words were the≈øe, Becau≈øe all particular Trea≈øons could not be then defined; therefore what the Parliament ≈øhould declare to be Trea≈øon, in time to come ≈øhould be puni≈øhed as Trea≈øon; And ≈øo this Salvo was to be the Ground work of the Bill of Attainder. This being a point of Law, the Earl had Council allowed him, who an≈øwered
on his behalf, That the Statute which they cited was but a Declarative and a Penal Law, awd would no way admit of ≈øuch Con≈øequential and Inferential Constructions, and that this Salvo was repealed by an Act of Parliament in the Sixth of Henry the fourth. And ≈øo the Court Adjourned without prefixing any time of Meeting; for the Commons proceeded to di≈øpatch their Bill of Attainder, and April 19, 1641, they Voted the Earl Guilty of High Trea≈øon, upon the Evidence of Secretary Vane and his Notes; And upon the 25th. they pa≈ø≈øed the Bill and ≈øent to the Lords for their Concurrence, to whom it ≈øeemed at fir≈øt ≈øo perplext a bu≈øine≈øs, that the Commons were forced to ≈øend Mr. Saint John the Kings Sollicitor, to confer with them about it, who gave them ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction, that thence forward they ≈øhewed greater propen≈øity to the Earls Condemnation.

In the mean time the Commons petitioned the King, 1. To remove all Papists from Court. 2. For di≈øarming of them generally throughout the Kingdom. 3. For disbanding the Iri≈øh Army. To which the King an≈øwered, 1. They all knew what Legal Tru≈øt the Crown hath in that particular, therefore he ≈øhall not need to ≈øay any thing to a≈ø≈øure them that he ≈øhall u≈øe it ≈øo, as there ≈øhall be no ju≈øt cau≈øe of ≈øcandal. 2. As for the ≈øecond he is content it ≈øhall be done by Law. And for the last, he had entred into Con≈øultation about it, finding many difficulties therein, and doth ≈øo wi≈øh the disbanding of all Armies, as he did conjure them ≈øpeedily and heartily to joyn with him in disbanding tho≈øe two here, Scots and Engli≈øh.

The Hou≈øe of Commons having fini≈øhed their Bill of Attainder again≈øt the Earl of Strafford, and the King fearing the Conclu≈øion, and being willing to do ≈øome good Office to him, His Maje≈øty May
1, 1641, calls both Hou≈øes together, and in a Speech tells them, That he had been pre≈øent at the hearing of that great Cau≈øe, and that in his Con≈øcience, po≈øitively he could not condemn him of High Trea≈øon, and yet could not clear him of mi≈ødemeanours; but hoped a way might be found out to ≈øatisfie Justice and their fears without oppre≈ø≈øing his Con≈øcience. And ≈øo he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them to their great di≈øcontent, which was propagated ≈øo far, that May 3. near a Thou≈øand Citizens, mo≈øt of them armed with Swords, Cudgels, and Staves, came thronging down to Westmin≈øter, crying out for Justice again≈øt the Earl of Strafford; e≈øpecially applying them≈øelves to the Earl of Montgomery, Lord Chamberlain by who≈øe per≈øwa≈øions, and promi≈øes their fury was partly abated: However they po≈øted upon the Gate at Westminster a Li≈øt of the Names of tho≈øe who would have acquitted the Earl, whom they ≈øtiled Staffordians.

The Parliament being Informed that ≈øome endeavours were u≈øed, to rai≈øe a Di≈øgu≈øt in the Engli≈øh Northern Army again≈øt their Proceedings, they now enter into a National Prote≈øtation to maintain with Life, Power, and E≈øtate the True Reformed Prote≈øtant Religion, expre≈ø≈øed in the Doctrine of the Church of England, again≈øt all Popery and Popi≈øh Innovations: Which was ordered to be printed and publi≈øhed through the Kingdom.

May 5. The Lords acquainted the Commons, That they thought it the ≈øafest cour≈øe to lay by the Bill of Attainder, becau≈øe it brought in the King for Judge: And the next day they debated the ≈øeveral Articles of his Impeachment, and voted the Earl guilty of High Trea≈øon upon Two of them, that is the 15th. For Levying of moneys in Ireland by force in a Warlike manner; And the 16th, For Impo≈øing an Oath upon the Subjects of Ireland.

The Commons had now fini≈øhed a Bill, For the Continuance of the Parliament; which having pa≈ø≈øed the Lords, was tendred to the King to be ≈øigned; together with the Bill of Attainder, His Maje≈øty an≈øwered, That on Monday following he would ≈øatisfie them; and on the Sunday before the King ≈øpent the whole day in con≈øulting about the Earl of Strafford with the Judges and Bi≈øhops: The Judges told him, That in point of Law (according to the Oath made by Sir H. Vane of the Earls advice, to rai≈øe Hor≈øe to awe this Nation) he was guilty of Trea≈øon. In the evening the Five Bi≈øhops, viz. of Armagh, London, Durham, Lincoln, and Carli≈øle, were called in to the King to ≈øatisfie his Con≈øcience about it, who all agreed, That the King might ≈øhew mercy without any ≈øcruple, and that he could not condemn the Earl, if he did not think him Guilty: This was to matter of Fact, but as to matter of Law, He was to re≈øt in the Opinion of the Judges.

Monday May 10. The King gives Commi≈ø≈øion to ≈øeveral Lords to pa≈øs Two Bills, one the Bill of Attainder again≈øt the Earl of Strafford: The other, For Continuing the Parliament during the plea≈øure of both Hou≈øes; Which la≈øt Act was occa≈øioned for ≈øatisfying the Scots, who required Va≈øt Sums of Money; and for disbanding both the Armies: whereby great Taxes were laid upon the People by Act of Parliament, which could not po≈ø≈øibly be levied in a ≈øhort time, and therefore there needed a pre≈øent Supply from the City of London, who (as it was alledged) would not part with their money, lea≈øt a Di≈ø≈øolution of the Parliament ≈øhould happen before payment; upon which Account the King was pre≈ø≈øed to pa≈øs this Act.

The ≈øame day the Bill was pa≈ø≈øed again≈øt the Earl of Strafford, the King ≈øent Sir Dudley Carlton,
Secretary of State, to acquaint the Earl with what was done, and the motives thereto, whereat the Earl was greatly a≈øtoni≈øht; but the next day the King being troubled, writes a Letter with his own hand to the Hou≈øe of Lords, and ≈øent it by the Prince of Wales, telling them, That whereas Ju≈øtice had been ≈øatisfied in his Condemnation, an intermixture of mercy would not now be un≈øea≈øonable; and therefore he de≈øired them, that if it might be done without any di≈øcontent to the People, the Earl might be permitted to fulfil the Natural Cour≈øe of his Life in clo≈øe Impri≈øonment, ≈øeque≈øtred from all Publick Affairs, provided he never attempted to make an E≈øcape; however he thought it a work of Charity to repreive him till Saturday. But nothing could be obtained in favour of him, but that the Lords ≈øaid, Their Intention was to be ≈øuitors to His Maje≈øty to ≈øhew favour to his innocent Children, and that whatever provi≈øion him≈øelf had made for them, it might be confirmed.

Some De≈øigns were ≈øaid to have been laid for his E≈øcape, however May 12, 1641, the Earl of Strafford was conveyed from the Tower by a Guard con≈øi≈øting of the Trained Bands, Mar≈øhals men, Sheriffs Officers, and Warders of the Tower. Before him went his Gentleman-U≈øher bare headed, and he him≈øelf followed, accompanied with the Archbi≈øhop of Armagh and others. As he went along he pa≈ø≈øed by Arch-bi≈øhop Lauds Lodging, and ≈øpying him at the Window, he called to him for his Prayers and his Ble≈ø≈øing; but the Bi≈øhop at the ≈øight of him was ≈øo ≈øurpriz'd that for ≈øome time he could not recollect him≈øelf, and being reprehended by his Friends of an undecent Pu≈øillanimity, He Replyed; That he doubted not but when that bitter Cup ≈øhould come to his turn, he ≈øhould taste it with a most Chri≈øtian Courage,

The Earl being come to the Scaffold upon Tower-hill, addre≈øt him≈øelf to the Arch-bi≈øhop of Armagh to this Effect, That he was come to pay the la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Debt he owed to Sin, with a good hope of ri≈øing agai ‚Ä¢ to Righteou≈øne≈øs: That he dyed willingly, forgave al ‚Ä¢ and ≈øubmitted to Justice: He profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf guiltle≈øs as to the matter for which he dyed; He wi≈øhed a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pro≈øperity to the King and People; and acquitted him from the guilt of his death, as having acted therei ‚Ä¢ no otherwi≈øe then as con≈øtrained: He advi≈øed his Adver≈øaries to repent of their Violent Proceedings again ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ him; and telling them that he thought it a ≈øtrange wa ‚Ä¢ to write in Blood the beginning of Reformation and Settlement of the Kingdom. However he wi≈øhed that hi ‚Ä¢ Blood might rest, and not cry again≈øt them. He declared, He died in the Faith of the Church of England for who≈øe happine≈øs he prayed, and concluded his Speech with intreating the Spectators to pray for him. After which he kneeled down to Prayer, and ri≈øing up again took his la≈øt leave of his Brother Sir George Wentworth and all his Friends, ≈øending his Love to his Wife, and his Ble≈ø≈øing to his Children; with a mo≈øt ≈øtrict Injunction to His Onely Son, Never to meddle with the Patrimony of the Church: And the ‚Ä¢ giving the ≈øign to the Executioner, his head wa ‚Ä¢ ≈øevered from his body at the fir≈øt ≈øtroke.

This was the end of that Great and Able Mini≈øter of State, who is reported when he heard the, King had con≈øented to the Bill of Attainder, to have lift up his Eyes to Heaven, and clapping his hand upon his heart, to have cried out (perhaps in immitation of Cardinal Wool≈øeys Complaint) Put not your Tru≈øt in Princes nor in the Sons of Men, for in them is no Salvation. And indeed it ≈øeemed very hard that he ≈øhou'd be made guilty of High Trea≈øon by a Bill framed on purpo≈øe, without former
Pre≈øident; and to which His Maje≈øties Con≈øent was in a manner extorted, and which he afterward bewailed with great remor≈øe of Con≈øcience, though it is ≈øaid the King was not ≈øo much convinced by any thing ≈øaid to him, but the chief Motive was a Letter from the Earl, wherein he thus concluded.

Sir, (To ≈øet your Maje≈øty's Con≈øcience at Liberty) I do mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech you, for the Preventing of ≈øuch mi≈øchiefs as may happen by your refu≈øal to pa≈øs the Bill, by this means to remove prai≈øed be God (I cannot ≈øay this accur≈øed but) this Unfortunate Thing, forth of the way, towards that ble≈ø≈øed Agreement which God I tru≈øt ≈øhall forever establi≈øh between You and Your Subjects. My con≈øent herein ≈øhall more acquit you to God, then all the world can do be≈øide: To a willing man there is no injury done.

His Character is Expre≈ø≈øed by the King his Ma≈øter, in his Eikon Ba≈øilike, who ≈øaid, He looked upon the Earl of Strafford as a Gentleman who≈øe great Abilities might make a Prince rather afraid than a≈øhamed to Imploy him in the greate≈øt Affairs of State.

The fall of this powerful man ≈øo ≈øtartled other great Officers of State, that ≈øeveral re≈øigned their places: About the ≈øame time ≈øome di≈øcontents aro≈øe between the Parliament and the Engli≈øh Army in the North, but a while after both Armies were disbanded. The payment of Tonnage and Poundage had been much que≈øtioned ≈øince 1628, but now the King at the reque≈øt of the Commons was content to relinqui≈øh his Claim to it, and afterward pa≈øied a Bill for Pole-money, and two others for putting down the Star chamber and High Commi≈ø≈øion Courts; which had proceeded with too much ≈øeverity, having ≈øo far out grown the power of the Law, that they would not be limited nor guided by it.

July 5. A Charge was brought into the Hou≈øe of Commons again≈øt Dr. Wren Bi≈øhop of Ely, being accu≈øed of ≈øome Trea≈øonable Mi≈ødemeanors in his Dioce≈øs; who thereupon Voted him unworthy and unfit to hold or exerci≈øe any Office or Dignity in Church or State, and de≈øired the Lords to join with them, to reque≈øt the King for his Removal from his ≈øervice; and ≈øo he was committed to the Tower, and about the ≈øame time the Writs for Ship money, and all the Proceedings therein were by the Kings con≈øent adjudged void; and 5. of the Judges that gave their Opinions for it, were Impeached of high mi≈ødemeanors; that is Bramston, Trevor, We≈øton, Davenport, and Crawly; and Berkly another of the Judges was accu≈øed for Trea≈øon, but no further pro≈øecution was made therein.

August 6. Both the Engli≈øh and Scotch Armies were disbanded, and four-days after the King went toward Scotland and was entertained with great demon≈øtrations of Affection by that Nation, and conferred ≈øeveral Places of Honour and Power upon divers of them; confirming likewi≈øe the Treaty between the two Nations by Act of Parliament.

October 23, 1641. A Horrid and Notorious Rebellion broke out in Ireland, which was managed with ≈øuch ≈øecrecy, that it was not di≈øcovered till the night before it was to have been put in Execution; which was in divers places carried on with ≈øuch fury, that Two hundred thou≈øand Engli≈øh Men, Women, and Children, were in a ≈øhort ≈øpace barbarou≈øly murdered by all manner of mo≈øt cruel torments that their Devli≈øh minds could invent. And this was chiefly occa≈øioned by the In≈øtigation of the Iri≈øh Popi≈øh Prie≈øts, Monks, and Fryers, who every where declaimed loudly again≈øt
the Prote≈øtants, ≈øaying, That they were Hereticks, and not to be ≈øuffered any longer to live amongst them, That it was no more ≈øin to kill one of them then to kill a dog; and that it was a mortal and unpardonable ≈øin to relieve or protect any of them. Yea the Prie≈øts gave the Sacrament to divers of the Iri≈øh, upon Condition they ≈øhould ≈øpare neither Man, Woman, nor Child of the Prote≈øtants, ≈øaying, That it did them a great deal of good to wa≈øh their hands in their blood; and that they were wor≈øe than Dogs; and if any of them died in the Quarrel, before their bodies were cold, their ≈øouls ≈øhould be in Heaven without ever calling in at Purgatory by the way.

This bloody Rebellion happened in a time wherein the Iri≈øh had all the Priviledges and Liberty they could rea≈øonably expect, and the ancient hatred which the Iri≈øh had born to the Engli≈øh did now ≈øeem to be forgotten, Forty Years of Peace having compacted and cemented them together, both by Alliances and Marriages, which were all now mi≈øerably broken and de≈øtroyed. The Ca≈øtle of Dublin, wherein were Ten thou≈øand Arms, and all other Forts and Magazines in the Kingdom, were to have been ≈øurprized, and all the Engli≈øh Protestants that would not joyn with them, were to be murdered; but the ≈øeizing of the Ca≈øtle was happily prevented by one Owen Conally, from ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe accidentally in a Tavern with one Hugh Mac Mahon, Grand≈øon to the Great Earl of Tyrone, the night before the intended Execution.

Upon this Di≈øcovery Mac Mahon and Lord Mac-Guire, were ≈øeized by the Lord Chief Ju≈øtices of Ireland, and many Principal Con≈øpirators e≈øcaped that night out of Dublin, ≈øo was Dublin ≈øaved, that all Ireland might not be lo≈øt in one day. But the horrid De≈øign was pa≈øt prevention as to the General,
for the Con≈øpirators were in Arms at the day appointed in all the Counties round about, and poor Engli≈øh Prote≈øtants daily arrived there, robbed and ≈øpoiled of all they had; giving lamentable Relations how their Hou≈øes were ≈øeized, the Towns and Villages fired, and in all parts all manner of cruel Outrages and Villanies committed. The Lords Ju≈øtices Sir William Par≈øons and Sir John Burlace, taking tho≈øe Arms which they found in Dublin, and Arming whom they could to defend them≈øelves, ≈øent Sir Henry Spot≈øwood to the King then in Scotland, with an Account of all that happened, who di≈øpatched Sir James Stuart with In≈øtructions to the Lords of the Privy Council in Ireland, and to carry all the Money his pre≈øent Stores would ≈øupply. He likewi≈øe moved the Parliament of Scotland (as being neare≈øt) for their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, but they excu≈øed it, becau≈øe Ireland was a dependant upon the Crown of England; but if the State of England would u≈øe any of their men for that ≈øervice, they would make Propo≈øitions in order to it. At the ≈øame time likewi≈øe, the King ≈øent Po≈øt to the Parliament of England, and a while after Owen O Conally the Fir≈øt Di≈øcoverer of the Plot, came to London and brought Letters to the Earl of Leice≈øter (who was cho≈øen Deputy, but not yet gone over) wherein the Lords Ju≈øtices de≈øired ≈øome Reward might be given him; upon which the Parliament Voted him a Gift of 500 l. and an Annuity of 200 l. a year, and at a Conference of both Hou≈øes they pa≈ø≈øed ≈øeveral Votes for the Relief of Ireland, yet little was done till the Kings return from Scotland, which was about the end of November.

The Iri≈øh, to di≈øhearten the Engli≈øh from any re≈øi≈øtance, bragged, That the Queen was with their
Army, That the King would come among≈øt them al≈øo, and a≈øi≈øt them; That they did but maintain his Cau≈øe again≈øt the Puritans: That they had the Kings Commi≈ø≈øion for what they did (≈øhewing indeed a Patent them≈øelves had drawn, but thereto was affixed an Old Broad Seal which had been taken from an Ancient Patent out of Farnham Abby by one Plunket in the pre≈øence of many of their Lords and Prie≈øts, as was afterwards atte≈øted by the Confe≈ø≈øion of ≈øeveral:) That the Scots were in the Confederacy with them; And to ≈øeem to confirm this la≈øt, they ab≈øtained for ≈øome time from de≈øtroying the E≈øtates or murdering any of that Nation: And on the other≈øide, to incourage the Iri≈øh, they produced pretended Letters; wherein they ≈øaid they were informed from England, That the Parliament had pa≈ø≈øed an Act, all the Iri≈øh ≈øhould be compelied to the Prote≈øtant wor≈øhip, and for the fir≈øt offence in refu≈øing, to forfeit all their Goods, for the ≈øecond their E≈øtates, and for the third their Lives; And be≈øides this they pre≈øented them with the hopes of Liberty, That the Engli≈øh Yoke ≈øhould be stricken off; That they ≈øhould have a King of their own Nation, and that then all the Goods and E≈øtates of the Engli≈øh ≈øhould be divided among≈øt them.

With the≈øe Motives of Spoil and Liberty, which were ≈øtrengthned by the former, of Religion, the Rebellion increa≈øed. The Rebels in Ul≈øter commanded by Sir Phelim O Neal, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by his Brother, the Brother of the Lord Mac Guire, Philip O Reley, and ≈øeveral others, had po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed mo≈øt of the ≈øtrong places in that Province; and many other, which they could not take by force nor treachery, were delivered to them by the Engli≈øh upon Articles, which they afterwards like true (or rather fal≈øe) Papi≈øts, mo≈øt perfidiou≈øly broke; Butchering and
Ma≈ø≈øacring the poor Engli≈øh without pity or compa≈ø≈øion to Age or Sex; though they ≈øtill ≈øpared the Scotch Plantations in Ulster, becau≈øe of their Numbers, and likewi≈øe for fear of the Scotch Army, ≈øo ea≈øily to be tran≈øported to the North parts of Ireland: But now their General Sir Phelim O Neal (one of the Race of the late Bloody Earl of Tyrone, (a pretended Prote≈øtant till ≈øome time before) having got together a va≈øt number of the Natives, fell upon them and de≈øtroyed their Hou≈øes and Goods; and though they did not exerci≈øe that Cruelty on their Bodies, yet they ≈øtript them and drove them Naked to the Scoti≈øh Shore; from thence he marched into other parts, and took Dundalk, incamping at Arde near Tredagh.

The King finding his ≈øtay to be longer than he thought left the whole bu≈øine≈øs of Ireland to the Parliament, who declared a ≈øpeedy and vigorous A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and Voted Fifty thou≈øand Pound for a pre≈øent Supply: By which time the Lords of the Council of Ireland had Armed as many as were able, and given Commi≈ø≈øions for rai≈øing ≈øeveral Regiments, of whom the Earl of Ormond was made Lieutenant General, and a Regiment was ≈øent from England under Sir Simon Harcourt; about which time the King returned out of Scotland, and was Entertained and Fea≈øted at London, and from thence Conducted to White-Hall: after which the King Treated ≈øeveral Chief Citizens at Hampton Court, where divers of the Aldermen had the honour of Knighthood.

December 2. The King Summons both Hou≈øes together, and tells them, That he had ≈øtaid in Scotland longer than he expected, yet not fruitle≈øly, for he had given full ≈øatisfaction to that Nation; but cannot chu≈øe but take notice of, and wonder at, the unexpected Di≈øtractions he finds at home; and then commends
to them the State of Ireland: next he publi≈øhes a Proclamation for Obedience to the Laws, in force concerning Religion, and the performance of Divine Service without Innovation or Aboli≈øhing of Rites and Ceremonies. January 20, His Maje≈øty makes another Speech to them, and Conjures them by all that is dear to him or them, to ha≈øten the bu≈øine≈øs of Ireland. After which the Commons ordered a Select Committee to draw up a Petition and Remon≈øtrance to the King; the Petition was thus,

The Je≈øuited Papi≈øts. 2. Th ‚Ä¢ Bi≈øhops, and corrupted Clergy. 3. Intere≈øte ‚Ä¢ Coun≈øellors, and Courtiers. The root of the mi ‚Ä¢

The Impri≈øoning and Fining ≈øeveral of the Members, rai≈øing great Sums of Money by Loan, Privy Seals, and Exci≈øe, and bla≈øting The Petition of Right, The ≈øucce≈øle≈øs Attempts upon France and Spain, and Peace made with the Spaniard without con≈øent of Parliament: The lo≈øs of Rochel occa≈øioned by lending part of our Fleet to the French King, de≈øerting the cau≈øe of the Palatinate, charging the Kingdom with Billeting Souldiers, and the De≈øign

Hereupon the King charges the L.
