To con≈øider of all matters ari≈øing from his Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage, and what was fit to be done.

And now began our Troubles, and all the Mi≈øeries of a Civil War; the Parliament every day entertaining (or pretending to entertain) new Jealou≈øies and Su≈øpicions of the Kings Actions, which how≈øoever in complement, they made ≈øhew of imputing only to his Evil Council, yet obliquely had had too great a Reflection upon his Per≈øon. They now proceed on a ≈øudden to make great preparations both by Sea and Land; and the Earl of Northumberland, Admiral of England, is commanded to rig the Kings Ships and fit them for Sea; and likwi≈øe all Ma≈øters and Owners of Ships were per≈øwaded to do the like. The Beacons were repaired, Seamarks ≈øet up, and extraordinary po≈øting up and down with Pacquets; all ≈øad Progno≈øticks of the Calamities en≈øuing.

The King being now at Roy≈øion, March 9, the Earls of Pembrook and Holland bring him the Parliaments Declaration, and read it to him; wherein they repre≈øent to him ≈øome former mi≈øcarriages: As the attempts to incen≈øe the late Nor hern Army again≈øt the Parliament. The Scoti≈øh Troubles, L. Jermins Trea≈øons and Tran≈øportation by the Kings Warrant. The Petition delivered to Captain Leg, with the Kings own hand, with the Direction ≈øigned C. R. The bu≈øine≈øs of the Lord Kimbolton and the five Members. The ≈øu≈øpicious de≈øigning a Guard about his Per≈øon, and under hand promoting the Iri≈øh Rebellion. The ordering Sir John Pennington to land the Lord Digby beyond Sea; from thence to alienate the King from his Parliament, and to procure Forreign Forces for his A≈ø≈øistance; which now (≈øaid they) appeared more credible by rea≈øon of his removal with the Prince, and the manifold Adverti≈øements from Rome, Venice, Paris, and other parts, certifying that the Popes Nuncio had ≈øollicited the Kings of France and Spain, to lend his
Maje≈øty 4000 Men apeice in reference to ≈øome De≈øign again≈øt Religion and the Parliament, and lastly, They de≈øire him to turn away his wicked Councellors, and to rely upon his Parliament, which if he would do, they would ≈øacrifice their Lives, Fortunes, and utmo≈øt endeavours to the Supportation of his Soveraignty.

After the reading of the Declaration, the Lords would have per≈øwaded the King to come near the the Parliament, and to grant the Militia for a time; which his Maje≈øty refu≈øed, and told them in ≈øhort, That their Fears, and Doubts and Jealou≈øies were ≈øuch as he would take time to ≈øatisfy the whole World of; but that his own doubts were not Trivial, occa≈øioned by ≈øo many Scandalous Pamphlets, and Seditious Sermons; divers publick Tumults hitherto uninquired into, and unpuni≈øhed; and ≈øometime after the King publi≈øhed a Declaration to the People, in An≈øwer to theirs; the ≈øum of which was.

p.q:
That he had no evil Councellors about him, but leaves ≈øuch to their cen≈øure where they ≈øhould find them. That he de≈øired the Judgments of Heaven might be manife≈øted upon tho≈øe who had any de≈øign again≈øt the Prote≈øtant Profe≈ø≈øion. That the Scotti≈øh Troubles were buried in perpetual ≈øilence, by the Act of Oblivion, and pa≈ø≈øed in Parliaments of both Kingdoms. That they charging him with any inclining to the Iri≈øh Rebels, was a high and cau≈øle≈øs injury to his Royal Reputation. That he never intended to exa≈øperate the late Army, or in any wi≈øe to u≈øe them again≈øt the Parliament. That Captain Leg's Petition was brought to him, ≈øub≈øcribed by the Officers of the Army, de≈øiring that the Parliament might not be hindred from reforming the Church and State, to the Model of Queen Elizabeths days; and was advantageous to them: And to a≈ø≈øure Sir Jacob
A≈øhly of his Opinion therein, he writ C. R. That the Lord Digby and Mr. Jermin, neither were at White-hall, nor had any Warrant from him after the Re≈øtraint. That he had given ≈øufficient An≈øwer about Kimbolton and the five Members. That the care of his own ≈øafety cau≈øed him to rai≈øe a Guard at White-hall, and to receive the Loyal Tender, which the Gentlemen of the Inns of Court did make him of their Service. And that he looked upon their Forreign Adverti≈øements, by them mentioned, as meerly wild and irrational.

div.p: The King goes further Northward, whil≈øt the Parliament Voted the Ordinance for Defence of the Kingdom, not to be prejudicial to the Oath of Allegiance, but to be obeyed as the Fundamental Laws; and that the Kings Commands for Lieutenancy over the ≈øeveral Counties were illegal and void; but he coming to Huntington ≈øends them a Me≈ø≈øage, March 15. That he intends to make his Re≈øidence at York, and de≈øires them to hasten their Succours for Ireland, and not upon any pretence of Order or Ordinance (to which he is not a Party) of the Militia, or any other thing, to Do or Execute against the Laws, which he him≈øelf was to keep, and his Subjects to obey, declaring his Subjects not to be obliged to obey any Act, Order, or Injunction to which he hath not given con≈øent: In an≈øwer to which, they re≈øolve That the ab≈øence of the King ≈øo far from his Parliament; was de≈øtructive to the Relief of Ireland; and therefore all tho≈øe Councellors which advi≈øed him to it, are to be ≈øu≈øpected as Favourers of that bloody Rebellion, as likewi≈øe tho≈øe who per≈øwaded his Maje≈øty to que≈øtion or contradict their Votes, which was a high breach of Priviledge of Parliament.

March 16. The King at Stamford publi≈øhed a
Proclamation for putting the Laws in Execution again≈øt Popi≈øh Recu≈øants; and from thence he goes to York, and there March 24, Repeals his Grant for pa≈ø≈øing the Bill against Tonnage and Poundage, of June 22 la≈øt pa≈øt, commanding the payment thereof for the future, according to the Act of the Fir≈øt of King James; and ≈øo this year ended.

It was now the year 1642, and the 18th of his Maje≈øties Reign, when a fre≈øh Difference aro≈øe; for the Earl of Northumberland, Admiral of England, being indi≈øpo≈øed, the King ordered Sir John Pennington, Vice Admiral, to take the charge of the Summer Fleet for the Narrow Seas; but the Parliament earne≈øtly de≈øired that it might be conferred upon the Earl of Warwick, but were refu≈øed by the King to their great di≈øta≈øte. During the A≈ø≈øizes at York, the Gentry, Mini≈øters, and Freeholders of that County, pre≈øented a Petition to the King, to endeavour an Agreement with the Parliament, who advi≈øes them to apply them≈øelves to the Parliament, for the good of all. And next day he ≈øends a Me≈ø≈øage to the Hou≈øes, That he intended to rai≈øe his Guard out of the Counties near Chester, Two thou≈øand Foot and Two hundred Hor≈øe, to be ≈øupplied with Arms from the Magazine at Hull, upon taking the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance, That if the Parliaments Undertaking for the Iri≈øh War, would not ≈øuffice to defray the Charges of rai≈øing and paying them, he would pawn or ≈øell his Land or Hou≈øes; de≈øiring them withal, to quicken their Levies for Munster, and Connaught, as the Scots already did theirs of Ul≈øter; and offers his Per≈øon again≈øt the Rebels.

The Parliament having for ≈øome time mi≈øtru≈øted the Kings going North, to be intended for ≈øeizing
the Magazine at Hull, endeavoured to prevent it, declaring their ≈øu≈øpicion of his de≈øign to rai≈øe an Army, and therefore pray, That it might be removed from thence to the Tower of London, as a place of more ≈øafety, and ea≈øier tran≈øport for Ireland; and that the Repreive for the popi≈øh prie≈øts in Newgate may be recalled and they executed. And to make all ≈øure, Sir John Hotham, a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, is ≈øent down to take upon him the Government of that place, who by his ≈øudden coming thither, prevented the Earl of New-ca≈øtle, who was de≈øigned by the King to be Governor thereof; ≈øo that when the King came to Hull in Per≈øon, with his Guard con≈øi≈øting of Lords and Gentlemen, April 23. 1642, he finds the Gates ≈øhut upon him, and the Bridges drawn up; but from the Wall Hotham appears, and upon his knees intreats his Maje≈øty, Not to command that, which, without the breach of his Tru≈øt, he could not yeild obedience to.

Whereupon the King finding his entrance prevented, cau≈øed Hotham in≈øtantly to be proclaimed Traytor; and by Letters to the Parliament, complained of that Indignity, and required ≈øatisfaction; but they ju≈øtified him therein, and ≈øent a Committee of the Lords and Commons to re≈øide there, for the better ≈øecuring the Garri≈øon to them, and gave the Governor power to rai≈øe the Trained Bands for his defence; after which the King hearing that the Parliament had rai≈øed a Guard of them≈øelves without his con≈øent; and reflecting upon the bu≈øine≈øs of Hotham, he ≈øummoned the Gentry of York≈øhire to a Meeting, and acquainted them, That his Magazine at Hull was going to be taken from him again≈øt his will, the Militia again≈øt the Law and his con≈øent, put in execution, and Sir
John Hothams Trea≈øon countenanced, ≈øo that he was re≈øolved to have a Guard to ≈øecure his per≈øon, in which he de≈øired their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, that he might be able to protect them, the Laws, and the true Prote≈øtant Religion, from violation or injury.

The King had hereby indifferently ≈øtrengthened him≈øelf, and more had come in had not tho≈øe Members of Parliament, who came to the King at York, prevailed with ≈øome of the Free-holders to prote≈øt again≈øt it. And the Parliament declare, That the Subjects unle≈øs bound to it by ≈øpecial Service, could not be commanded to attend the King at his plea≈øure, without tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing again≈øt the Laws and Liberties of the Kingdom. And that who≈øoever, upon pretence of his Maje≈øties Command, ≈øhall take up Arms in a warlike manner, ≈øhall be e≈øteemed di≈øturbers of the peace, and to be proceeded again≈øt accordingly.

In the mean while Sir Thomas Gardiner, who had been Recorder of London for ≈øix years, being Impeached by the Parliament, and in danger of hanging, was glad to ≈øhift for him≈øelf, and by flight e≈øcaped to the King; at which time his Maje≈øty endeavoured to have removed the Term from London to York, but was much oppo≈øed therein by the Parliament, who Voted it Illegal, and forbid the L. Keeper to i≈ø≈øue out Writs, or Seal any Proclamation to that purpo≈øe. The Parliament now proceed to put the people into a Military po≈øture, requiring all Per≈øons in Authority to put the late Ordinance of the Militia in Execution, which the King by his Proclamation forbids; but for the Peoples ≈øatisfaction the Parliament publi≈øh'd a ≈øevere Declaration to the ≈øame Effect as their former Remon≈øtrance; only this was added, That the King at his being in Scotland had countenanced the Iri≈øh in their Rebellious
De≈øigns, and that his connivance was manife≈øted by his tedious with-holding the Proclamation whereby they were declared Traytors, till Jan. 2. being almo≈øt a Quarter of a Year after the breaking out of the Rebellion, and then had appointed but forty Copies to be printed, & none of them to be publi≈øhed without his plea≈øure ≈øignified; whereas his Proclamations again≈øt the Scots had been di≈øper≈øed throughout all the Kingdom with publick Prayers and Execrations.

The King makes a ≈øpeedy An≈øwer hereunto, not much differing from what he had ≈øaid before; yet tells them, That as to the bu≈øine≈øs of the Iri≈øh, his Council in Ireland had de≈øired them no ≈øooner, nor ≈øo many Copies by twenty as he had Signed and and ≈øent them. His Maje≈øty had written a Letter to his Privy Council of Scotland, to take away from them all ≈øu≈øpicion of tho≈øe Imputations ≈øo frequently laid to his Charge, of being Popi≈øhly affected, to be guilty of the blood≈øhed in Ireland, and to bring in Forreign Forces; Wherewith they ≈øeemed ≈øo ≈øatisfied, that they returned a mo≈øt re≈øpectful An≈øwer, and pre≈øently interpo≈øed their Mediation to heal the Breach before it grew wider; humbly de≈øiring the King to hearken to his Parliament, as his greate≈øt, his be≈øt, and mo≈øt unparallel'd Council; and di≈øcouraging him from any per≈øonal Journey into Ireland. This Me≈ø≈øage was ≈øent by the Earl of Lowden, Chancellor of Scotland, and after this the Scots Petition to the Kings Privy Council there, Not to meddle with any verbal or real Engagement for the King again≈øt the Parliament. Hereupon the Engli≈øh Parliament publi≈øh a Prote≈øtation, wherein they vindicate their own proceedings, and declare the great ≈øen≈øe they had of the Affection of their Scoti≈øh Brethren, manife≈øted unto them in ≈øo many
particulars, and more e≈øpecially the mentioned Petition.

The Earl of Bristol, an Old Experienced State≈øman, prudently fore≈øaw that ≈øuch unhappy beginings mu≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily have a very bad I≈ø≈øue, & therefore earne≈øtly endeavoured an Accommodation by ≈øtating the Ca≈øe in the Hou≈øe of Lords; repre≈øenting the Offers of the King on the one ≈øide, and the Profe≈ø≈øions of the Parliament on the other; and likewi≈øe the dreadful Effects of a Civil War (then likely to en≈øue) by the Example of the woful De≈øolations in Germany, and the expen≈øive Troubles in Scotland; and then propo≈øes ≈øome methods for preventing the≈øe dangers: as 1. That a ≈øelect Committee of Parliament ≈øhould truly ≈øtate the matters in difference, with the mo≈øt probable ways of reconciling them. 2. To con≈øider particularly what may be expected, either in point of ≈øupporting the King, or releiving his People: And la≈øtly, how the Conditions agreed upon, may be ≈øecured. And to ≈øhew the nece≈ø≈øity of this cour≈øe, he di≈øcovers the deplorable State of Ireland, the debts and nece≈ø≈øities of the Crown, the di≈øtractions which were likely to produce confu≈øion of Religion, mo≈øt dangerous and de≈øtructive to a State, be≈øides the general Di≈øtraction of the Subjects, who between Commands, and Countermands, knew not whom to obey, This was admitted as good and ≈øolid Rea≈øon, but Divine Ju≈øtice would not ≈øo permit the Sins of the Engli≈øh Nation to go unpuni≈øhed, and the L. Bri≈øtols Speech, though well received, yet proved ineffectual.

In the mean time the Kings Guard increa≈øes at York, which the Hou≈øe Voted a preparation for War again≈øt the Parliament, a Breach of the Tru≈øt repo≈øed in him by his People, and that all ≈øuch as
≈øerve him there are Traitors to the Laws of the Kingdom, as the 11 Rich. 2. and the 1 Hen. 3. This was followed by another Declaration or Remon≈øtrance of the mi≈øactions of the King, and their own Priviledges, which the King an≈øwers and they again reply to; and May 28. the Parliament ordain, That all Sheriffs, Ju≈øtices, &c. make ≈øtay of all Arms and Ammunition going to the King at York; the King on the other ≈øide forbids all Per≈øons belonging to the Trained Bands or Militia of the Kingdom, to obey any Order, or Ordinance of any of the Hou≈øes; divers Members of both Hou≈øes withdrew them≈øelves to the King, as being un≈øatisfied with their proceedings; whereupon the Parliament Ordered, That all ≈øuch as did not make their Per≈øonal Appearance by June 16 en≈øuing, ≈øhould be fined an 100 pounds toward the Iri≈øh Wars, ≈øuch only excepted as were imployed by the Parliament.

They likewi≈øe under≈øtood that the Queen had pawned the Crown Jewels in Holland for Money to be tran≈øported to the King; which to prevent him of, they order, That whoever hath; or ≈øhall pay, lend, ≈øend, or bring any Money in Specie into this Kingdom, for, or upon tho≈øe Jewels; or accept of any Bill hereafter, ≈øhall be an Enemy to the State.

June 2. The Parliament ≈øent to the King Nineteen Propo≈øition: 1. That all the Kings Privy Council, great Officers, and Mini≈øters of State, may be put out, except ≈øuch as the Parliament ≈øhall approve; and that an Oath be tendered them. 2. That all Affairs of State be managed by the Parliament, except ≈øuch matters as are transferr'd by them to the Privy Council, and to be concluded by the major part of the Nobility under their hands, the full number not to exceed twenty
five, nor to be under Fifteen. If any place ≈øhall fall Void in the interval of Parliament, then that the major part of the Council chu≈øe one to be confirmed at the next Se≈ø≈øion of Parliament, 3. That all great Officers of the Kingdom, ≈øhall be cho≈øen with Approbation of Parliament. 4. That the Government and Education of the Kings Children, be by appointment of Parliament. 5. That their Marriages be treated and concluded by Parliament. 6. That the Laws again≈øt Papi≈øts, Prie≈øts, and others, be executed, without Toleration or Di≈øpen≈øation, except by Parliament. 7. That no Popi≈øh Lord or Peer have Vote in Parliament; and their Children be educated in the Protestant Faith. 8. That Church Government be reformed as the Parliament ≈øhall advi≈øe. 9. That the Militia be ≈øettled as the Parliament have ordered, and that the King recall all his Declarations, publi≈øhed again≈øt their Ordinances therein. 10. That all Privy Councellors and Judges take an Oath for the maintenance of The Petition of Right, and other Statutes, which ≈øhall be made this Parliament. 11. That all Officers placed by Parliament hold their places, Quam diu bene ≈øege≈ø≈øerint, as long as they ≈øhall act ju≈øtly. 12. That all Members of Parliament put out, during this time, be re≈øtored again. 13. That the Ju≈øtice of Parliament pa≈øs upon all Delinquents, and that they appear or abide their cen≈øure. 14. That the general Pardon pa≈øs with Exceptions, as the Parliament ≈øhall advi≈øe. 15. That all Forts and Ca≈øtles of this Kingdom be di≈øpo≈øed of by Parliament. 16. That the King di≈øcharge all his Guards and Forces now in being, and not rai≈øe any other, but in ca≈øe of actual Rebellion. 17. That the King enter into ≈øtrict Alliance with all Protestant Kingdoms and States for their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance,
to recover the Rights of his Si≈øter, and her Princely I≈ø≈øue, to tho≈øe Dignities and Dominions which belong to them: 18. That the Lord Kimbolton and the Five Members be cleared by Act of Parliament. 19. That no Peer hereafter to be made, ≈øhall ≈øit in Parliament without their con≈øent.

The≈øe propo≈øitions were rejected by the King, as incon≈øi≈øtent with his Regality: ≈øo that now Men began to di≈øpair of any good i≈ø≈øue, for both ≈øides make preparations for War: The King ≈øending out his Commi≈ø≈øions of Array; and the Parliament publi≈øhed an Order June 10. for bringing in money or plate to maintain the Hor≈øe, Hor≈øe-men, and Arms, for the publick peace and defence of the King and both Hou≈øes of Parliament; and declared the Kings Commi≈ø≈øion to be again≈øt the Law, Liberty and property of the Subject; and the Actors therein to be di≈øturbers of the peace, and Betrayers of the Subjects Liberty. At this time the Lord keeper Littleton, having delivered the Great Seal to one Eliot, whom the King ≈øent for it, dur≈øt not ≈øtay behind for fear of being que≈øtioned, but went to the King to York, as many of the Peers did likewi≈øe whom the King ≈øummoning together, as al≈øo his Privy Council, he declares and prote≈øts to them, That he would not U≈øurp any Illegal Authority over them, but is ready to maintain them again≈øt all others that would. And that he would defend them from all Votes and Orders of Parliament, together with the true Protestant Religion, the lawful Liberty of the Subject, and the ju≈øt Priviledges of the Three E≈øtates of Parliament; nor will he Engage them in any War but what ≈øhall be for the nece≈ø≈øary defence of his and their rights; Whereupon they all ingaged to him their Duty and Allegiance in a mo≈øt Solemn-Prote≈øtation,
After which the King ≈øent Letters to Sir Rich. Gurney L. Mayor, and the Aldermen and Sheriffs of London, forbidding them, upon peril of having their Charter que≈øtioned, to levy Arms or rai≈øe Money, upon pretence of a Guard to the Parliament, or any other Account, except only the relief of Ireland, or the payment of the Scotch Subjects.

At this time the King publi≈øheth a General Declaration, wherein he de≈øcants upon all the Parliaments Declarations for the la≈øt 7 Months, but e≈øpecially the la≈øt; profe≈ø≈øing that hence forward he expects they ≈øhould break out into di≈øloyal Actions, declaims again≈øt their making the defence of the King, to be the pretence for their rai≈øing Forces; prote≈øts his own con≈øtant Re≈øolution for the pre≈øerving of Peace, Religion, the Laws and Subjects Liberties, and expects all his Subjects to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him again≈øt the Traiterous Attempts of ≈øuch Men as would de≈øtroy his Per≈øon, Honour, and E≈øtate, and bring on a Civil War; engaging that who≈øoever ≈øhall bring to him Money, Ammunition, Hor≈øe, or Arms, ≈øhall receive Eight Pound per Cent. Con≈øideration, and have good A≈ø≈øurance of both Principal and Intere≈øt, upon his Forre≈øt Lands, Parks, and Hou≈øes.

After this the King by Proclamation forbids all Levies of Forces, and all Contributions to ≈øuch Levies, without his expre≈øs plea≈øure; grounding it upon ≈øeveral Statutes as 7 Edw. 1. 2 Edw. 3. And then minds them of their Oath of Allegiance, by which they were bound to be Faithful, not to the King only as King, but to his Per≈øon, as King Charles, contrary to the Parliaments di≈øtinction, betwixt his Per≈øon and his Authority; his Per≈øon at York, and his Authority in Parliament; and concludes
with ju≈øtifying his Commi≈ø≈øion of Array, which were now I≈ø≈øued out in ≈øeveral Counties in England and Wales; to this the Parliament reply, and the King again to them, which was followed by ≈øeveral Me≈ø≈øages to and fro; all which rather exa≈øperated than allayed the difference; and now began England to be divided, as Italy once was into Guelphes and Gibbellines, ≈øo they into Rovallists and Presbyterians, or Cavaleers and Roundheads.

After this the King makes a Progre≈øs from York into the Counties of Nottingham and Lincoln, and Summons the Gentlemen and Freeholders to Newark, he Care≈ø≈øes them with the mo≈øt obliging expre≈ø≈øions imaginable. And July 11, 1642, His Maje≈øty ≈øends a Me≈ø≈øage to the Parliament to Certifie them of his Intentions to reduce Hull by force, if not forthwith delivered to him, which if they ≈øhould do, he would then admit of their future Addre≈ø≈øes, and return ≈øuch Propo≈øitions as might be≈øt conduce to prevent the approaching War; together with this Me≈ø≈øage he ≈øent them likewi≈øe a Copy of the Proclamation, which he had publi≈øh'd again≈øt Sir J. Hotham, wherein he complains of the Affront done to his Per≈øon by Sir J. and of the Parl. ju≈øtifying that Action by their Votes and Orders; That Hotham having fortified the Town, and drown'd the Countrey, had al≈øo ≈øet out a Pinnace at Sea, which had intercepted his Pacquet Boat with the Queens Letters, and that the E. of Warwick contrary to the Kings Command, had taken upon him the Command of the Fleet; for which Rea≈øons the King was re≈øolv'd to puni≈øh Hotham. Indeed the E. of W. had been by the Parl. commended to the King as the fitte≈øt man for Admiral (the E. of N. being then ≈øick) but he was rejected by the King, who conferr'd that place upon Sir John Pennington; Yet afterwards the Parl. conceiving it
nece≈ø≈øary to get the Fleet into their hands, they found means, notwith≈øtanding the Oppo≈øitions of Sir J. Pennington and his Adherents, to make the E. of W. Admiral; after which a Ship laden with Arms and Ammunition from Holland for the King, being ignorant of the matter, fell in among the Fleet, and was by the E. of W. ≈øent to the Parliament.

The Parliament now thought fit to Arm, and therefore re≈øolve that an Army ≈øhall be rai≈øed for Defence (as they term it) of King and Parliament; and the Earl of E≈ø≈øex to be Capt. General, and the E. of Bedford to command the Hor≈øe; the E. of Holland, Sir John Holland, and Sir Will. Stapleton, were ordered to carry a Petition to the King then at Beverly; the effect whereof was, To pray him to di≈øband all his Forces, to recal his Commi≈ø≈øions of Array, di≈ømi≈øs his Guard; and return to the Parliament: All which the King refu≈øed. The Parliament next con≈øider of rai≈øing Money, and ≈øo declare for Loan upon the Publick Faith; to promote which the endeavours of the Mini≈øters were very ≈øerviceable, whereby in a ≈øhort time a very con≈øiderable quantity of Money, Plate, and Ammunition, were brought in.

The King was likewi≈øe furni≈øhed with Money from the Queen upon the pawned Jewels, and ≈øome Contributions from divers Lords and Gentlemen, and the Univer≈øity of Oxford. The King goes from Beverly to Leicester, and there Proclaims the Earl of Stamford Traitor, for removing the County Magazine from the Town to his own Hou≈øe at Bradgate. Aug. 1. the King comes back to Yorkshire, and rai≈øes a Regiment under the E. of Cumberland, which he called Prince Charles his Regiment.

The Parliament on the other ≈øide, declare the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Array to be Traitors and di≈øturbers of the State and Peace of the Kingdom, and Lievtenants of ‚Ä¢ everal Counties were con≈øtituted by Parliament. The King likewi≈øe deals with their Commanders, as ‚Ä¢ hey did with his, and Proclaimed General E≈ø≈øex with all his Collonels and Officers who ≈øhould not ‚Ä¢ n≈øtantly lay down their Arms, to be Rebels and Trai
‚Ä¢ ors; and the Marque≈øs of Hartford and his Forces ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re ordered to march again≈øt him. The King then ‚Ä¢ ummons in the Countrey on the North ≈øide of Trent,
‚Ä¢ nd 20 miles Southward, and publi≈øheth his Grand Declaration concerning all tran≈øactions between him≈øelf and the Parliament.

Augu≈øt 22. 1642. The King comes to Nottingham,
‚Ä¢ nd there erects his Standard, to which ≈øome numbers re≈øorted, but far ≈øhort of what was expected; And three days after the King ≈øends a Me≈ø≈øage to the Parliament to propo≈øe a Treaty; the Me≈ø≈øengers were ‚Ä¢ he Earls of Southampton and Dor≈øet, Sir John Culpeper Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Sir William ∆≤dall; none of which were ≈øuffered to ≈øit in the Hou≈øe, to deliver their Errand, therefore it was ≈øent in by the U≈øher of the Black Rod, to which the Parliament An≈øwered, That untill His Maje≈øty ≈øhall recall his Proclamations, and Declarations of Trea≈øon again≈øt the E. of E≈ø≈øex, and them, and their Adherents; And unle≈øs the Kings Standard ≈øet up in pur≈øuance thereof, be taken down, they cannot by the fundamental Priviledges of Parliament, give his Maje≈øty another an≈øwer.

p.q: The King replyes, that he never intended to declare the Parliament Traitors, or ≈øet up his Standard again≈øt them; but if they re≈øolve to Treat, either Party ≈øhall revoke their Declarations again≈øt all Per≈øons as Traitors, and the ≈øame day to take down his Standard.

div.p:
To this they an≈øwer, That the Differences could no ‚Ä¢ any ways be concluded, unle≈øs he would for≈øake hi ‚Ä¢ evil Councellors, and return to his Parliament; And accordingly Sept. 6. they Order and Declare, tha ‚Ä¢ the Arms which they have, or ≈øhall take up for th ‚Ä¢
Parliament, Religion, Laws, and Liberties of the Kingdom, ≈øhall not be laid down untill the King withdraw his Protection from ≈øuch per≈øons as are or ≈øhall be Voted Delinquents, and ≈øhall leave them to Ju≈øtice that ≈øo their E≈øtates may di≈øcharge the Debts and Loan Moneys of the Common-wealth.

The War being now begun, the new rai≈øed Souldiers committed many Outrages upon the Countrey People, which both King and Parliament upon Complaint endeavoured to rectifie: The King him≈øelf was now Generali≈ø≈øimo over his own, his Captain General was fir≈øt the Marque≈øs of Hartford, and afterward the E. of Lind≈øey, and the E. of E≈ø≈øex for the Parliamentarians; The Kings Forces received the fir≈øt repul≈øe at Hull by Sir John Hotham, and Sir John Meldrum, and the King takes up his Quarters at Shrewsbury; Port≈ømouth was next ≈øurrendred to the Parliament, and pre≈øently after Sir John Byron takes Worce≈øter for the King; In September the two Prince Palatines, Rupert and Maurice arrived in England, who were pre≈øently entertained, and put into Command by the King; who having now got together a potent Army, he made a ≈øolemn Prote≈øtation to them of his candid Intentions, and ≈øincere meaning, to defend the Prote≈øtant Religion, the Laws and Liberties of the Subject, and Priviledges of Parliament, according to the former prote≈øtation at York.

Sept. 9. the Earl of E≈ø≈øex in great State attended on by the Parliament ≈øet forth out of London toward St. Albans, and from thence to Northampton, where all his Forces met, amounting to near fourteen thou≈øand
men, having with him the Parliaments Petition which he was to pre≈øent to the King, the effect of which was,

That his Loyall Subjects the Lords and Commons in Parliament, cannot without tenderne≈øs of Compa≈ø≈øion behold the pre≈ø≈øing Calamities of England, and Ireland, by the Practices of a prevailing Party with his Maje≈øty, to alter true Religion, and the Ancient Government of this Kingdom, introducing Super≈øtition into the Churches, and Confu≈øion in the State; Exciting, encouraging, and fo≈øtering the Rebellion in Ireland, and as there, ≈øo here begin the like Ma≈ø≈øacres; by drawing on a War again≈øt the Parliament, leading his Per≈øon again≈øt them, as if by Conque≈øt to e≈øtabli≈øh an unlimited Power over the People, ≈øeeking to bring over the Rebels of Ireland to joyn with them: And all the≈øe evil Councellors are Defended and protected again≈øt the Ju≈øtice of the Parliament, who have for their ju≈øt Defence of Religion, the Kings Crown and Dignity, the Laws, Liberties and Power of Parliaments, taken up Arms, and Authorized the E. of E≈ø≈øex to be their Captain General again≈øt the≈øe Rebels and Traytors. And pray the King to withdraw his Per≈øon, and leave them to be ≈øuppre≈øt by his Power, and to return to his Parliament, and that they will receive him with Honour, and yeild him Obedience, ≈øecure his Per≈øon, and e≈øtabli≈øh him and his People with all the Ble≈ø≈øings of a Glorious and Happy Reign.

This Petition was never delivered, though E≈ø≈øex ≈øent twice to the King for ≈øafe conduct for tho≈øe who were to pre≈øent it; for the King refu≈øed to receive any Addre≈øs from tho≈øe whom he accu≈øed of High Trea≈øon, of whom the E. of E≈ø≈øex was one: The King then marches from Shrewsbury toward London, upon which the Parliament ordered the Forces of the A≈ø≈øociated Counties of E≈ø≈øex, Hartford, Middle≈øex
and London to be ready at an hours warning‚ñ™ They likewi≈øe order that the Lands, Rents and Profits of Archbi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, ≈øhall be Seque≈øtred, as likewi≈øe the Kings Fines about Wards.

A while after Collonel Fines and Sands were routed at Worce≈øter by Prince Rupert, while they endeavoured to take the Town from Sir John Byron, who had it in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion for the King; but E≈ø≈øex making his approach with his Army, Prince Rupert and Byron quitted the Town to him; then were Gloce≈øter, Bri≈øtol and other places made Garri≈øons for the Parliament; But in York-≈øhire and Cornwall the Kings Party grew powerfull, and likewi≈øe in Wales; where the E. of Worce≈øter had got together a great number of Welchmen, ≈øo that the King ≈øeeing his Army increa≈øed, re≈øolved to march toward London, and was gotten one dayes Journey before E≈ø≈øex; who perceiving his Error of ≈øtaying ≈øo long at Worce≈øter, ha≈øtens after him, to the relief of his Ma≈øters; the King di≈ødaining to be pur≈øued by a Subject, turns back to meer him, and October 23. 1642. both Parties drew into the Field between Keinton and Edghill in Warwick-≈øhire, where on both ≈øides were ≈ølain between five and 6000. men that day, but night parting them, the next day both parties quit the Field; the King then marches to Coventry, and from thence ≈øends a Proclamation of Pardon to the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øome Per≈øons only excepted. This Battell of Edge-hill was fought on Sunday, the ≈øame day twelve Month the Iri≈øh Rebellion brake out.

The King then takes in Banbury, the Town and Ca≈øtle being ≈øurrendred without a blow, and two Regiments of Foot, and a Troop of Hor≈øe, took Arms under him; from thence the King marches to Oxford; and E≈ø≈øex goes to London, where he was received with great Honour; The Parliament to
recruit their Army, declare; That all Apprentices who will Li≈øt them≈øelves, ≈øhall be free from their Ma≈øters for that time, and ≈øhall afterward be received again into ≈øervice: By which means abundance were induced to turn Souldiers; they likewi≈øe invite the Scots to come in to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; which the King by a Letter to the Lords of the Privy Council in Scotland endeavours to prevent, but in vain: At this time ≈øeveral of the Lords and Commons pre≈øent a Petition to the King at Colebrook, to de≈øire him to appoint a place to treat in: To which he an≈øwered; He would expect them at his Ca≈øtle of Wind≈øor, and de≈øires them to ha≈øten the Treaty.

At the ≈øame time, the King hearing that E≈ø≈øex had drawn his Forces and Ordnance out of London toward him, and that unle≈øs he gained Brainford he would be hemm'd in by the Parliaments Army, who po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed mo≈øt of the Towns round about him; the King marches thither that night, where part of Col. Hollis's Regiment that quartered there, made a ≈øtout re≈øi≈øtance, till the L. Brooks's and Coll. Hamdens Regiments came in to their relief, who maintained the Fight till night, and then retreated out of Town, which the King pre≈øently took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of, with ≈øome Pri≈øoners, Arms and Amunition, 11 Colours, and 15 pieces of Ordnance: E≈ø≈øex hearing this, ≈øoon came thither, followed with the City Militia and Trained Bands, which together made a formidable Army, ≈øo that the King thought fit to march back again to Oxford; This Action in a time of Treaty, (though not without ≈øufficient ground) was ≈øo ill re≈øented by the Hou≈øes, that they Voted to have no Accommodation: Yet afterward upon con≈øideration, they again Petition him to de≈øert his Army, and return to his Parliament, but with the ≈øame ≈øucce≈øs as formerly.

At this time a Letter from one of the Kings Agents
in Holland was intercepted, in which he is advertis'd of con≈øiderable Forces ready to be ≈øent over for his Service; from Denmark likewi≈øe Arms are ≈øent for ten thou≈øand Foot, and 2500 Hor≈øe, with a Train of Artillery, and every thing proportionable, even to the Drums and Halberts. In York-≈øhire the Earl of Newca≈øtle had a ≈øharp rencounter at Tadca≈øter with the L. Fairfax, and forced him to retreat: The Counties of Norfolk, Suffolk, E≈ø≈øex, Hartford, Cambridge, the I≈øle of Ely, and the City of Norwich, are authorized by Parliament to a≈ø≈øociate under the L. Gray of Wark, and Winche≈øter and Che≈øter are gained by the Paliament.

Dec. 15. Collonel Goring with the Kings Standard, 80 Old Commanders, and ≈øtore of Warlike Provi≈øion, joyn with the E. of Newca≈øtle. About which time the City of London Petitioned the King, and profe≈øs their grief, for his di≈øtru≈øt of their Loyalty, with large Prote≈øtations of their zealous Intentions to defend him, with all the Love and Duty which became good Subjects. The King replies, That he hath a good Opinion of many of them, and could freely and willingly Pardon all except Pennington the pre≈øent Maior, Venn, and ≈øome others; and concludes with declaring his high di≈øplea≈øure again≈øt ≈øuch as ≈øhall continue acting, and a≈ø≈øi≈øting his Adver≈øaries: Many of them were ≈øtartled with this An≈øwer, yet were revived again with what Mr. Pryn and the Parliament Committee told their Common Council, of the Parliaments great Love and Affection to them, and Re≈øolution to live and dye in their Defence.

In the North Sir. Hugh. Cholmly encounters with ≈øeveral Partyes of the Kings Hor≈øe at Malton, and Jan. 16. joyning with Sir. Matthew Boynton, routed a Party of 600 Hor≈øe and Foot under, Col. Slingsby, Sir. Thomas Fairfax. likewi≈øe take≈øt, Leeds with little lo≈øs on his ≈øide, but 500 Royalli≈øts
were made Pri≈øoners, (≈øix of them Commanders) 4 Colours, and much Arms and Ammunition were taken; The Kings Forces next leave Wakefield and Donca≈øter, which are pre≈øently garri≈øoned for the Parliament. The E. of Newca≈øtle brings his Forces to York, to prepare for entertaining the Queen; and Jan. 17. he proclaims the L. Fairfax, and his Son Sir Thomas, Traytors, (as the E. of Cumberland had done before) which the Parliament re≈øenting, proclaimed the L. Newca≈øtle the ≈øame.

The Parliament, Febr. 1. make the following Prepo≈øitions to the King at Oxford (which were pre≈øented by the Earls of Northumberland, Salisbury, Pembrook, and Holland, with 8. of the Hou≈øe of Commons.) To disband his Army, and to return home to his Parliament; To leave all Delinquents to Tryal, and all Papi≈øts to be di≈øarmed: To pa≈øs an Act for Aboli≈øhing the pre≈øent Church Governors, and ≈øuch other Bills as ≈øhall be prepared in order to a Reformation; All Popi≈øh Recu≈øants to abjure and renounce Popery; All Malignant Councellors to be removed, the Militia to be ≈øetled according to the Parliaments minds; ≈øuch Per≈øons to be preferr'd to Great Offices and Places of Judicature, as the Parliament ≈øhall name, and all ≈øuch Ju≈øtices of Peace as have been lately turned out of Commi≈ø≈øion to be again taken in; That an Act pa≈øs to Vindicate the L. Kimbolton, and the 5 Members. And an Alliance be entred into with our Prote≈øtant Neighbours for Recovery of the Palatinate, That a General Pardon pa≈øs, with exception to the E. of Newca≈øtle, L. Digby, and ≈øome others; That ≈øuch Members of Parliament as have been di≈øplaced, be re≈øtored to Offices and Places, and ≈øatisfaction made them for their Lo≈ø≈øes.

On the other ≈øide, the King Propo≈øed, That his own Revenue, Magazines, Towns, Ships, and Forts be re≈øtored: That what hath been done contrary to Law, and the King Rights, may be renounced, and recalled: That all Illegal Power claimed, or acted by any Orders of Parliament, be di≈øclaimed; And as the King will readily con≈øent to the Execution of all Laws made or to be made concerning Popery, and Reformation, ≈øo he de≈øires a Bill for the pre≈øerving the Book of Common-Prayer again≈øt Sectaries; And that all Per≈øons excepted again≈øt in the Treaty, may be Tryed per Pares by the Equals: That there be a Ce≈ø≈øation of Arms, and a Free Trade.

This made way for a Treaty of Peace, but little was done in it till March 4. 1642. when Sir Ben. Rudyard one of the Commons, told the Parliament plainly, That the War would ruine all; whereupon they appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners, that is, the E. of Northumberland, Mr. Perpoints, Sir. William Ermine, Sir John Holland, and Mr. Whitlock, who were to attend the King at Oxford.

Feb. 23. 1642. The Queen landed at Burlington Key, with Officers, Ammunition and Mony from Holland, from whence the E. of Montro≈øs, and the Lord Ogilby conveyed her to York, where ≈øhe was honourably received by the Earls of Cumberland and Newca≈øtle, and there ≈øhe began to form her Army. In the mean time Coll. Ma≈ø≈øey advances again≈øt Capt. Bridges, who kept Sudly Ca≈øtle in Gloce≈øter≈øhire, with 60 Souldiers, and all other things ≈øufficient, for the L. Shandois on the Kings behalf; Coll. Ma≈ø≈øy offers to ≈øtorm the Ca≈øtle, but is repul≈øed, yet next day he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed the Garden under the Ca≈øtle, and firing ≈øome hay and ≈øtraw, made ≈øo great
a ≈ømother in the Hou≈øe, that taking the opportunity thereof, he planted his great Guns ≈øo conveniently as forced the Be≈øieged to ≈øurrender upon Quarter, leaving their Arms, and ingaging to pay 500 pounds in ≈øix days for the goods in the Ca≈øtle, or el≈øe to lo≈øe them.

Yet had the Parliament no great cau≈øe of boa≈øting of this Victory; For ≈øoon after P. Rupert with 4000 Hor≈øe and Foot, making ≈øhew to regain it, marches to Cirence≈øter, where the ≈øtrength and great part of the Magazine of the County lay, and Feb. 1. he ma≈øters the Gaurd, and forces his Pa≈ø≈øage into the Town, which in two hours he gained, taking 1100 Pri≈øoners, and 2000 Arms; And next day he ≈øummons Gloce≈øter, which Coll. Ma≈ø≈øey was re≈øolved to defend, and to ≈øtrengthen it, de≈øerts Sudly Ca≈øtle and other our Garri≈øons.

The Earl of Worce≈øter and his ≈øon the L. Herbert had now rai≈øed an Army of near 1500 Welchmen for the King, with whom he marched to the Forre≈øt of Dean, and beat Coll. Bourroughs Regiment out of a ≈ømall Town call'd Coford near Monmoth; from thence they march to Hingham within 2 miles of Gloce≈øter, and Coll. Bret, demands the Town for the King, but was an≈øwered with ≈øcorn; for Ma≈ø≈øey with a≈ø≈øi≈øtance from Capt. Fines at Bri≈øtol, weakned them with continual Shirmi≈øhes, till Sir William Waller having taking Malmsbury came to Gloce≈øter, and joyned his Forces with the other, ≈øo that this Welch Army ≈øpent near five weeks without doing any Memorable Action.

But now Coll. Ma≈ø≈øey draws out all his Hor≈øe, with 500 Foot, and ≈øome Ordnance, and held them play the fir≈øt day; the next morning the great. Guns give the Alarum, and both Parties engage
very fiercely, and the Welch were like to have routed him, and taken his Ordnance, at which in≈øtant Sir William Waller comes in to Ma≈ø≈øeys a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who taking courage thereby they run furiou≈øly upon the Welchmen, and drive them back to Hingham hou≈øe, which they began pre≈øently to batter with their Cannon; whereupon the Welch found a Parley, and ≈øurrender the Place, and them≈øelves Pri≈øoners, but the Officers were to receive Quarter according to their Qualities; and next day Waller and Ma≈ø≈øey led their booty in Triumph to Gloce≈øter.

The a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Scots had been formerly de≈øired by the Parliament, which (notwith≈øtanding their late Prote≈øtations not to take Arms again≈øt their Prince,) they now hearken to, and having compleated their Army, March 13. 1641. they cro≈øs the River Tyne, and march Southward, to imploy the E. of Newca≈øtle.

The Iri≈øh Rebels about this time (notwith≈øtanding the defeats they met with at Tredagh and Dundalk) were much increa≈øed in number; And the the Pope (a more unhappy Fi≈øher, than his pretended Predece≈ø≈øor St. Peter, who was for ≈øaving, but he for de≈øtroying men) ≈øends two Letters to them, one ≈øub≈øcribed to Owen Oneal, and the other to all Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Nobles and People of the Kingdom of Ireland, in both which he commends tho≈øe who had already appeared in the Quarrel, and exhorts others to engage in the ≈øame, declaring his great Joy for their late Butcheries, and Ma≈ø≈øacres upon the Prote≈øtants, and be≈øtowing upon them his Fatherly Benediction, and Plenary Pardon and Ab≈øolution for whatever Villanies they had committed. By the Popes thus publickly declaring him≈øelf for them, the Rebels grew very powerful,
and many who were at fir≈øt afraid of being concerned, now openly appeared for them, in≈øomuch that all parts of Ireland were overwhelmed by them as with an Innundation.

This year was remarkable for the death of Cardinal Richlieu that great Firebrand and di≈øturber of Europe, but more pertcularly the≈øe three Kingdoms, of who≈øe di≈øtractions he was both a Principal cau≈øer, and Fomenter; He led the way to his Ma≈øter Lewis 13. who decea≈øed ≈øoon after in the mid≈øt of his Conque≈øts in Catalonia, leaving for his ≈øucce≈ø≈øer his elde≈øt ≈øon Lewis 14. (the pre≈øent French King) under the Government of the Queen Dowager, and Cardinal Mazarine ≈øucceeded in Richlieus ≈øtead.

The year 1643. and the nineteenth of his Maje≈øties Reign, began with a Treaty of Peace, which was formerly agreed on, but proceeded ≈ølowly, till it was again revived by Sir Ben. Rudyard; The Commi≈ø≈øioners on both parties now met at Oxford, and began to Treat of the Kings Propo≈øitions, concerning his Revenue, Magazines, Forts, and Ships; And the Parliaments Propo≈øitions concerning the di≈øbanding of Armies, which particulars taking up more time than the King expected, his Maje≈øty April 12. 1643. ≈øends this Me≈ø≈øage to the Parliament.

That as ≈øoon as he was ≈øatisfied concerning his own Revenue, Magazines, Ships and Forces, in which he de≈øired nothing but his Ju≈øt and Legal known Rights to be re≈øtored to him, and to Per≈øons Tru≈øted by him; And as ≈øoon as the Members of both Hou≈øes ≈øhould be re≈øtored to the ≈øame capacity of ≈øitting and Voting in Parliament as they had upon January 1. 1641. (excluding ≈øuch who≈øe Votes had been taken away by Bill, or by New Elections, or New Writts:) And that as ≈øoon as his Maje≈øty and both Hou≈øes may be ≈øecured from ≈øuch Tumultuous A≈ø≈øemblies as to the High di≈øhonour of the Parliament had
awed the Members of the ≈øame (which he conceived could not otherwi≈øe be done, but by adjourning the Parliament to ≈øome place Twenty miles from London, ≈øuch as the Hou≈øes ≈øhould agree upon,) His Maje≈øty mo≈øt chearfully and readily would con≈øent to the disbanding of the Armies, and would return ≈øpeedily to his Two Hou≈øes of Parliament according to the Time and Place which they ≈øhould agree upon.

Upon this Me≈ø≈øage the Parliament re≈øolved to call back their Commi≈ø≈øioners, and ≈øo April 15. the Treaty ended; About the beginning of la≈øt March the L. Brook marched toward Northampton, and ≈øeizing the Ammunition there he went from thence to Warwick, and ≈øo to Stratford upon Avon, and beat Coll. Crockers, and Lt. Coll Wag≈øtaff's Forces out of that Town; after which Be≈øiegeing Litchfield, one of the Kings Party ≈øhooting at a venture at the window of his Chamber, the bullet pierced him in the Eye, of which he immediately dyed, yet his Souldiers being heightned with Revenge, took the Clo≈øe with the E. of Che≈øterfield and all his Souldiers and Ordnance; after which Prince Rupert and the Earl of Northampton joining their Forces, fell upon the Parliamentarians at Lichfield, where the E. of Northampton was ≈ølain in the head of his Troop, yet Lieut. Coll. Ru≈ø≈øel who commanded it, de≈øpairing of ≈øuccour, yielded up the Place to Prince Rupert upon Honourable Conditions, and marched away to Coventry.

April 17. 1643. the E. of E≈ø≈øex ≈øate down before Reading, and made two a≈ø≈øaults, but was repul≈øed; The King marched from Oxford to Wallingford for its relief, but E≈ø≈øexes Army increa≈øing daily with fre≈øh ≈øupplies from London, both Parties happened to Skirmi≈øh at Cau≈øum Bridge, where many of the Kings Forces were ≈ølain, and forced to retreat; whereupon the Town was a while after ≈øurrendred
by Coll. Fielding, who was made Deputy Governour in the room of Sir Arthur A≈øton who was di≈øabled by a brui≈øe he received in his head with a Brickbat: Fielding was for this Sentenced by a Council of War at Oxford to lo≈øe his Head, but by the Interce≈ø≈øion of Friends was pardoned.

May 3. Cheap≈øide Cro≈øs was demoli≈øhed a Troop of Hor≈øe, and two Companies of Foot waiting to ≈øee it done, and at the fall of the Top Cro≈øs, Drums beat, Trumpets blew, and a great ≈øhout was made; Charing-cro≈øs, and all other Cro≈ø≈øes in and about London were likewi≈øe pulled down about the ≈øame time.

In the mean time the breach between the King and Parliament became wider than ever; ≈øo that they proceeded to draw up Articles of High Trea≈øon again≈øt the Queen, ≈øome of which were; That ≈øhe had pawned the Crown Jewells in Holland, That ≈øhe had favoured the the Rebellion in Ireland, That ≈øhe had endeavoured to rai≈øe a Party in Scotland again≈øt the Parliament, and that ≈øhe had gone in the head of a Popi≈øh Army in England; Several other Articles were framed again≈øt her, upon which Mr. Pym carried up an Impeachment to the Lords, who ≈øeemed at fir≈øt ≈øurprized therewith, but they afterward agreed to the Charge.

The Queen had about this time rai≈øed an indifferent Army of Hor≈øe and Foot, and leaving ≈øome Hor≈øe and Foot with Sir Charles Cavendi≈øh for defence of Lincoln-≈øhire, and Nottingham-≈øhire, ≈øhe with 3000 foot, three Companies of Hor≈øe and Foot, ≈øix Canons, and two Mortar pieces, met the King at Edge-hill, and goes from thence with him to Oxford.

Several Encounters happened in the We≈øt between Sir Ralph Hopton for the King, and Sir G.
Chudleigh then Commander of the Parliaments Forces, where ≈øometimes one Party was Victorious, and then the other; Collonel Nath. Fines Governout of Bri≈øtoll, about this time di≈øcover'd a de≈øign of Robert Yeomans, and George Bouchier to deliver up that City to the Kings Forces, upon which they were Condemned by Council of War, and hanged May 30 notwith≈øtanding the Kings Letter to the Maior and Citizens, and General Ruthens to the Governour on their behalf; And ≈øo ends this month, famous by the Death of Mr. John Pym that active Per≈øon in the Hou≈øe of Commons.

In June 1643. Mr. Waller a Member of the Hou≈øe of Commons, Mr. Tomkins, Mr. Challoner, Mr. Ha≈øel, Mr. Blinkhorn, Mr. White and others, were Arraigned at Guild-Hall London, they being charged, For de≈øigning to ≈øeize into their Cu≈øtody the Kings Children, ≈øome Members of Parliament, the L. Mayor, and Committee of the Militia, all the Cities Outworks, and Forts, the Tower of London, and all the Magazines, and then to let in the Kings Forces to ≈øurprize the City. Upon this Indictment they were Tryed, and Condemned, but Tomkins and Challoner onely were hanged.

Some Skirmi≈øhes pa≈ø≈øed between the E. of E≈ø≈øex and P. Rupert, who ingaging about Tame in Oxford≈øhire, The Prince routed a body of Hor≈øe in Chalgrave Field, where Mr. John Hambden recieved his mortal wounds; but in the We≈øt the Parliaments Forces had better ≈øucce≈øs, where they took in the Towns of Taunton and Bridgewater; At this time finding the want of a Great Seal, the Parliament after long debates Voted, That a new Seal ≈øhould be made for Confirmation of their Acts and Ordinances; which was forthwith done, and thereon was Ingraven the Picture of the Hou≈øe of Commons and Members ≈øitting, and on the other ≈øide the Arms of England and
Ireland; but between the Voting and making this Seal, they pa≈ø≈øed this Order, That if the L. Keeper Littleton upon Summons did not return with the great Seal within fourteen dayes, he ≈øhould lo≈øe his Place, and what≈øoever ≈øhould be Sealed therewith by him after that time, ≈øhould be null and void in Law; And pre≈øently after Mr. Hen. Martin a Member of Parliament ≈øeized upon the Regalia which were repo≈øited in We≈øtmin≈øter Abby; telling ≈øome of his Accomplices, That the time would come wherein there would be no need of Crowns and Scepters.

July 5. 1643. Sir Will. Waller meets with Sir Ralph Hopton's Forces at Land≈ødown near Bath, who though fewer than Sir Williams, yet maintained the fight from two in the afternoon till one the next morning; and then Sir Williams Party for≈øook the Field; Hopton him≈øelf was hurt, and lo≈øt divers Gentlemen of note, but the Parliaments lo≈øs was more; Hopton marches to the Devizes in Wilt-≈øhire, and Waller after him; whereupon the King ≈øent 1500 Hor≈øe from Oxford to Hoptons relief; Waller draws off to Roundway Down, and there the Fight began, in which the Parliamentarians were defeated and fled, leaving the Foot to the mercy of their Adver≈øaries, by whom hundreds of them were Slain, and more taken, with four bra≈øs Guns, Ammunition and Baggage, 28 Colours, and 9 Cornets; Waller having thus lo≈øt his Army, po≈øts to London with a few followers for Recruits. This Fight happened July 13.

Some difference ari≈øing in the North between L. Fairfax General for the Parliament, and Sir John Hotham Governour of Hull, who refu≈øed to ≈øubmit to the L. Fairfax; the Parliament de≈øigned to di≈øplace Hotham, which he di≈øcovering by an intercepted Letter, began to project new de≈øigns, and his
Son Capt. Hotham being ≈øu≈øpected by the Parliament was impri≈øoned at Nottingham, but made his e≈øcape and underhand Treated with the E. of Newca≈øtle; Upon which Orders were ≈øent for ≈øeizing both Father and Son, which was done accordingly, together with his wife, and the re≈øt of his Children, who were all ≈øent up Pri≈øoners to the Parliament; and ≈øome Months after Sir John and his Son were brought to Tryal in Guild-hall, the E. of Manche≈øter and others being a≈ø≈øigned their Judges; and the Father is charged, That he had Traiterou≈øly betrayed the Tru≈øt repo≈øed in him by the Parliament, and adhered to the Enemy, as appeared by his Words, by his Letters, and by his Actions, and that he held corre≈øpondence with the Queen, the E. of Newca≈øtle, L. Digby, and others of that Party, and had endeavoured to betray Hull to them. His Son was charged with things of the ≈øame nature; upon which they were both Sentenced to be Beheaded, which was accordingly Executed, the Son Jan. 1. 1644. and the Father, the next day after.

But to return; July 4. 1643. P. Rupert ≈øits down before Bri≈øtoll, and though Coll. Fines had formerly hanged up ≈øome Citizens for intending to have delivered up the Town to the Prince, yet neverthele≈øs the de≈øign took effect, for being at that time very ill provided for re≈øi≈øtance, (which P. Rupert had notice of from his Corre≈øpondents within) the Governour was con≈øtrained after 3 days Siege, to ≈øurrender it to him.

Aug. 12. the E. of Lind≈øey being freed from his impri≈øonment wherein he was ≈øince Edge-hill fight, came to the King at Oxford; and ≈øoon after P. Maurice be≈øieged Exeter, flinging in Granadoes and firing part of the Suburbs, upon which a fruitle≈øs Parley en≈øued; the next day the Prince ma≈øters the Great Sconce,
and turns the great Guns thereon upon the City, and then the Garri≈øon agreed to yield, the Officers only to part with their Swords, and the private Souldiers to march out with Cudgels in their hands. At this time Judge Berkley who had been impri≈øoned by the Parliament about Shipmoney, was fined Twenty thou≈øand pound, made incapable of all Offices, and to continue a Pri≈øoner during plea≈øure.

The Parliament were now bu≈øied for recruiting Sir William Waller's Army, and to incline the Londoners to a more chearfull compliance, Pennington the L. Maior was made Lieutenant of the Tower; yet Waller was forced to ≈øtay becau≈øe E≈ø≈øex his Army wanted likewi≈øe Reinforcement; E≈ø≈øex mu≈øters ten thou≈øand men at Houn≈ølow Heath; but this would not ≈øerve for ≈øo weighty an Affair as the relief of Gloce≈øter, now be≈øieged by the King, and he mu≈øt therefore make u≈øe of the London Trained Bands.

Gloce≈øter was the place which ≈øtopt the current of the Kings ≈øucce≈ø≈øes; Ma≈ø≈øey was Governour thereof, and had with him two Regiments of Foot, and an 100 Hor≈øe, which with ≈øome other Recruits made up 1500 men, with forty Barels of Powder, and a ≈ølender Artillery; yet they within behaved them≈øelves like men of Re≈øolution, and Allarum'd the Be≈øiegers with frequent Sallies; The King plants his Cannon again≈øt the Gates, which made above 150 ≈øhot, and the Granadoes did ≈øome Execution in the Town, yet nothing abated the Spirits of the People. Whereupon the King prepares for a General Storm, and all was ready, they within being in want and having but three Barrels of Powder left, when news comes that E≈ø≈øex was on his March with a powerfull Army to rai≈øe the Siege; whereupon after con≈øultation
had by the King with the General Officers, it was re≈øolved, the Kings Army ≈øhould draw off, which was done, and all their Hutts were ≈øet on fire, and Sept. 5. 1643. E≈ø≈øex enters into Gloce≈øter, and having furni≈øhed the City plentifully with provi≈øions, went after the King, who at that Siege lo≈øt that opportunity of marching up to London (the Parliament having then no con≈øiderable Army in the Field) which he could never regain.

The War had hitherto continued in Ireland, and the Engli≈øh Army had commonly ≈øucce≈øs again≈øt the Rebels, but the King now under≈øtanding the Parliaments contracting with the Scots for aid; thought fit to ≈øtrengthen him≈øelf by recalling part of his Army there, hither; and commi≈ø≈øionated the E. of Ormond his Lieut. General, to agree on a ce≈ø≈øation for a year, which was concluded at Singe≈øton, and Sept. 18. 1643. was proclaimed by the Lords Ju≈øtices and Council at Dublin; and ≈øoon after ≈øome Forces from thence landed in Wales, and took Hawerden Ca≈øtle near Che≈øter for the King.

The E. of E≈ø≈øex having relieved Gloce≈øter, ≈øpeeds after the King, and pa≈ø≈øing by Cirence≈øter left a ≈øtrong Party there, where P. Maurice was expected that night; but in≈øtead of him, comes E≈ø≈øex, and being mi≈øtaken for the other, enters the Town without any Oppo≈øition, ≈øeizes 400 men, and 30 Cart loads of Provi≈øion, and then marches to Newberry where the King was before, and had gotten the advantage of the Ground, and planted his Ordnance; Early in the morning, Sept. 20. 1643. E≈ø≈øex views the Kings Army, and in Newberry Common draws up his own, and falls to firing, the Kings Army doing the like; That part of the Army which P. Rupert charged, being overlay'd, were forced to fall off on the Right hand, where two Great
Bodies of Hor≈øe marched down the Hill, and fell in furiou≈øly upon the Prince; both ≈øides acting with great valour and fury, and coming to handy-≈øtrokes with their Swords.

The E≈ø≈øexians then wheeling about charged the L. Jermins Regiment, whom they forced to make their e≈øcape through ≈øome Bodies of Foot; this Battel cau≈øed great lo≈øs and blood≈øhed on either ≈øide, but greater on the Kings, who≈øe other Bodies of Hor≈øe commanded by the Earls of Carnarvan, and Northampton, notwith≈øtanding the great courage of their Commanders were overpowered, and the Earls of Carnarvan and Sunderland, Vi≈øcount Falkland and many other Officers and Gentlemen ≈ølain; The London Trained Bunds and Auxiliaries did the Parliament great ≈øervice in this Fight; Night coming on, both Armies retired, and next day marched away from each other.

After this, ≈øeveral Places were Garri≈øoned for the King by Sir William Vava≈øor, as Tewksbury, Shudley Ca≈øtle and other places in Gloce≈øter-≈øhire, and ≈øoon after Waller again ≈øurpri≈øeth Tewksbury, but is afterward beaten by P. Maurice. Ma≈ø≈øey and Waller take Hereford, and Sir William Brereton had the Town and Ca≈øtle of Eccle≈øhall delivered upon rea≈øonable Quarter. An Ordinance is now publi≈øhed by the Parlirment to ≈øeize upon the Kings Revenue; And Sir William Waller is made Major General of Hamp≈øhire, Su≈ø≈øex, Surrey, and Kent, and marching to Farnham beat a Party of the Kings Army, and then took Aulton and Arundell, Ca≈øile; Collonel Nerton was routed by Hopton; and the Paliament finding the Kings Power increa≈øe, they publi≈øh, That whoever ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt the King with Hor≈øe, Arms, Plate or Money again≈øt them, are Traytors to the Paliament, and ≈øhall be ≈øo preceeded again≈øt. The King ≈øummons
a Parliament at Oxford, Jan. 22. 1643. where in the great Hall at Chri≈øt-Church he tell; them, That if he had the lea≈øt Thoughts of di≈øagreeing with the happine≈øs of this Kingdom, he would not advi≈øe with ≈øuch Councellors as they were; And ≈øo the upper Schools were a≈ø≈øigned to the Lords, and the Convocation Hou≈øe to the Commons. In this Parliament, be≈øides the Prince, D. of York, L. Keeper Littleton, Trea≈øurer Cottington, D. of Richmond, and Marque≈øs of Hartford, there were 19 Earls and as many Lords, and 117 Knights and Gentlemen, and afterwards 5 Lords and 23 Gentlemen more came to them; The fir≈øt thing they fell upon, was to con≈øider of means for effecting a Peace, to which end a Letter was written to the E. of E≈ø≈øex, and ≈øub≈øigned by all their hands, who returned no an≈øwer, but ≈øent it to the Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter.

Jan. 16. 1643. The Scots Army entred England by the way of Newca≈øtle, being 18000 Foot, and 2000 Hor≈øe, under Gen. Levens; For a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Parliament in pur≈øuance of the Solemn League and Covenant, and declaring the Ju≈øtne≈øs of their Cau≈øe, which they profe≈øs to be Reformation of Religion, Honour of the King, and Peace of the Kingdoms; and that the main end of their coming is to re≈øcue the King from his pernicious Coun≈øellors. The Parliament care≈ø≈øe the Scots Army, and impower them to a≈ø≈øe≈øs for them≈øelves the Twentieth part of all Malignants E≈øtates (as they called them) in the North, be≈øides what other Counties were a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed for them. But the E. of Newca≈øtle is marching to give them rougher entertainment, and the L. Fairfax ≈øent his Son Sir Thomas again≈øt him.

Sir John M ‚Ä¢ ldrum with 700 men be≈øieged Newarks and is blockt up by Prince Rupert, whereupon
they parleyed, and upon Articles were ≈øuffered to march away, leaving their Match, Bullet, Powder, Cannon and all other Fire-Arms behind them. In the mean time Matters are preparing for Scotland by James Marqu≈øs of Montro's who had formerly ≈øided with the Covenanters, but now the King under≈øtanding he had really for≈øaken them, gives him a Commi≈ø≈øion to be General Governor of Scotland, and orders him Forces to go into the heart of that Kingdom, for a diver≈øion to the Scots.

In the year 1644. the Twentieth of his Maje≈øties Reign, Sir. Will. Waller defeats the L. Hoptons Forces and takes Winche≈øter, and Oliver Cromwell was made Governor of Ely; Beudly is ≈øurprized by Coll. Fox for the Parliament, and the Garri≈øons of Selby and Heintough are taken by the L. Fairfax and his Son, Prince Rupert rai≈øeth the ≈øiege at Latham Hou≈øe. The King at this time in the pre≈øence of the Peers at Oxford received the Sacrament at Chri≈øts Church at the hands of Bi≈øhop ∆≤≈øher, where he u≈øed the≈øe ≈øolemn Prote≈øtations:

My Lords, I e≈øpy here many re≈øolved Prote≈øtants, who declare to the world the Re≈øolution I do now make; I have to the utmo≈øt of my power prepared my Soul to become a worthy Receiver, and may I ≈øo receive comfort by the Ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament, as I do intend the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the True Reformed Prote≈øtant Religion, as it ≈øtood in its beauty in the happy days of Q. Elizabeth, without any connivance at Popery; I ble≈øs God that in the mid≈øt of the≈øe Publick Di≈øtractions I have ≈øtill Liberty to communicate, and may this Sacrament be my damnation if my heart do not joyn with my lips in this Prote≈øtation.

The Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter Voted it Trea≈øon for any Member, or Member of either Hou≈øe to de≈øert them, and to go to the King, and they never to be received
again. The King marcheth out of Oxford, and i ‚Ä¢ followed by E≈ø≈øex and Waller, he defeats Waller at Cropredy-Bridge, and E≈ø≈øex is blockt up by the Kings Forces in Cornwall, and July 4th. the King ≈øends ≈øeveral Letters to the Parliament about a Treaty of Peace. Sept. 12. the Parliament at Oxford A≈ø≈øemble again but falling into Factions and Divi≈øions the King in March following Di≈ø≈øolves them.

The Earl of Newca≈øtle was be≈øieged in York about two months, to who≈øe relief Prince Rupert advanceth Northward with a great Power of Hor≈øe and Foot, upon who≈øe approach to the City the Be≈øeigers drew off, and tho≈øe within ≈øally out upon their Rear; the E. of Newca≈øtle being thus relieved, joyns with P. Rupert, re≈øolving to follow the Parliamentarians and give them battle, which accordingly they did upon a Plain called Mar≈øton-Moor, where about 9000 men were ≈ølain, for the Royali≈øts having near routed the Parliaments Army, pur≈øued the Chace ≈øo far, that the Victory was ≈ønatcht out of their hands, and the Parliament obtained an entire Victory, after 3 hours Fight re≈øolutely maintained on both ≈øides: After which York was delivered up to the Parliament, and they ≈øoon became Ma≈øters of all the North, and Levens the Scotch General takes Newca≈øtle; After, this Battel which was the greate≈øt both for the fiercene≈øs of it, and for the number of Souldiers on both ≈øides, P. Rupert goes into Lanca≈øhire, but the E. of Newea≈øtle lately made Marque≈øs, with his two Sons, and his brother Sir Charles Cavendi≈øh, General King, the Lord Falconbridge, the Lord Widdrington, the Earl of Cranworth, the Bi≈øhop of London-derry, Sir Edward Widdrington, Coll. Carnaby, Col. Ba≈ø≈øet, Col. Mou≈øon, Sir. William Vava≈øor, Sir Francis Mackworth with about eighty other per≈øons, upon ≈øome di≈øcontent, refu≈øed
to engage any further in the Kings Cau≈øe, and went over to Hamburgh.

New Levies are now made by the Parliament and „Äà‚óä„Äâ Attempts were made by the Parliamentarians upon Dennington Ca≈øtle, but in vain; The Queen go
‚Ä¢ ng from Oxford to Exeter was there delivered of a daughter, June 16 1644. who was called Henrietta Maria, and afterward went from thence to Penden
‚Ä¢ is, Ca≈øtle in Cornwall where ≈øhe embarqued for France, and did not return again to England, till His pre≈øent Maje≈øties Happy Re≈øtoration in 1660. Banbury Ca≈øtle is relieved by Sir William Compton, having been be≈øieged about 11 weeks by the Par
‚Ä¢ iamens Forces; Coll. Myn is defeated by Ma≈ø≈øy near Gloce≈øter, and him≈øelf ≈ølain, and about 170 Officers and Souldiers taken Pri≈øoners; Prince Rupert ≈øending 500 Hor≈øe and Foot to fortifie Beachly, in order to his going to A≈øhferry, they are routed by Ma≈ø≈øey, who ≈øoon after takes Monmouth Town.

Newberry ≈øeemed to be a Place de≈øtined for Martial exploits, for October 27. another great Battel was fought there, between the Kings party and the Parliaments, under E≈ø≈øex, Waller, and Manche≈øter, wherein the Royali≈øts were wor≈øted, and between 4 and 5000 men ≈ølain on both ≈øides; Novemb. 19. Monmouth is retaken by the Kings Forces; December. 23. Sir. Alexander Carew was beheaded for endeavouring to deliver up the I≈øland of Plymouth to the Kings Forces.

Two Principal Iri≈øh Rebels, the L. Macguire, and Mac-mahon had been ≈øent from Ireland, and impri≈øoned in the Tower, from whence they made their e≈øcape, but being retaken, and Tryed, were found guilty of High Trea≈øon, and were both Drawn, Hang'd and Quartered at Tyburn, though Macguire pleaded his Priviledge to the Lords, as a Peer of Ireland.

Archbi≈øhop Laud having been accu≈øed by th ‚Ä¢ Parliament in 1640. as the framer of the Canons „Äà‚óä„Äâ Convocation, and other Delinquencies, and th ‚Ä¢
Scots joyning him and the E. of Strafford in the Grand Accu≈øation, charging him for obtruding th ‚Ä¢
Common Prayer Book, and Canons and Con≈øtitution Eccle≈øia≈øtical upon their Nation, and for advi≈øing th ‚Ä¢ King to di≈ø≈øolve the la≈øt Parliament, and other ≈øu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ matters, upon which he was fir≈øt committed to th ‚Ä¢ black Rod, and 10 weeks after Voted Guilty of Hig ‚Ä¢ Trea≈øon, and ≈øent to the Tower, where he continue ‚Ä¢ 4 years; his Charge was, endeavouring the ≈øubver≈øi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
1. Of the Lawes, 2. Of Religion, 3. Of the Priviledg ‚Ä¢ of Parliament; And after many times attending on th ‚Ä¢ Hou≈øe, Jan. 4. 1644. they pa≈ø≈øed their Ordinance o ‚Ä¢ Parliament. That he ≈øhould be drawn, hang'd and quartered; but upon his Petition, They voted him to be beheaded, which he ≈øuffered Jan. 10. after.

Jan. 30. a Treaty was begun at ∆≤xbridge between the King and Parliament, but took no effect: Ba≈øing Hou≈øe was relieved by the Kings Forces, again≈øt which Sir William Waller had lo≈øt above 1000 men; About this time the E. of E≈ø≈øex was ca≈øhiered ou ‚Ä¢ of his Command, and Sir. Tho. Fairfax was Voted General of the Parliaments Forces; Col. Ro≈ø≈øiter wa ‚Ä¢ defeated by Sir Marm. Langdale and the Kings party.

In April 1645. Collonel Ma≈ø≈øey defeated by Prince Rupert at Ledbury, and Blechington Hou≈øe delivered to the Parliament. In May, Oxford was be≈øieged the fir≈øt time, and Leice≈øter taken by the King: In June, Leice≈øter regained by the Parliament; Carli≈øle after 41 weeks ≈øiege deliver'd by Sir T. Glenham to the Scots.

June 14. 1645. was fought that unfortunate Battell at Na≈øeby, which proved ≈øo fatal to the King and his Cau≈øe: This fight was exceeding bloody, both Armies being very couragious and numerous, there
not being above 500 odds: On the Parliaments ≈øide ‚Ä¢ ere ≈ølain and wounded above 1000 Officers and ‚Ä¢ rivate Souldiers; but much more was the lo≈øs on „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Kings ≈øide, there being taken 6 Collonels, 8 ‚Ä¢ ieutenant Collonels, 18 Majors, 70 Captains, 8 Lieu
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nants, 200 Enfigns and other inferior Officers, 4500 ‚Ä¢ ommon Souldiers, many Women, 13 of the Kings ‚Ä¢ ou≈øhold Servants, 4 Footmen, 12 pieces of Ordinance, ‚Ä¢ 000 Arms, 48 Barrels of Powder, 200 Carriages, all ‚Ä¢ heir Bag and Baggage, with ≈øtore of rich Pillage, ‚Ä¢ 000 Hor≈øe, the Kings Standard, and one of his ‚Ä¢ oaches, and his Cabinet of Letters and Papers, which were afterwards publi≈øhed, ≈øo that it proved a com
‚Ä¢ leat Victory to the Parliamentarians.

In July, the Kings Forces were defeated at Lang
‚Ä¢ ort, about 200 ≈ølain, and 1400 Pri≈øoners: Pomfret Ca≈øtle, Bridgwater, Scarborough, and Bath, deliver
‚Ä¢ d to the Parliament. In Augu≈øt, Sherburn Ca≈øtle ta
‚Ä¢ en by the Parliament: In Sept. Bri≈øtoll ≈øurrendred ‚Ä¢ o them, and the Kings Forces wor≈øted at Routon Heath: In October, Ba≈øing-Hou≈øe taken by Cromwell,
‚Ä¢ nd L. Digby defeated in York-≈øhire; in Decemb. La
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ am Hou≈øe delivered by the Kings Order, and Here
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rd ≈øurpriz'd by the Parliament, before which ‚Ä¢ lace the Scots in Augu≈øt had lo≈øt about 1000 men: ‚Ä¢ n March, L. A≈øhly defeated near Stow.

In April, 1646. Ruthen Ca≈øtle Exeter, St. Micha
‚Ä¢ ls Mount, Dun≈øter Ca≈øtle, and Wood≈øtock yielded; Corf Ca≈øtle taken by Stratagem: Sir Tho. Fairfax re≈øolves ‚Ä¢ o march to Oxford, which put the King upon thoughts of providing for his own ≈øafety, and therefore April,
‚Ä¢ 3. he goes out of Oxford in Di≈øgui≈øe with Mr. Hud
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
a Mini≈øter, and Mr. John A≈øhburnham, who≈øe Ser
‚Ä¢ ant he per≈øonated, and went to the Scots Army at Newark. In May, Oxford was be≈øieged, and Banbury
‚Ä¢ nd Radnor ≈øurrendred to the Parliament. In June,
Litchfield, Worce≈øter, Wallingford Ca≈øtle, Bor≈øtall, Oxford, and Farringdon, and yielded to the Parliament: In July, Gothridge and Pendennis the like, and Conway taken by Storm: In Augu≈øt, Ragland ≈øurrendred by the Marque≈øs of Worce≈øter; In September, Scilly I≈øland and Ca≈øtle taken, Denbigh Ca≈øtle al≈øo yielded. In Novemb. Gen. Fairfax marched Triumphantly into London. In February, the Scotch Army having fir≈øt ≈øold the King for two hundred thou≈øand Pound, marched into Scotland, and the King was ≈øent Pri≈øoner to Holmby by the Parliament.

The King being now in the power of his Enemies, they remove him from place to place, and at length into the I≈øle of Wight, under the Guard of Coll. H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
mond; and afterwards a Treaty of Peace was there begun, wherein things were ≈øo managed, that his Maje≈øties Conce≈ø≈øions were Voted ≈øatisfactory: After which the Army and ≈øome part of the Parliament driving on an Intere≈øt contrary to Peace, turned all ≈øuch Members out of the Hou≈øe of Commons as they thought would not comply with their De≈øigns; and then conveyed the King to Wind≈øor: During which time there happened ≈øeveral Bickerings and Ingagements between the Royali≈øts and the Parliamentarians; the Royal Party being in all places defeated, e≈øpecially at Maid≈øtone, Pontefract, Bow, Stratford, King≈øton and Pre≈øton, (where the Scotch Army received a very great Overthrow, lo≈øing abundance of men:) And la≈øtly at Colche≈øter, where tho≈øe two gallant Gentlemen, Sir Ch. Lucas and Sir George Li≈øle were ≈øhot to death after quarter given, contrary to the Law of Arms.

After this, the Officers of the Army, and tho≈øe Members then left in the Hou≈øe, proceeded to that height as to pre≈øume to bring the King to Tryal; which becau≈øe it was an unparallel'd Action, it may be nece≈øtary to give a more particular Account thereof.

figure.head: The Martyrdom of King Charles 1648

div.p: Upon the fourth of January, 1648. the Hou≈øe of Commons being turned into a Grand Committee, pa≈ø≈øed the≈øe following Votes. 1. That the People under God are the Original of all ju≈øt Power. 2. That the Commons of England A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, being cho≈øen by, and repre≈øenting the People, have the Supream Authority of the Nation. 3. That what≈øoever is Enacted and Declared for Law by the Commons of England A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, hath the force of a Law. 4. That all the People of the Nation are included thereby; although the con≈øent, and concurrence of the Hou≈øe of Peers be not had thereunto. 5. That to rai≈øe Arms again≈øt the Peoples Repre≈øentative or Parliament, and to make War upon them, is High Trea≈øon. 6. That the King him≈øelf took Arms again≈øt the Parliament, and upon that account is guilty of the Blood-≈øhed throughout the Civil War; and that he ought to explate the Crime with his own Blood.

After this they proceeded to make a pretended Act for the Tryal of the King, which they ‚Ä¢ ntituled, An Act of the Commons of England A≈ø≈øem
‚Ä¢ led in Parliament, for erecting of an High Court of ‚Ä¢ u≈øtice for the Trying and Judging of CHARLES STUART King of England: which was in the ‚Ä¢ orm following.

body.p:
WHereas it is notorious, That Charles Stuart the now King of England, not content with tho≈øe many incroachments which his Predece≈ø≈øors had made upon the People in their Rights and Freedoms, hath had a wicked de≈øign totally to ≈øubvert the ancient and fundamental Laws and Liberty of the Nation: And in their place, to introduce an Arbitrary and Tyrannical Government, with fire and ≈øword levyed and maintained a cruel War in the
Land, again≈øt the Parliament and Kingdom; Whereby the Countrey hath been mi≈øerably wa≈øted, the publick Trea≈øury exhau≈øted, Trade decayed, and thou≈øands of People murthered, and infinite of other mi≈øchiefs committed; For all which High and Trea≈øonable Offences, the ≈øaid Charles Stuart might long ≈øince ju≈øtly have been brought to exemplary and condign puni≈øhment: Whereas al≈øo the Parliament, well hoping that the re≈øtraint and impri≈øonment of his Per≈øon, (after it had plea≈øed God to deliver him into their hands) would have quieted the di≈øturbers of the Kingdom, did forbear to proceed judicially again≈øt him: But found by ≈øad experience, that ≈øuch their remi≈ø≈øives ≈øerved only to encourage him and his Complices, in the Continuance of their evil practices, and in rai≈øing of new Commotions, De≈øigns, and Inva≈øions; For prevention therefore of the like greater inconveniencies, and to the end that no Magi≈øtrate or Officer what≈øoever, may hereafter pre≈øume traiterou≈øly and malitiou≈øly to imagine or contrive the in≈ølaving or de≈øtroying of the Engli≈øh Nation, and to expect impunity in ≈øo doing:

Be it Ordained and Enacted by the Commons is Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, and it is hereby Ordained and enacted by the Authority thereof: That Thomas L. F. O. C. &c. ‚Äî ≈øhall be, and are hereby appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners and Judges, for the Hearing, Trying, and Judging of the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, and the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners or any Twenty or more of them, ≈øhall be, and are hereby authorized and Con≈øtituted an High Court of Ju≈øtice, to meet at ≈øuch convenient times and places, as by the ≈øaid Commi≈ø≈øioners, or the major part, or twenty or more of them, under their Hands and Seals ≈øhall be appointed and notified by publick Proclamation in the great Hall or Palace-yard of We≈øtmin≈øter; and adjourn
from time to time, and from Place to place, as the ≈øaid High Court, or the major part thereof meeting ≈øhould hold fit, and to take Order for charging of him the ≈øaid Charles Stuart with the Crimes above-mentioned, and for the receiving his Per≈øonal An≈øwer thereunto, and for Examination of Witne≈ø≈øes upon Oath (if need be) concerning the ≈øame; and thereupon, or in default of ≈øuch An≈øwer, to proceed to final Sentence according to Ju≈øtice, and the merit of the Cau≈øe, and to be Executed ≈øpeedily and Impartially, &c.

div.p: Pre≈øently after this was publi≈øhed, Proclamation was made, That tho≈øe who had any thing to ≈øay again≈øt the King, ≈øhould have a hearing given them: This was proclamed fir≈øt in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, by the Serjeant at Arms to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, Riding into the Hall with his Mace, attended with ≈øix Trumpeters and other Officers, who likewi≈øe rode bare into the Hall with him, the Drums of the Guard beating in the mean time without in the Palace-yard. And the day after Proclamation was made to the ≈øame effect in Cheap≈øide, and at the Old-Exchange: And in order to this grand Tryal, Hillary Term which u≈øually begins Jan. 23. was adjourned for fourteen dayes; The Hou≈øe of Lords, refu≈øing to concur with the Commons in their Ordinance for the Kings Tryal, the Commons re≈øolve and Vote, That all Members and others appointed to Act in any Ordinance, are impowered and enjoyned to Sit, Act, and Execute, notwith≈øtanding the Hou≈øe of Peers joyn not with them.

And now the Mini≈øters in general, and the Presbyterians likewi≈øe, who had been active again≈øt the Kings Cau≈øe, declare them≈øelves both in their
Pulpits, and by earne≈øt Petitions to the Parliament, to be zealous abhorrers of the Kings death, and every where publickly prote≈øt again≈øt this Tryal; The Nobility likewi≈øe offer them≈øelves Pledges on the Kings behalf; and the People univer≈øally ≈øeem greatly troubled and a≈øtoni≈øht: Notwith≈øtanding all which the Hou≈øe of Commons and the Army went de≈øperately on, and a New and Illegal Tribunal called An High Court of Ju≈øtice was erected, the Commi≈ø≈øioners whereof met in the Painted Chamber to con≈øult what cour≈øe to take about the Tryal of the King.

Fryday Jan. 19. 1648. The King was brought with a ≈øtrong Guard of Hor≈øe from Wind≈øor to St. James's; and the next day Serjeant Brad≈øhaw Pre≈øident of the pretended High Court of Ju≈øtice, with about ≈øeventy of the Members of the ≈øaid Court, having Coll. Fox and ≈øixteen Gentlemen with Partizans, and a Sword born by Coll. Humphrey, and a Mace by Serj. Dandy, with their and other Officers of the faid Court marching before them, came to the place ordered to be prepared for their ≈øitting, at the We≈øt end of the Great Hall in We≈øtmin≈øter; where the Lord Pre≈øident in a Crim≈øon Velvet Chair, fixed in the mid≈øt of the Court, placed him≈øelf having a Desk with a Crim≈øon Velvet Cu≈øhion before him: The re≈øt of the Members placing them≈øelves on each ≈øide of him, upon the ≈øeveral Seats or Benches prepared and hung with Scarlet for that purpo≈øe, and the Partizans dividing them≈øelves on each ≈øide of the Court before them.

The Court being thus ≈øet, and ≈øilence made, the great Gate of the ≈øaid Hall was ≈øet open, to the end, That all per≈øons, without exception, de≈øirous to ≈øee, or hear, might come into it;
upon which the Hall was pre≈øently filled, and Silence again ordered.

This done, Colonel Thomlin≈øon, who had the charge of the King, as a Pri≈øoner, was commanded to bring him to the Court, who within a quarter of an hours ≈øpace brought him attended with about twenty Officers with Partizans marching before him, there being Coll. Hacker and other Gentlemen, to who≈øe care and Cu≈øtody he was likewi≈øe committed, marching in his Rear.

Being thus brought up within the face of the Court, the Serjeant at Arms, with his Mace, receives and conducts him ≈øtreight to the Bar, where a Crim≈øon Velvet Chair was ≈øet for the King. After a ≈øtern looking upon the Court, and the people in the Galleries on each ≈øide of him, he places him≈øelf, not at all moving his Hat, or otherwi≈øe ≈øhewing the lea≈øt re≈øpect to the Court, but pre≈øently ri≈øes up again, and turns about looking downwards upon the Guards placed on the left ≈øide, and on the multitude of Spectators on the right ≈øide of the ≈øaid great Hall. After Silence made among the people, the Act of Parliament for the Trying of CHARLES ST∆≤ART King of England, was read over by the Clerk of the Court; who ≈øate on one ≈øide of the Table covered with a rich Turkey Carpet, and placed at the feet of the ≈øaid Lord Pre≈øident, upon which Table was al≈øo laid the Sword and Mace.
