After reading the ≈øaid Act, the ≈øeveral Names of the Commi≈ø≈øioners were called over, every one who was pre≈øent, ri≈øing up, and an≈øwering to his Call.

The King having again placed him≈øelf in his Chair, with his face towards the Court, Silence
being again ordered, the Lord Pre≈øident ≈øtood up and ≈øaid:

Pre≈øident. CHARLES ST∆≤ART, King of England; The Commons of England A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, being deeply ≈øen≈øible of the Calamities that have been brought upon this Nation, (which is fixed upon you, as the Principal Author of them) have re≈øolved to make inqui≈øition for Blood, and according to that Debt and Duty they owe to Ju≈øtice, to God, the Kingdom, and them≈øelves, and according to the Fundamental Power that re≈øts in them≈øelves, They have re≈øolved to bring you to Tryal and Judgment; and for that purpo≈øe have con≈øtituted this High Court of Ju≈øtice, before which you are brought.

This ≈øaid, Mr. Cook Solicitor General for the Common-wealth (≈øtanding within a Bar on the right hand of the King) offered to ≈øpeak; but the King having a Staff in his hand, held it up, and laid it upon the ≈øaid Mr. Cooks ≈øhoulder two or three times, bidding him hold: Neverthele≈øs, the Lord Pre≈øident ordering him to go on, he ≈øaid:
Cook. My Lord, I am commanded to charge Charles Stuart, King of England, in the name of the Commons of England, with Trea≈øon and high Mi≈ødemeanours; I de≈øire the ≈øaid Charge may be read.

The ≈øaid Charge being delivered to the Clerk of the Court, the Lord Pre≈øident ordered it ≈øhould be read, but the King bid him hold; Neverthele≈øs, being commanded by the Lord Pre≈øident to read it, the Clerk begun.

body.head: The Charge of the Commons of England again≈øt CHARLES STUART King of England, of High Trea≈øon, and other High Crimes, exhibited to the High Court of Ju≈øtice.
body.p: THat the ≈øaid Charles Stuart being admitted King of England, and therein tru≈øted with a Limited Power, to govern by, and according to the Laws of the Land, and not otherwi≈øe; And by his Tru≈øt, Oath, and Office, being obliged to u≈øe the power committed to him, for the good and benefit of the people, and for the pre≈øervation of their Rights and Liberties; Yet neverthele≈øs, out of a wicked de≈øign to erect, and uphold in him≈øelf an unlimited and Tyrannical Power, to rule according to his Will, and to overthrow the Rights and Liberties of the People; Yea, to take away, and make void the Foundations thereof, and of all redre≈øs and remedy of mi≈øgovernment, which by the fundamental Con≈øtitutions of this Kingdom, were re≈øerved on the Peoples behalf, in the Right and Power of frequent and ≈øucce≈ø≈øive Parliaments, or National meetings in Councel; He, the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, for accompli≈øhment of ≈øuch his De≈øigns, and for the protecting of him≈øelf and his Adherents, in His and their wicked practices to the ≈øame end, hath traiterou≈øly and maliciou≈øly levied War again≈øt the pre≈øent Parliament, and the people therein repre≈øented.

Particularly, upon or about the thirtieth day of June, in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand
≈øix hundred forty and two, at Beverly in the Count, of York; And upon or about the thirtieth day of July, in the year afore≈øaid, in the County of the City of York; and upon, or about the twenty fourth day of Augu≈øt, in the ≈øame year, at the County of the Town of Nottingham, (when, and where he ≈øet up his Standard of War,) and upon, or about the twenty third day of October, in the ≈øame year, at Edge-Hill, and Keinton-field, in the County of Warwick; And upon or about the thirtieth day of Nov. in the ≈øame year, at Brainford in the County of Middle≈øex: And upon, or about the thirtieth day of Aug. in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and three at Cave≈øhambridge neer Reding, in the County of Berks: And upon, or about the thirtieth day of October, in the year la≈øt mentioned, at, or near the City of Gloce≈øter; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of November, in the year la≈øt mentioned, at Newberry, in the County of Berks; and upon; or about the one and thirtieth day of July; in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and four, at Cropredy-bridge, in the County of Oxon; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of September, in the la≈øt year mentioned, at Bodmin, and other places near adjacent, in the County of Cornwall; And upon, or about the thirtieth day of November, in the la≈øt year mentioned, at Newberry afore≈øaid: And upon or about the Eighth of June, in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and five, at the Town of Leice≈øter; and al≈øo upon the fourteenth day of the ≈øame month; in the ≈øame year, at Na≈øeby-field, in the County of Northampton. At which ≈øeveral times and places,
or mo≈øt of them, and at many other places in this Land, at ≈øeveral other times, within the years aforementioned: And in the year of our Lord, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and ≈øix: He the ≈øaid Ch. Stuart, hath cau≈øed and procured many thou≈øands of the Free-people of the Nation to be ≈ølain; and by Divi≈øions, parties, and in≈øurrections, within this Land, by Inva≈øions from Foreign parts, endeavoured and procured by him, and by many other evil wayes and means; He the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, hath not onely maintained and carried on the ≈øaid War, both by Land and Sea, during the years before mentioned; but al≈øo hath renewed, or cau≈øed to be renewed, the ≈øaid War again≈øt the Parliament, and good people of this Nation, in this pre≈øent year, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty and eight, in the Counties of Kent, E≈ø≈øex, Surrey, Su≈ø≈øex, Middle≈øex, and many other Counties and places in England and Wales, and al≈øo by Sea: and particularly, He the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, hath for that purpo≈øe, given Commi≈ø≈øion to his Son, the Prince and others; whereby, be≈øides multitudes of other per≈øons, many ≈øuch, as were by the Parliament intru≈øted and imployed for the ≈øafety of the Nation, being by Him or His Agents, Corrupted, to the betraying of Their Tru≈øt, and revolting from the Parliament, have had entertainment and Commi≈ø≈øion, for the continuing and the renewing of War and Ho≈øtility, again≈øt the ≈øaid Parliament and people, as afore≈øaid. By which cruel and unnatural Wars by Him the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, levyed, continued, and renewed, as afore≈øaid, much Innocent Blood of the Free-People of this Nation hath been ≈øpilt, many Familie have been undone, the publick
Trea≈øury wa≈øted and exhau≈øted, Trade ob≈øtructed, and mi≈øerably decayed; va≈øt expence, and damage to the Nation incurred, and many parts of the Land ≈øpoyled, ≈øome of them even to de≈øolation.

And for further pro≈øecution of his ≈øaid evil De≈øigns, He, the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, doth ≈øtill continue his Commi≈ø≈øions to the ≈øaid Prince, and other Rebels and Revolters, both Engli≈øh and Forreigners, and to the Earl of Ormond, and to the Iri≈øh Rebels and Revolters a≈ø≈øociated with him: from whom further Inva≈øions upon this Land are threatned, upon the procurement and on the behalf of the ≈øaid Charles Stuart.

All which wicked De≈øigns, Wars, and evil practices of him the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, have been, and are carried on, for the advancing and upholding of the per≈øonal Intere≈øt of Will and Power, and pretended Prerogative to Him≈øelf and his Family, again≈øt the publick Intere≈øt, Common Right, Liberty, Ju≈øtice, and Peace of the people of this Nation, by, and for whom he was entru≈øted, as afore≈øaid.

By all which it appeareth, that he the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, hath been, and is the Occa≈øioner, Author, and Contriver of the ≈øaid Unnatural, Cruel and Bloody Wars, and therein guilty of all the Trea≈øons, Murthers Rapines, Burnings, Spoils, De≈øolations, Damage and Mi≈øchief to this Nation acted or committed in the ≈øaid Wars, or occa≈øioned thereby.

And the ≈øaid John Cook, by prote≈øtation (≈øaving on the behalf of the people of England, the liberty of exhibiting at any time hereafter any other Charge again≈øt the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, and al≈øo of replying to the An≈øwers which the
≈øaid Ch. Stuart ≈øhall make to the Premi≈øes, or any of them, or any other Charge that ≈øhall be ≈øo Exhibited) doth for the ≈øaid Trea≈øons and Crimes, on the behalf of the ≈øaid people of England, Impeach the ≈øaid Charles Stuart as a Tyrant, Traitor, Murtherer, and a publick and implacable Enemy to the Common-wealth of England: And pray, that the ≈øaid CHARLES ST∆≤ART, King of England, may be put to an≈øwer All, and Every the Premi≈øes; That ≈øuch Proceedings, Examinations, Trials, Sentence, and Judgment may be thereupon had, as ≈øhall be agreeable to Ju≈øtice.

div.p: IT is ob≈øerved, that the time the Charge was reading, the King ≈øate down in his Chair, looking ≈øometimes on the Court, ≈øometimes up to the Galleries, and having ri≈øen again, and turned about to behold the Guards and Spectators, ≈øate down, looking very ≈øternly, with a countenance not at all moved, till the≈øe words, viz. Charles Stuart (to be a Tyrant and Traitor, &c.) were read, at which he laughed as he ≈øate in the face of the Court.
Charge being read, the Lord Pre≈øident replyed,

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you have now heard your Charge read, containing ≈øuch matters as appear in it; you find, That in the clo≈øe of it, it is prayed to the Court, in the behalf of the Commons of England, that you an≈øwer to your Charge. The Court expects your An≈øwer.

p.q:
I would know by what Power I am called hither? I was, not long ago, in the I≈øle of Wight, how I came there, is a longer ≈øtory than I think is fit at this time for me to ≈øpeak of; but there I entred into a Treaty with both Hou≈øes of Parliament,, with as much publick Faith as 'tis po≈ø≈øible to be had of any people in the world. I treated there with a number of Honourable Lords and Gentlemen, and treated hone≈øtly and
uprightly; I cannot ≈øay but they did very nobly with me, we were upon a conclu≈øion of the Treaty. Now I would know by what Authority, I mean, lawful; there are many unlawful Authorities in the world, Thieves and Robbers by the high wayes; but I would know by what Authority I was brought from thence, and carried from place to place, (and I know not what;) and when I know by what lawful Authority, I ≈øhall an≈øwer: Remember I am your King, and what ≈øins you bring upon your heads, and the Judgment of God upon this Land, think well upon it, I ≈øay, think well upon it, before you go further from one ≈øinto a greater, therefore let me know by what lawful Authority I am ≈øeated here, and I ≈øhall not be unwilling to an≈øwer; in the mean time I ≈øhall not betray my Tru≈øt. I have a Tru≈øt committed to me by God, by old and lawful De≈øcent, I will not betray it to an≈øwer to a new unlawful Authority, therefore re≈øolve me that, and you ≈øhall hear more of me.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: If you had been plea≈øed to have ob≈øerved what was hinted to you, by the Court, at your fir≈øt coming hither, you would have known, by what Authority; which Authority, requires you, in the name of the people of England, of which you are Elected King, to an≈øwer them.

p.q: No Sir, I deny that.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: If you acknowledge not the Authority of the Court, they mu≈øt proceed.

p.q:
I do tell them ≈øo, England was never an Elective Kingdom, but an Hereditary Kingdom for neer the≈øe thou≈øand years, therefore let me know by what Authority I am called hither: I do ≈øtand more for the Liberty of my people than any here that come to be my pretended Judges; and therefore
let me know by what lawful Authority I am ≈øeated here, and I will an≈øwer it, otherwi≈øe I will not an≈øwer it.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, how really you have managed your Tru≈øt, is known: your way of an≈øwer is to interrogate the Court, which be≈øeems not you in this condition. You have been told of it twice or thrice.

p.q: Here is a Gentleman, (Lieut. Col. Cobbet) ask him, if he did not bring me from the I≈øle of Wight by force? I do not come here as ≈øubmitting to the Court; I will ≈øtand as much for the Priviledge of the Hou≈øe of Commons, rightly under≈øtood, as any man here what≈øoever. I ≈øee no Hou≈øe of Lords here that may con≈øtitute a Parliament, and (the King too) ≈øhould have been. Is this the bringing of the King to his Parliament? Is this the bringing an end to the Treaty in the publick Faith of the world? Let me ≈øee a legal Authority warranted by the Word of God, the Scriptures, or warranted by the Con≈øtitutions of the Kingdom, and I will an≈øwer.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir. You have propounded a Que≈øtion, and have been an≈øwered: ≈øeeing you will not an≈øwer, the Court will con≈øider how to proceed; in the mean time, tho≈øe that brought you hither, are to take charge of you back again.
The Court de≈øires to know whether this be all the An≈øwer you will give, or no?

p.q:
Sir, I de≈øire that you would give me, and all the world, ≈øatisfaction in this; let me tell you; it is not a ≈ølight thing you are about. I am ≈øworn to keep the Peace by that duty I owe to God and my Country, and I will do it to the la≈øt breath of my body, and therefore you ≈øhall do well to ≈øatifie fir≈øt God, and then the Country, by what Authority
you do it; if you do it by a u≈øurped Authority, that will not la≈øt long. There is a God in Heaven that will call you, and all that give you power, to account: Satisfie me in that, and I will an≈øwer, otherwi≈øe I betray my tru≈øt, and the Liberties of the People, and therefore think of that, and then I ≈øhall be willing. For I do avow, that it is as great a ≈øin to with≈øtand lawful Authority, as it is to ≈øubmit to a Tyrannical, or any other wayes unlawful Authority; and therefore ≈øatisfie God, and me, and all the World in that, and you ≈øhall receive my An≈øwer: I am not afraid of the Bill.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: The Court expects you ≈øhould give them a final An≈øwer; their purpo≈øe is to adjourn till Monday next, if you do not ≈øatisfie your ≈øelf, though we do tell you our Authority; we are ≈øatisfied with our Authority, and it is upon Gods Authority and the Kingdoms, and that peace you ≈øpeak of will be kept in the doing of Ju≈øtice, and that's our pre≈øent work.

p.q: Let me tell you, if you will ≈øhew me what lawful Authority you have, I ≈øhall be ≈øatisfied: But that you have hitherto ≈øaid, ≈øatisfies no rea≈øonable man.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: That's in your apprehen≈øion, we think it rea≈øonable that are your Judges.

p.q: 'Tis not my apprehen≈øion, nor yours neither, that ought to decide it.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: The Court hath heard you, and you are to be di≈øpo≈øed of as they have commanded.

p.hi: Two things were remarkable in this dayes proceedings.

div.p: 1. It is ob≈øerved, That as the Charge was reading again≈øt the King, the ≈øilver head of his Staff fell off, the which he wondered at, and ≈øeeing none to take it up, he ≈øtoop'd for it him≈øelf, and put it in his pocket.

2. That as the King was going away, he looking with a very au≈øtere countenance upon the Court, without ≈øtirring of his Hat, replyed, Well Sir, (when the L. Pre≈øident commanded the Guard to take him away) and at his going down, he ≈øaid, I do not fear that, (pointing with his ≈øtaff at the Sword.) The people in the Hall, as he went down the ≈øtairs cryed out, ≈øome, God ≈øave the King, and ≈øome for Ju≈øtice.
O yes being called, the Court adjourned till Monday next, January 22. at 9. in the morning to the Painted Chamber, and from thence to the ≈øame place again in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall.

January 21. being Sunday, the Commi≈ø≈øioners kept a Fa≈øt at White-Hall; there Preached Mr. Spigge, his Text was, He that ≈øheds Mans blood, by Man ≈øhall his blood be ≈øhed: next, Mr. Foxeley, his Text Judge not, lea≈øt you be judged. La≈øt, was Mr. Peters, his Text was, I will bind their Kings in Chains, and their Nobles in fetters of Iron.

div.head: At the High-Court of Ju≈øtice ≈øitting in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, Monday, Jan. 22. 1648.
div.p: O Yes made: Silence commanded, The Court called, and an≈øwered to their Names.
Silence commanded upon pain of impri≈øonment, and the Captain of the Guard to apprehend all ≈øuch as make di≈øturbance.
Upon the Kings coming in a ≈øhout was made.
Command given by the Court to the Captain of the Guard, to fetch and take into his cu≈øtody tho≈øe who make any di≈øturbance.

Mr. Solicitor. May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, my Lord Pre≈øident, I did at the la≈øt Court in the behalf of the Commons of England, exhibit and give into this Court a Charge of High Trea≈øon and other high Crimes, again≈øt the Pri≈øoner at the Bar, whereof I do accu≈øe him in the name of the People of England, and the Charge was read unto
him, and his An≈øwer required. My Lord, he was not then plea≈øed to give an An≈øwer, but in ≈øtead of an≈øwering, did there di≈øpute the Authority of this High Court. My humble Motion to this High Court, in behalf of the People of England, is, That the Pri≈øoner may be directed to make a po≈øitive An≈øwer, either by way of Confe≈ø≈øion or Negation; which if he ≈øhall refu≈øe to do, that the matter of. Charge may be taken pro confe≈ø≈øo, and the Court may proceed according to Ju≈øtice.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p:
Sir, You may remember at the la≈øt Court, you were told the occa≈øion of your being brought hither, and you heard a Charge again≈øt you, containing a Charge of high Trea≈øon, and other high Crimes, again≈øt this Realm of England; you heard likewi≈øe that it was prayed in the behalf of the People, that you ≈øhould give an an≈øwer to that Charge, that thereupon ≈øuch proceedings might be had, as ≈øhould be agreeable to ju≈øtice; you were then plea≈øed to make ≈øome ≈øcruples concerning the Authority of this Court, and knew not by what Authority you were brought hither; you did divers times propound your Que≈øtions, and were as often an≈øwered, that it was by Authority of the Commons of England a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that did think fit to call you to an account for tho≈øe high and capital mi≈ødemeanours wherewith you were then charged. Since that, the Court hath taken into Con≈øideration what you then ≈øaid; they are fully ≈øatisfied with their own Authority, and they hold it fit you ≈øhould ≈øtand ≈øatisfied with it too; and they do require it, that you do give a po≈øitive and particular An≈øwer to this Charge that is exhibited again≈øt you, they do expect you ≈øhould either confe≈øs or deny it; if you deny, it is offered in the behalf of the Nation to be made good again≈øts
you; their Authority they do avow to the whole world, that the whole Kingdom are to re≈øt ≈øati≈øfied in, and you are to re≈øt ≈øatisfied with it, and therefore you are to lo≈øe no more time, but to give a po≈øitive An≈øwer thereunto.

q.p: When I was here la≈øt, 'tis true, I made that Que≈øtion, and truly if it were onely my own particular ca≈øe, I would have ≈øatisfied my ≈øelf with the Prote≈øtation I made the la≈øt time I was here again≈øt the Legality of this Court, and that a King cannot be tryed by any Superiour Juri≈ødiction on Earth; but it is not my ca≈øe alone, it is the Freedom and the Liberty of the people of England; and do you pretend what you will, I ≈øtand more for their Liberties. For if power without Law, may make Laws, may alter the fundamental Laws of the Kingdom, I do not know what Subject he is in England, that can be ≈øure of his life, or any thing that he calls his own; therefore when that I came here, I did expect particular Rea≈øons to know by what Law, what Authority you did proceed again≈øt me here, and therefore I am a little to ≈øeek what to ≈øay to you in this particular, becau≈øe the Affirmative is proved, the Negative often is very hard to do: but ≈øince I cannot per≈øwade you to do it, I ≈øhall tell you my Rea≈øons as ≈øhort as I can.

My Rea≈øons why in Con≈øcience, and the duty I owe to God fir≈øt, and my People next, for the pre≈øervation of their Lives, Liberties and E≈øtates; I conceive I cannot an≈øwer this, till I be ≈øatisfied of the legality of it.
Here the King would have delivered his Rea≈øons. All proceedings again≈øt any man what≈øoever‚Äî

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p:
Sir, I mu≈øt interrupt you, which I would not do, but that what
you do, is not agreeable to the proceedings of any Court of Ju≈øtice; you are about to enter into Argument, and di≈øpute concerning the Authority of this Court, before whom you appear as a Pri≈øoner, and are charged as an high Delinquent; if you take upon you to di≈øpute the Authority of the Court, we may not do it, nor will any Court give way unto it, you are to ≈øubmit unto it, you are to give in a punctual and direct An≈øwer, whether you will an≈øwer to your Charge or no, and what your An≈øwer is.

p.q: Sir by your favour, I do not know the forms of Law, I do know Law and Rea≈øon, though I am no Lawyer profe≈ø≈øed, yet I know as much Law as any Gentleman in England; and therefore (under favour) I do plead for the Liberties of the People of England more than you do, and therefore if I ≈øhould impo≈øe a belief upon any man without Rea≈øons given for it, it were unrea≈øonable; but I mu≈øt tell you, That by that Rea≈øon that I have as thus informed, I cannot yield unto it.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, I mu≈øt interrupt you, you may not be permitted; you ≈øpeak of Law and Rea≈øon, it is fit there ≈øhould be Law and Rea≈øon, and there is both again≈øt you. Sir, the Vote of the Commons of England A≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, it is the Rea≈øon of the Kingdom, and they are the≈øe too that have given that Law, according to which you ≈øhould have ruled and reigned. Sir, you are not to di≈øpute our Authority, you are told it again by the Court. Sir, it will be taken notice of, that you ≈øtand in contempt of the Court, and your contempt will be recorded accordingly.

p.q:
I do not know how a King can be a Delinquent: not by any Law that ever I heard of, all men (Delinquents or what you will)
let me tell you, they may put in Demurrers again≈øt any proceedings as Legal, and I do demand that, and demand to be heard with my Rea≈øons, if you deny that, you deny Rea≈øon.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you have offered ≈øomething to the Court, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak ≈øomething unto you the ≈øence of the Court; Sir, neither you nor any man are permitted to di≈øpute that point, you are concluded, you may not demur the Juri≈ødiction of the Court; if you do, I mu≈øt let you know, that they over-rule your Demurrer, they ≈øit here by the Authority of the Commons of England, and all your Predece≈ø≈øors, and you are re≈øpon≈øible to them.

p.q: I deny that, ≈øhew me one Pre≈øident‚Äî

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir you ought not to interrupt while the Court is ≈øpeaking to you, this point is not to be debated by you, neither will the Court permit you to do it; if you offer it by way of Demurrer to the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, they have con≈øidered of their Juri≈ødiction, they do affirm their own Juri≈ødiction.

p.q: I ≈øay Sir, by your favour, that the Commons of England was never a Court of Judicature, I would know how they came to be ≈øo.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you are not to be permitted to go on in that Speech, and the≈øe Di≈øcour≈øes.
Then the Clerk of the Court read as followeth.

Charles Stuart, King of England, You have been accu≈øed on the behalf of the People of England, of High Trea≈øon, and other high Crimes, the Court have determined, that you ought to an≈øwer the ≈øame.

p.q: I will an≈øwer the ≈øame as ≈øoon as I know by what Authority you do this.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: If this be all that you will ≈øay, then Gentlemen, you that brought the Pri≈øoner hither, take charge of him back again.

p.q: I do require that I may give in my Rea≈øons why I do not An≈øwer, and give me time for that.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, 'Tis not for Pri≈øoners to require.

p.q: Pri≈øoners! Sir, I am not an ordinary Pri≈øoner.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: The Court hath con≈øidered of their Juri≈ødiction, and they have already affirmed their Juri≈ødiction; if you will not an≈øwer, we ≈øhall give order to record your default.

p.q: You never heard my Rea≈øons yet.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, your Rea≈øons are not to be heard again≈øt the highe≈øt Juri≈ødiction.

p.q: Shew me that Juri≈ødiction, where Rea≈øon is not to be heard.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, We ≈øhew it you here, the Commons of England; and the next time you are brought, you will know more of the plea≈øure of the Court, and it may be, their final determination.

p.q: Shew me wherever the Hou≈øe of Commons was a Court of Judicature of that kind.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Serjeant take away the Pri≈øoner.

p.q: Well Sir, remember that the King is not ≈øuffered to give his Rea≈øons for the Liberty and Freedom of all his Subjects.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, You are not to have liberty to u≈øe this language; how great a friend you have been to the Laws and Liberties of the people, let all England and the World judge.

p.q:
Sir, under favour, it was the Liberty, Freedom, and Laws of the Subject that ever I
took ‚Äî defended my ≈øelf with Arms; I never took up Arms again≈øt the People, but for my people and the Laws.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: The command of the Court mu≈øt be obeyed; no An≈øwer will be given to the Charge.

p.q: Well Sir.

div.p: Then the Lord Pre≈øident ordered the default to be recorded, and the Contempt of the Court, and that no an≈øwer would be given to the Charge.
And ≈øo was guarded forth to Sir Robert Cotton's hou≈øe.

Then the Court adjourned to the Painted Chamber on Tue≈øday at twelve a clock, and from thence they intended to adjourn to We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, at which time all per≈øons concerned were to give their attendance.

div.head: Re≈øolutions of the Court at their meeting in the Painted Chamber, Lunae Jan. 22. 1648.
div.p:
This day the King being withdrawn from the Bar of the High Court of Ju≈øtice, the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the ≈øaid High Court of Ju≈øtice ≈øate private in the Painted Chamber, and con≈øidered of the Kings carriage upon the Saturday before, and of all that had then pa≈ø≈øed, and fully approved of what the Lord Pre≈øident had done and ≈øaid in the managing of the bu≈øine≈øs of that day, as agreeing to their ≈øence. And perceiving what the King aimed at, viz. to bring in que≈øtion (if he could) the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, and the Authority thereof, whereby they ≈øate; and con≈øidering that in the interim he had not acknowledged them in any ≈øort to be a Court or his Judges; and through their ≈øides intended to wound (if he might be permitted) the Supream
Authority of the Commons of England, in their Repre≈øentatives the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, after advice with their Councell learned in both Laws, and mature deliberation had of the matter:

Re≈øolved, That the King ≈øhould not be ≈øuffered to argue the Courts Juri≈ødiction, of that which con≈øtituted them a Court, of which debate they had not proper Conu≈øance, nor could they, being a derivative Judge of that Supream Court which made them Judges, from which there was no Appeal, and did therefore order and direct, viz.

Ordered, That in ca≈øe the King ≈øhall again offer to di≈øpute the Authority of the Court, the Lord Pre≈øident do let him know, that the Court have taken into con≈øideration his demands of the la≈øt day, and that he ought to re≈øt ≈øatisfied with this An≈øwer; That the Commons of England a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament have con≈øtituted this Court, who≈øe power may not, nor ≈øhould be permitted to be di≈øputed by him.
That in ca≈øe the King ≈øhall refu≈øe to an≈øwer or acknowledge the Court, the Lord Pre≈øident do let him know that the Court will take it as a Contumacy, and that it ≈øhall be ≈øo Recorded.

That in ca≈øe he ≈øhall offer or an≈øwer with a ≈øaving, notwith≈øtanding of his pretended Prerogatives, above the juri≈ødiction of the Court, That the Lord Pre≈øident do in the Name of the Court refu≈øe his prote≈øt, and require his po≈øitive An≈øwer, whether he will own the Court or not.
That in ca≈øe the King ≈øhall demand a Copy of the Charge, that he ≈øhall then declare his intention to An≈øwer, and that declaring his intention, a Copy be granted unto him.

That in ca≈øe the King ≈øhall ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt in his
contempt, the Lord Pre≈øident do give command to the Clerk, to demand of the King, in the name of the Court, in the≈øe words following, viz.

Charles Stuart King of England, you are accu≈øed in the behalf of the People of England, of divers high Crimes and Trea≈øons, which Charge hath been read unto you. The Court requires you to give a po≈øitive An≈øwer, to confe≈øs or deny the Charge, having determined that you ought to An≈øwer the ≈øame.

opener.dateline: At the High Court of Ju≈øtice ≈øitting in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, Tue≈øday, Jan. 23. 1648.

div.p: O yes made. Silence commanded. The Court called. Seventy three Per≈øons pre≈øent.
The King comes in with his Guard, looks with an au≈øtere countenance upon the Court, and ≈øits down.
The ≈øecond O Yes made, and ≈øilence commanded.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cook Solicitor General.
sp.p: May it plea≈øe your Lord≈øhip, my Lord Pre≈øident,

This is now the third time that by the great grace, and favour of this High Court, the Pri≈øoner hath been brought to the Bar, before any I≈ø≈øue joyned in the Cau≈øe. My Lord, I did at the fir≈øt Court exhibit a Charge again≈øt him, containing the highe≈øt Trea≈øon that ever was wrought upon the Theatre of England: that a King of England, tru≈øted to keep the Law, That had taken an Oath ≈øo to do, That had Tribute paid him for that end, ≈øhould be guilty of a wicked de≈øign to ≈øubvert and de≈øtroy our Lawes, and introduce an Arbitrary and Tyrannical Government, in the defiance of the Parliament and their Authority, ≈øet up his Standard for War again≈øt his Parliament and People; and I did
humbly pray, in the behalf of the People of England; that he might ≈øpeedily be required to make an an≈øwer to the Charge.

But, my Lord, in≈øtead of making any An≈øwer, he did then di≈øpute the Authority of this High Court; your Lord≈øhip was plea≈øed to give him a further day to con≈øider, and to put in his An≈øwer, which day being ye≈øterday, I did humbly move that he might be required to give a direct and po≈øitive an≈øwer, either by denying, or confe≈ø≈øion of it; but (my Lord) he was then plea≈øed for to demurre to the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, which the Court did then overrule, and command him to give a direct and po≈øitive An≈øwer. My Lord, be≈øides this great delay of, Ju≈øtice, I ≈øhall now humbly move your Lord≈øhip for ≈øpeedy Judgment again≈øt him. My Lord, I might pre≈ø≈øe your Lord≈øhip upon the whole, That according to the known Rules of the Law of the Land, That if a Pri≈øoner ≈øhall ≈øtand as contumacious in contempt, and ≈øhall not put in an i≈ø≈øuable plea, Guilty or not Guilty of the Charge given again≈øt him, whereby he may come to a fair Tryal; That as by an implicite confe≈ø≈øion, it may be taken pro confe≈ø≈øo, as it hath been done to tho≈øe who have de≈øerved more favour than the Pri≈øoner at the Bar has done: but be≈øides, my Lord, I ≈øhall humbly pre≈ø≈øe your Lord≈øhip upon the whole Fact; the Hou≈øe of Commons, the Supream Authority and Juri≈ødiction of the Kingdom, they have declared, That it is notorious, That the matter of the Charge is true, as it is in truth (my Lord) as clearas Chry≈øtal, and as the Sun that ≈øhines at noonday; which if your Lord≈øhip and the Court be not ≈øatisfied in, I have notwith≈øtanding, on the
people of Englands behalf, ≈øeveral witne≈ø≈øes to produce: And therefore I do humbly pray, and yet I mu≈øt confe≈øs it is not ≈øo much I, as the innocent blood that hath been ≈øhed, the cry whereof is very great for ju≈øtice and judgment, and therefore I do humbly pray, that ≈øpeedy Judgement be pronounced again≈øt the Pri≈øoner at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you have heard what is moved by the Councel on the behalf of the Kingdom again≈øt you. Sir, you may well remember, and if you do not, the Court cannot forget, what dilatory dealings the Court hath found at your hands: you were plea≈øed to propound ≈øome Que≈øtions, you have had your Re≈øolutions upon them. You were told over and over again, That the Court did affirm their own juri≈ødiction: That it was not for you, nor any other man, to di≈øpute the Juri≈ødiction of the Supreme and highe≈øt Authority of England, from which there is no Appeal, and touching which there mu≈øt be no di≈øpute; yet you did per≈øi≈øt in ≈øuch carriage, as you gave no manner of obedience, nor did you acknowledge any Authority in them, nor the High Court, that con≈øtituted this Court of Ju≈øtice.

Sir, I mu≈øt let you know from the Court, That they are very ≈øen≈øible of the≈øe delays of yours, and that they ought not, being thus Authorized by the ≈øupreme Court of England, to be thus trifled withall, and that they might in ju≈øtice, if they plea≈øed, and according to the Rules of Ju≈øtice, take advantage of the≈øe delayes, and proceed to pronounce judgment again≈øt you; yet neverthele≈øs they are plea≈øed to give direction, and on their behalfs I do require you, that you make a po≈øitive An≈øwer unto this Charge that is again≈øt you: Sir, in plain terms; for Ju≈øtice knows no re≈øpect of per≈øons, you are to
give your po≈øitive and final An≈øwer in plain Engli≈øh, whether you be guilty or not guilty of the≈øe Trea≈øons laid to your Charge.

div.p: The King after a little pau≈øe, ≈øaid,

p.q: When I was here ye≈øterday, I did de≈øire to ≈øpeak for the Liberties of the People of England; I was interrupted: I de≈øire to know yet whether I may ≈øpeak freely or not.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir you have had the Re≈øolution of the Court upon the like Que≈øtion the la≈øt day, and you were told, That having ≈øuch a Charge of ≈øo high a Nature again≈øt you, your Work was, that you ought to acknowledge the juri≈ødiction of the Court, and to An≈øwer to your Charge. Sir, if you An≈øwer to your Charge, which the Court gives you leave now to do, though they might have taken the advantage of your Contempt, yet if you be able to An≈øwer to your Charge, when you have once An≈øwered, you ≈øhall be heard at large, make the be≈øt Defence you can. But Sir, I mu≈øt let you know from the Court, as their commands, that you are not to be permitted to i≈ø≈øue out into any other di≈øcour≈øes, till ≈øuch time as you have given a po≈øitive An≈øwer concerning the Matter that is Charged upon you.

sp.speaker: King.

p.q:
For the Charge I value it not a Ru≈øh, it is the Liberty of the people of England that I ≈øtand for; for me to acknowledge a new Court, that I never heard of before, I that am your King, that ≈øhould be an example to all the people of England, for to uphold Ju≈øtice, to maintain the old Laws; indeed I do not know how to do it; you ≈øpoke very well the fir≈øt day that I came here, (on Saturday) of the Obligations that I had laid upon me by God, to the maintenance of the Libertyes of my People: The ≈øame Obligation you ≈øpeak of, I do
acknowledge to God that I owe to Him, and to my people, to defend, as much as in me lies, the ancient Laws of the Kingdom; therefore until that I may know that this is not again≈øt the Fundamental Laws of the Kingdom, by your favour, I can put in no particular An≈øwer: If you will give me time, I will then ≈øhew you my Rea≈øons why I cannot do it, and this ‚Äî

By your favour, you ought not to interrupt me; how I came here, I know not, there's no Law for it, to make your King your Pri≈øoner: I was lately in a Treaty upon the publick Faith of the Kingdom, that was the known ‚Äî the two Hou≈øes of Parliament, that was the Repre≈øentative of the Kingdom, and when that I had almo≈øt made an end of the Treaty, then I was hurried away and brought hither, and therefore‚Äî

sp.p: Here the Pre≈øident interrupted him and ≈øaid, Sir, you mu≈øt know the plea≈øure of the Court.

p.q: By your favour Sir,‚Äî

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Nay Sir, by your favour, you may not be permitted to fall into the≈øe di≈øcour≈øes; you appear as a Delinquent, you have not acknowledged the Authority of the Court; the Court craves it not of you, and once more they command you to give your po≈øitive An≈øwer‚ÄîClerk. Do your Duty.

p.q: Duty Sir!

div.p: The Clerk reads,

body.p: Charles Stuart, King of England, you are accu≈øed in the behalf of the Commons of England of divers high Crimes and Trea≈øons, which Charge hath been read unto you; the Court now requires you to give your po≈øitive and final An≈øwer, by way of confe≈ø≈øion, or denyal of the Charge.

p.q: Sir; I ≈øay again to you, ≈øo that I might give ≈øatisfaction to the people of England of the clearne≈øs of my proceedings, not by way of An≈øwer, not in this way, but to ≈øatisfie them that I have done nothing again≈øt that Tru≈øt that hath been committed to me, I would do it; but to acknowledge a new Court again≈øt their Priviledges, to alter the fundamental Laws of the Kingdom; Sir, you mu≈øt excu≈øe me.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, this is the third time that you have publickly di≈øowned the Court, and put an affront upon it; how far you have pre≈øerved the Priviledges of the people, your Actions have ≈øpoke it; but truly Sir, mens intentions ought to be known by their Actions, you have written your meaning in bloody Characters throughout the whole Kingdom; but Sir, you under≈øtand the plea≈øure of the Court: ‚ÄîClerk Record the default, ‚Äî and Gentlemen, you that took charge of the Pri≈øoner, take him back again.

p.q: I will onely ≈øay this one word to you, If it were only my own particular, I would not ≈øay any more, nor interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you have heard the plea≈øure of the Court, and you are (notwith≈øtanding you will not under≈øtand it) to find that you are before a Court of Ju≈øtice.

div.p: Then the King went forth with his Guard, and Proclamation was made, That all per≈øons who had then appeared, and had further to do at the Court, might depart into the Painted Chamber, to which place the Court did forthwith adjourn, and intended to meet in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall by Ten of the clock the next morning.

sp.speaker: Cryer.
sp.p: God ble≈øs the Kingdom of England.

div.p: His Maje≈øty intended to have delivered in writing his Rea≈øons again≈øt the Pretended Juri≈ødicton of the High Court of Ju≈øtice, upon Monday, Jan. 22. but was not permitted.

O Yes made. Silence commanded. The Court called; Serjeant Brad≈øhaw, Lord Pre≈øident, in his Scarlet Robe (≈øuitable to the work of this day) with ≈øixtie eight other Members of the Court called. As the King came into the Court, in his u≈øual po≈øture with his Hat on, a Cry made in the Hall by ≈øome of the Souldiers for Ju≈øtice, Ju≈øtice, and Execution.

p.q: I ≈øhall de≈øire a word to be heard a little, and I hope I ≈øhall give no occa≈øion of interruption.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: You may an≈øwer in your time, hear the Court fir≈øt.

p.q: If it plea≈øe you, Sir, I de≈øire to be heard, and I ≈øhall not give any occa≈øion of interruption, and it is only in a word; a ≈øudden judgment‚Äî

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: You ≈øhall be heard in due time, but You are to hear the Court fir≈øt.

p.q: Sir, I de≈øire it, it will be in order to what I believe the Court will ≈øay; and therefore, Sir, a ha≈øtie Judgment is not ≈øo ≈øoon recalled.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you ≈øhall be heard before the Judgment be given, and in the mean time you may forbear.

p.q: Well Sir, ≈øhall I be heard before the judgment be given?

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, it is well known to all, or mo≈øt of you here pre≈øent, That the Pri≈øoner at the Bar hath been ≈øeveral times convented
and brought before the Court to make an≈øwer to a Charge of Trea≈øon and other high Crimes exhibited again≈øt him in the Name of the People of England; to which Charge, being required to An≈øwer,
Here an honourable Lady interrupted the Court, ≈øaying, Not half the People, but ≈øhe was ≈øoon ≈øilenced. he hath been ≈øo far from obeying the Commands of the Court, by ≈øubmitting to their Ju≈øtice, as he began to take upon him to offer rea≈øoning and debate unto the Authoritie of the Court, and of the highe≈øt Court that con≈øtituted them to try and judge him; but being over-ruled in that, and required to make his An≈øwer, he was ≈øtill plea≈øed to continue contumacious, and to refu≈øe to ≈øubmit or An≈øwer: Hereupon the Court, that they may not be wanting to them≈øelves, to the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them, nor that any mans wilfulne≈øs prevent Ju≈øtice, they have thought fit to take the matter into their con≈øideration; They have con≈øidered of the Contumacy, and of that confe≈ø≈øion which in Law doth ari≈øe upon that contumacy; They have likewi≈øe con≈øidered of the notoriety of the Fact charged upon the Pri≈øoner, and upon the whole matter they are re≈øolved, and have agreed upon a Sentence to be now pronounced again≈øt this Pri≈øoner: but in re≈øpect he doth de≈øire to be heard before the Sentence be read and pronounced, the Court hath re≈øolved that they will hear him; yet Sir, thus much I mu≈øt tell you before-hand, which you have been minded of at other Courts; that if that you have to ≈øay be to offer any Debate concerning juri≈ødiction, you are not to be heard in it, you have offered it formerly, and you have indeed ≈øtruck at the root, that is, the power and Supreme Authority of the Commons of England, which this Court will not admit a debate of, and
which indeed is an irrational thing in them to do, being a Court that acts upon Authority denived from them, that they ≈øhould pre≈øume to judge upon their Superiority, from whom there is no Appeal. But Sir, if you have any thing to ≈øay in defence of your ≈øelf concerning the matters charged, the Court hath given me command to let you know they will hear you.

p.q:
Since that I ≈øee that you will not hear any thing of debate concerning that which I confe≈øs I thought mo≈øt material for the peace of the Kingdom, and for the Liberty of the Subject, I ≈øhall wave it, I ≈øhall ≈øpeak nothing to it; but only I mu≈øt tell you, That this many a day all things have been taken away from me, but that, that I call more dear to me than my life, which is My Con≈øcience and my Honour; and if I had re≈øpect to my life more than the Peace of the Kingdom, the Liberty of the Subject, certainly I ≈øhould have made a particular defence for my ≈øelf, for by that at lea≈øt-wi≈øe I might have delayed an ugly Sentence, which I believe will pa≈øs upon me; Therefore certainly, Sir, as a man that hath ≈øome under≈øtanding, ≈øome knowledge of the world, if that my true zeal to my Countrey had not overborn the care that I have of my own pre≈øervation, I ≈øhould have gone another way to work than that I have done: Now Sir, I conceive that an ha≈øtie Sentence once pa≈øt, may be ≈øooner repented than recalled: And truly the ≈øelf ≈øame de≈øire that I have for the Peace of the Kingdome, and the Liberty of the Subject, more than my own particular, does make me now at la≈øt de≈øire, That having ≈øomething for to ≈øay that concerns both, I de≈øire before Sentence be given, that I may be heard in the Painted Chamber before the Lords and Commons;
this delay cannot be prejudicial to you what≈øoever I ≈øay, if that I ≈øay no Rea≈øon, tho≈øe that hear me mu≈øt be Judges, I cannot be Judge of that that I have; if it be Rea≈øon, and really for the welfare of the Kingdom, and the Liberty of the Subject, I am ≈øure on it very well, it is worth the hearing; Therefore I do conjure you, as you love that you pretend, I hope it is real, the Liberty of the Subject, the Peace of the Kingdom; that you will grant Me the hearing, before any Sentence be pa≈ø≈øed; I only de≈øire this, that you will take this into your con≈øideration, it may be you have not heard of it before-hand; if you will, I'le retire, and you may think of it: but if I cannot get this Liberty, I do here prote≈øt, that ≈øo fair ≈øhews of Liberty and Peace are pure ≈øhews, and not otherwi≈øe, then that you will not hear your KING.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, You have now ≈øpoken?

p.q: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: And this that you have ≈øaid is a further declining of the Juri≈ødiction of this Court, which was the thing wherein you were limited before.

p.q: Pray excu≈øe me Sir, for my interruption, becau≈øe you mi≈øtake me, it is not a declining of it, you do judge me before you hear me ≈øpeak: I ≈øay it will not, I do not decline it, though I cannot acknowledge the Juri≈ødiction of the Court; yet Sir, in this give Me leave to ≈øay, I would do it, though I did not acknowledge it in this, I do prote≈øt it is not the declining of it, ≈øince I ≈øay, if that I do ≈øay any thing but that that is for the Peace of the Kingdom, and the Liberties of the Subject, then the ≈øhame is mine. Now I de≈øire, that you will take this into your con≈øideration, if you will, I'le withdraw.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p:
Sir, this is not altogether new that
you have moved unto us, not altogether new to us, though the fir≈øt time in per≈øon you have offered it to the Court: Sir, you ≈øay you do not Decline the Juri≈ødiction of the Court.

p.q: Not in this that I have ≈øaid.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: I under≈øtand you well Sir, but neverthele≈øs that which you have offered, ≈øeems to be contrary to that ≈øaying of yours; for the Court are ready to give a Sentence: it is not as you ≈øay, That they will not hear your King, for they have been ready to hear you, they have patiently waited your plea≈øure for three Courts together, to hear what you would ≈øay to the Peoples Charge again≈øt you, to which you have not vouch≈øafed to give any an≈øwer at all; Sir, This tends to a further delay: Truly Sir, ≈øuch delayes as the≈øe neither may the Kingdom, nor Ju≈øtice well bear; You have had three ≈øeveral dayes to have offered in this kind what you would have plea≈øed; This Court is founded upon that Authority of the Commons of England, in whom re≈øts the Supreme Juri≈ødiction; That which you now tender, is to have another Juri≈ødiction, and a coordinate Juri≈ødiction, I know very well you expre≈øs your ≈øelf. Sir, That notwith≈øtanding that you would offer to the Lords nnd Commons in the Painted Chamber, yet neverthele≈øs you would proceed on here, I did hear you ≈øay ≈øo; but Sir, that you would offer there, whatever it is, mu≈øt needs be in delay of the Ju≈øtice here; ≈øo as if this Court be re≈øolved, and prepared for the Sentence, this that you offer they are not bound in ju≈øtice to grant; but Sir, according to that you ≈øeem to de≈øire, and becau≈øe you ≈øhall know the further plea≈øure of the Court upon that which you have moved, the Court will withdraw for a time.

p.q: Shall I withdraw?

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you ≈øhall know the plea≈øure of Court pre≈øently, the Court withdraws for half an hour into the Court of Wards.

div.p: Serjeant at Arms: The Court gives command that the Pri≈øoner be withdrawn, and they give order for his return again.
The Court withdraws for half an hour and returns.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Serjeant at Arms, ≈øend for your pri≈øoner.

Sir, You were plea≈øed to make a motion here to the Court, to offer a de≈øire of yours touching the propounding of ≈øomewhat to the Lords in the Painted Chamber for the Peace of the Kingdom: Sir, you did in effect receive an an≈øwer before the Court adjourned; Truly Sir, their withdrawing and adjournment was pro forma tantum, for it did not ≈øeem to them that there was any difficulty in the thing; they have con≈øidered of what you have moved, and have con≈øidered of their own Authority, which is founded (as hath been often ≈øaid) upon the Supreme Authority of the Commons of England a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, The Court acts accordingly to their Commi≈ø≈øion: Sir, the return I have to you from the Court, is this, That they have been too much delayed by you already, and this that you now offer hath occa≈øioned ≈øome little further delay, and they are JUDGES appointed by the highe≈øt JUDGES, and Judges are no more to delay, than they are to deny ju≈øtice: they are good words in the old Charter of England, Nulli negabimus, nulli vendemus, nulli deferemus Ju≈øtitiam. There mu≈øt be no delay; but the truth is, Sir, and ≈øo every man here ob≈øerves it, That you have much delayed them in your contempt and default, for which they might have long ≈øince proceeded, to judgment again≈øt
you, and notwith≈øtanding what you have offered, they are re≈øolved to proceed to puni≈øhment, and to Judgment, and that is their unanimous re≈øolution.

p.q: Sir, I know it is in vain for me to di≈øpute, I am no Sceptick for to deny the power that you have, I know that you have power enough; Sir, I confe≈øs I think it would have been for the Kingdoms peace, if you would have taken the pains for to have ≈øhown the lawfulne≈øs of your power; for this delay that I have de≈øired, I confe≈øs it is a delay, but it is a delay very important for the peace of the Kingdom, for it is not my Per≈øon that I look on alone, it is the Kingdoms welfare, and the Kingdoms peace: it is an old ≈øentence, That we ≈øhould think on long, before we have re≈øolved of great matters ≈øuddenly; Therefore, Sir, I do ≈øay again, that I do put at your doors all the inconveniency of an ha≈øty Sentence; I confe≈øs, I have been here now I think this week, this day eight daies, was the day I came here fir≈øt, but a little delay of a day or two further, may give peace, whereas an Ha≈øty Judgment may bring on that trouble and perpetual inconveniency to the Kingdom, that the Child that is unborn may repent it; and therefore again out of the Duty I owe to God, and to my Countrey, I do de≈øire that I may be heard by the Lords and Commons in the Painted Chamber, or any other Chamber that you will appoint me.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you have been already an≈øwered to what you even now moved, being the ≈øame you moved before, ≈øince the Re≈øolution and the Judgement of the Court in it, and the Court now requires to know whether you have any more to ≈øay for Your ≈øelf, than you have ≈øaid, before they proceed to Sentence.

p.q: I ≈øay this Sir, That if you will hear me, if you will give me but this delay, I doubt not but I ≈øhall give ≈øome ≈øatisfaction to you all here, and to my people after that, and therefore I do require you, as you will An≈øwer it at the dreadfull day of judgment, that you will con≈øider it once again.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, I have received direction from the Court,

p.q: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: If this mu≈øt be re-inforc'd, or any thing of this nature, your an≈øwer mu≈øt be the ≈øame, and they will proceed to Sentence if you have nothing more to ≈øay.

p.q: I have nothing more to ≈øay, but I ≈øhall de≈øire that this may be entred what I have ≈øaid.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: The Court then Sir, hath ≈øomething to ≈øay unto you, which although I know it will be very unacceptable, yet notwith≈øtanding they are willing, and are re≈øolved to di≈øcharge their Duty.

Sir, you ≈øpeak very well of a precious thing that you call Peace, and it had been much to be wi≈øhed that God had put it into your heart, that you had as effectually and really endeavoured and ≈øtudied the Peace of the Kingdom, as now in words you ≈øeem to pretend; but as you were told the other day, Actions mu≈øt expound Intentions, yet Actions have been clean contrary; and truly Sir, it doth appear plainly enough to them, that you have gone upon very erroneous principles; the Kingdom hath felt it to their ≈ømart, and it will be no ea≈øe to you to think of it; for Sir, you have held your ≈øelf, and let fall ≈øuch Language, as if you had been no wayes ≈øubject to the Law, or that the Law had not been your Superiour. Sir, the Court is very well ≈øen≈øible of it, and I hope ≈øo are all the under≈øtanding people of England, That the Law is your Superiour:
That you ought to have ruled according to the Law, you ought to have done ≈øo Sir: I know very well your pretence hath been that you have done ≈øo, but Sir, the difference hath been, who ≈øhall be the Expo≈øitors of this Law; Sir, whether you and your party out of Courts of Ju≈øtice, ≈øhall take upon them to expound Law, or the Courts of Ju≈øtice, who are the Expounders; nay, the Soveraign and the High Court of Ju≈øtice, the Parliament of England, who are not onely the highe≈øt Expounders, but the ≈øole Makers of the Law. Sir, for you to ≈øet your ≈øelf with your ≈øingle judgment, and tho≈øe that adhere unto you, again≈øt the highe≈øt Court of Ju≈øtice, that is not Law: Sir, as the Law is your ≈øuperiour, ≈øo truly Sir, there is ≈øomething that is ≈øuperior to the Law, and that is indeed the Parent or Author of the Law, and that is the People of England. For Sir, as they are tho≈øe that at the fir≈øt, (as other Countreys have done) did chu≈øe to them≈øelves this Form of Government, even for Ju≈øtice ≈øake, that Ju≈øtice might be admini≈øtred, that Peace might be pre≈øerved; ≈øo Sir, they gave Laws to their Governors, according to which they ≈øhould govern; and if tho≈øe Laws ≈øhould have proved inconvenient, or prejudicial to the publick, they had a power in them, and re≈øerved to them≈øelves, to alter as they ≈øhould ≈øee cau≈øe. Sir, it is very true, what ≈øome of your ≈øide have ≈øaid, Rex non habet parem in Regno; This Court will ≈øay the ≈øame while King, That you have not your Peer in ≈øome ≈øence, for you are Major ≈øingulis, but they will averr again, that you are Minor univer≈øis; and the ≈øame Author tells you, that in exhibitione juris, there you have no power, but are qua≈øi minimus.

This we know to be Law, Rex habet ≈øuperiorem, Deum & Legem, etiam & Curiam, and ≈øo ≈øays the
≈øame Author; and truly Sir, he makes bold to go a little further, Debent ei ponere fraenum, They ought to bridle him; and Sir, we know very well the ≈øtories of old; Tho≈øe Wars that were called the Barons Wars, when the Nobility of the Land did ≈øtand out for the Liberty and Property of the Subject, and would not ≈øuffer the Kings that did invade to play the Tyrants here, but called them to account for it, we know that truth, That they did fraenum ponere: But Sir, if they do forbear to do their duty now, and are not ≈øo mindful of their own honour and the Kingdoms good, certainly the Commons of England will not be unmindful of what is for their pre≈øervation, and for their ≈øafety: Ju≈øtitiae fruendi cau≈øa Reges con≈øtituti ≈øunt. This we learn is the end of having Kings, or any other Governours, it's for the enjoying of Ju≈øtice, that's the end. Now Sir, if ≈øo be the King will go contrary to the end of his Government; Sir, he mu≈øt under≈øtand that he is but an Officer of tru≈øt, and he ought to di≈øcharge that tru≈øt, and they are to take order for the animadver≈øion and puni≈øhment of ≈øuch an offending Governour.

This is not Law of ye≈øterday, Sir, (≈øince the time of the divi≈øion betwixt you and your People,) but it is Law of old; And we know very well the Authors and Authorities that do tell us what the Law was in that point upon the Election of Kings, upon the Oath that they took unto their People, and if they did not ob≈øerve it, there weere tho≈øe things called Parliaments; The Parliaments were they that were to adjudge (the very words of the Author) the plaints and wrongs done of the King and Queen, or their Children; ≈øuch wrongs e≈øpecially, when the People could have no where el≈øe any remedy. Sir, that hath been the People of Englands ca≈øe, they could not have their remedy el≈øewhere but in Parliament.

Sir, Parliaments were ordained for that purpo≈øe, to redre≈øs the grievances of the People, that was their main end; and truly Sir, if ≈øo be that the Kings of England had been rightly mindful of them≈øelves, they were never more in Maje≈øty and State, than in the Parliament: but how forgetfull ≈øome have been, Hi≈øtories have told us; We have a mi≈øerable, a lamentable, a ≈øad experience of it. Sir, by the old Laws of England, (I ≈øpeak the≈øe things the rather to you, becau≈øe you were plea≈øed to let fall the other day, you thought you had as much knowledge in the Law, as mo≈øt Gentlemen in England; it is very well Sir. And truly Sir, it is very good for the Gentlemen of England to under≈øtand that Law under which they mu≈øt live, and by which they mu≈øt be governed. And then Sir, the Scripture ≈øays, They that know their Ma≈øters Will and do it not, what follows. The Law is your Ma≈øter, the Acts of Parliaments.) the Parliaments were to be kept anciently, we find in our Author, twice in the year, That the Subject upon any occa≈øion, might have a ready remedy and redre≈ø≈øe for his Grievance. Afterwards, by ≈øeveral Acts of Parliament in the dayes of your Predece≈ø≈øor Edward the third, they mu≈øt have been once a year. Sir, what intermi≈ø≈øion of PARLIAMENTS hath been in your time, it is very well known, and the ≈øad con≈øequences of it, and what in the interim in≈øtead of the≈øe Parliaments, hath been by you, by an high and Arbitrary hand introduced upon the People, that likewi≈øe hath been too well known and felt. But when God by his Providence had ≈øo brought it about, that you could no longer decline the calling of a Parliament; Sir, yet it will appear what your ends were again≈øt the Ancient, and your Native Kingdom of Scotland: The Parliament
of England, not ≈øerving your ends again≈øt them, you were plea≈øed to di≈ø≈øolve it. Another great nece≈ø≈øity occa≈øioned the calling of this Parliament, and what your de≈øigns and plots and endeavours all along have been for the ruining and confounding of this Parliament, hath been very notorious to the whole Kingdom; And truly Sir, in that you did ≈øtrike at all; that had been a ≈øure way to have brought about that that this layes upon you, Your Intention to ≈øubvert the Fundamental Laws of the Land. For the great bulwark of Liberty of the People, is the PARLIAMENT of England; and to Subvert and Root up that, which your aim hath been to do, certainly at one blow you had confounded the Liberties and the Propriety of England.

Truly Sir, it makes me call to mind, I cannot forbear to expre≈øs it, for Sir, we mu≈øt deal plainly with you, according to the merits of your cau≈øe, ≈øo is our Commi≈ø≈øion; it makes me call to mind (the≈øe proceedings of yours) that we read of a great Roman Emperor, by the way let us call him a great Roman Tyrant, Caligula, that wi≈øht that the People of Rome had had but one Neck, that at one blow he might cut it off: and your proceedings hath been ≈øomewhat like to this, for the body of the people of England hath been (and where el≈øe repre≈øented but) in the Parliament, and could you have but confounded that, you had at one blow cut off the neck of England: but God hath re≈øerved better things for us, and hath plea≈øed for to Confound your de≈øigns, and to break your Forces, and to bring your Per≈øon into Cu≈øtodie, that you might be re≈øpon≈øible to Ju≈øtice.

Sir, we know very well, That it is a que≈øtion on your ≈øide very much Pre≈øs'd, By what pre≈øident we
≈øhall proceed? Truly Sir, for Pre≈øidents, I ≈øhall not at this pre≈øent make any long di≈øcour≈øe, but it is no new thing to cite Pre≈øidents almo≈øt of all Nations, where the People (when power hath been in their hands) have not ≈øticked to call their Kings to account, and where the change of Government hath en≈øued upon occa≈øions of the Tyranny and Mi≈ø-government of tho≈øe that have been placed over them; I will not ≈øpend time to mention France, or Spain, or the Empire, or other Countries, Volumes may be written of them; But truly Sir, that of the Kingdom of Arragon, I ≈øhould think ≈øome of us have thought upon it, where they have the Ju≈øtice of Arragon, that is a man tanquam in medio po≈øitus, betwixt the King of Spain, and the people of the Country, that if wrong be done by the King, he that is the King of Arragon, the Ju≈øtice hath power to reform the wrong, and he is acknowledged to be the Kings Superiour, and is the grand pre≈øerver of their priviledges, and hath pro≈øecuted Kings upon their mi≈øcarriages.

Sir, What the Tribunes of Rome were heretofore, and what the Ephori were to the Lacedaemonian State, we know that is the Parliament of England to the Engli≈øh State; and though Rome ≈øeem to have lo≈øt its liberty when once the Emperours were, yet you ≈øhall find ≈øome famous Acts of Ju≈øtice even done by the Senate of Rome; that great Tyrant of his time, Nero, condemned and judged by the Senate. But truly Sir, to you I ≈øhould not mention the≈øe Forreign examples and ≈øtories. If you look but over Tweed, we find enough in your native Kingdom of Scotland. If we look to your fir≈øt King Forgu≈øius, that your ≈øtories make mention of, he was an Elective King, he died, and left two Sons both in their minority, the Kingdom made choice
of their Unkle his Brother to govern in the minority; afterwards the Elder Brother giving ≈ømall hopes to the People that he would rule or govern well, ≈øeeking to ≈øupplant that good Unkle of his, that governed them ju≈øtly, they ≈øet the Elder a≈øide, and took to the Younger. Sir, if I ≈øhould come to what your ≈øtories make mention of, you know very well you are the 109th King of Scotland; for to mention ≈øo many Kings as that Kingdom, according to their power and priviledge, have made bold to deal withal, ≈øome to bani≈øh, and ≈øome to impri≈øon, and ≈øome to put to death, it would be too long; and as one of your Authors ≈øayes, it would be too long to recite the manifold examples that your own ≈øtories make mention of; Reges (≈øay they) we do create, we created Kings at fir≈øt; Leges; &c. We impo≈øed Lawes upon them; and as they are cho≈øen by the ≈øuffrages of the People at the fir≈øt, ≈øo upon ju≈øt occa≈øion, by the ≈øame ≈øuffrages, they may be taken down again: and we will be bold to ≈øay, that no Kingdom hath yielded more plentiful experience than that your Native Kingdome of Scotland hath done, concerning the depo≈øition and the puni≈øhment of their offending and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øing Kings, &c.

It is not far to go for an example near you, your Grandmother ≈øet a≈øide, and your Father an Infant crowned; and the State did it here in England; here hath not been a want of ≈øome examples, they have made bold (the Parliament and the People of England) to call their Kings to account, there are frequent examples of it in the Saxons time, the time before the Conque≈øt; ≈øince the Conque≈øt there wants not ≈øome Pre≈øidents neither; King Edward the ≈øecond, King Richard the ≈øecond, were dealt with ≈øo by the Parliament, as they were depo≈øed and
deprived: and truly Sir, whoever ≈øhall look into their ≈øtories, they ≈øhall not find the Articles that are charged upon them to come near to that height and capitalne≈øs of Crimes that are layed to your charge, nothing near.

Sir, you were plea≈øed to ≈øay the other day, wherein they de≈øcend, and I did not contradict it, but take altogether: Sir, if you were as the Charge ≈øpeaks, and no otherwi≈øe admitted K. of England, but for that you were plea≈øed then to alledge, how that almo≈øt for a thou≈øand years the≈øe things have been, ≈øtories will tell you, if you go no higher than the time of the Conque≈øt; if you do come down ≈øince the Conque≈øt, you are the 24th King from William called the Conqueror, you ≈øhall find one half of them to come meerly from the State, and not meerly upon the point of De≈øcent; it were ea≈øie to be in≈øtanced to you, the time mu≈øt not be lo≈øt that way. And truly Sir, what a grave and learned Judge ≈øaid in his time, and well known to you, is ≈øince printed for po≈øterity, That although there was ≈øuch a thing as a De≈øcent many times, yet the Kings of England ever held the greate≈øt a≈ø≈øurance of their titles, when it was declared by Parliament: And Sir, your Oath, the manner of your Coronation doth ≈øhew plainly, That the Kings of England, and though it's true by the Law the next per≈øon in blood is de≈øigned; yet if there were ju≈øt cau≈øe to refu≈øe him, the people of England might do it. For there is a Contract and Bargain made between the King and his People, and your Oath is taken, and certainly Sir, the Bond is reciprocal; for as you are the liege Lord, ≈øo they liege Subjects, and we know very well that hath been ≈øo much ≈øpoken of, Ligantis e≈øt duplex. This we know now, the one tye, the one Bond, is the bond of perfection which is due from the Soveraign, the other is the bond of Subjection
that is due from the Subject. Sir, if this bond be once broken, farewel Soveraignty, Subjectio trahit, &c.

The≈øe things may not be denyed, Sir; I ≈øpeak it the rather, and I pray God it may work upon your heart, that you may be ≈øen≈øible of your mi≈øcarriages. For whether you have been, as by your Office you ought to be, a Protector of England, or the De≈øtroyer of England, let all England judge, or all the world that hath look'd upon it. Sir, though you have it by Inheritance in the way that is ≈øpoken of, yet it mu≈øt not be denyed that your Office was an Office of Tru≈øt, and an Office of the highe≈øt tru≈øt lodged in any ≈øingle per≈øon: For as you were the grand Admini≈øtrator of Ju≈øtice, and others were as your Delegates, to ≈øee it done throughout your Realms, if your great Office were to do Ju≈øtice, and pre≈øerve your People from wrong, and in≈øtead of doing that, you will be the great wrong-doer your ≈øelf; If, in≈øtead of being a Con≈øervator of the Peace, you will be the Grand Di≈øturber of the Peace, ≈øurely this is contrary to your Office, contrary to your Tru≈øt. Now Sir, if it be an Office of Inheritance, as you ≈øpeak of, your Title by De≈øcent, let all men know that great Offices are ≈øeizable and forfeitable, as if you had it but for a year, and for your life; Therefore Sir, it will concern you to take into your ≈øerious con≈øideration your great mi≈øcarriages in this kind.

Truly Sir, I ≈øhall not particularize the many mi≈øcarriages of your Reign what≈øoever, they are famou≈øly known, it had been happy for the Kingdom, and happy for you too, if it had not been ≈øo much known and ≈øo much felt, as the ≈øtory of your mi≈øcarriages mu≈øt needs be, and hath been already.

Sir, That that we are now upon by the command of the highe≈øt Court, hath been and is to Trie and Judge you for great offences of yours. Sir, the Charge hath called you Tyrant, a Traytor, a Murtherer, and a publick Enemy to the Common-wealth of England. Sir, it had been well if that any of all the≈øe terms might rightly and ju≈øtly have been ≈øpared, if any one of them at all.

p.q: Ha?

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p:
Sir, the term Traytor cannot be ≈øpared, we ≈øhall ea≈øily agree it mu≈øt denote and ≈øuppo≈øe a breach of Tru≈øt, and it mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe it to be done by a Superiour; and therefore Sir, as the People of England might have incurred that re≈øpecting you, if they had been truly guilty of it, as to the definition of Law; ≈øo on the other ≈øide, when you did break your Tru≈øt to the Kingdom, you did break your Tru≈øt to your Superior: For the Kingdom is that for which you were tru≈øted: And therefore Sir, for this breach of Tru≈øt, when you are called to account, you are called to account by your Superiors. Minimus ad Majorem in judicium vocat. And Sir, the People of England cannot be ≈øo far wanting to them≈øelves, which God having dealt ≈øo miraculou≈øly and gloriou≈øly for, they having power in their hands, and their great Enemy, they mu≈øt proceed
to do Ju≈øtice to them≈øelves and to you: For, Sir, the Court could heartily de≈øire, That you would lay your hand upon your heart, and con≈øider what you have done ami≈øs: That you would endeavour to make your peace with God. Truly Sir, The≈øe are your high crimes, Tyranny and Trea≈øon.

There is a third thing too, if tho≈øe had not been, and that is Murther, which is laid to your charge. All the bloody Murthers that have been committed ≈øince this time that the Divi≈øion was betwixt you and your People, mu≈øt be laid to your charge, that have been acted or committed in the≈øe late Wars. Sir, it is an heinous and crying ≈øin; and truly Sir, if any man will ask us what puni≈øhment is due to a Murtherer, Let Gods Law, let Mans Law ≈øpeak. Sir, I will pre≈øume that you are ≈øo well read in Scripture, as to know what God him≈øelf hath ≈øaid concerning the ≈øhedding of Mans blood: Gen. 9. Num. 35. will tell you what the puni≈øhment is, and which this Court in behalf of the Kingdom are ≈øen≈øible of, of that innocent blood that has been ≈øhed, whereby indeed the Land ≈øtands ≈øtill defiled with that blood, and as the Text hath it, It can no way be clean≈øed, but with the ≈øhedding of the blood of him that ≈øhed this blood. Sir, we know no Di≈øpen≈øation from this blood in that Commandement, Thou ≈øhalt do no Murder; we do not know but that it extends to Kings, as well as to the meane≈øt Pea≈øants, the meane≈øt of the People, the command is univer≈øal. Sir, Gods Law forbids it, Mans Law forbids it, nor do we know that there is any manner of exception, nor even in mans Laws, for the puni≈øhment of Murther in you. 'Tis true, that in the ca≈øe of Kings every private hand was not to put forth it ≈øelf to this work for their Reformation and puni≈øhment. But Sir, the People repre≈øented having power in their
hands, had there been but one wilful act of Murther by you committed, had power to have convented you, and to have puni≈øhed you for it.

But then Sir, the weight that lies upon you in all tho≈øe re≈øpects that have been ≈øpoken, by rea≈øon of your Tyranny, Trea≈øon, breach of Tru≈øt, and the Murthers that have been committed, ≈øurely Sir, it mu≈øt drive you into a ≈øad con≈øideration concerning your eternal condition: As I ≈øaid at fir≈øt, I know it cannot be plea≈øing to you to hear any ≈øuch things as the≈øe are mentioned unto you from this Court, for ≈øo we do call our ≈øelves, and ju≈øtifie our ≈øelves to be a Court, and a High Court of Ju≈øtice, authorized by the highe≈øt and ≈øolemne≈øt Court of the Kingdom, as we have often ≈øaid; and although you do yet endeavour what you may to di≈ø-court us, yet we do take knowledge of our ≈øelves to be ≈øuch a Court as can admini≈øter Ju≈øtice to you, and we are bound, Sir, in duty to do it. Sir, all I ≈øhall ≈øay before the reading of your Sentence, it is but this; the Court does heartily de≈øire, that you will ≈øeriou≈øly think of tho≈øe evils that you ≈øtand guilty of. Sir, you ≈øaid well to us the other day, you wi≈øht us to have God before our eyes: Truly Sir, I hope all of us have ≈øo, that God that we know is a King of Kings, and Lord of Lords, that God with whom there is no re≈øpect of per≈øons, that God that is the avenger of innocent blood, we have that God before us, that God that does be≈øtow a Cur≈øe upon them that withhold their hands from ≈øhedding of blood, which is the ca≈øe of guilty Malefactors, and that do de≈øerve death; That God we have before our eyes, and were it not that the con≈øcience of our duty hath called us unto this place, and this
imployment, Sir, you ≈øhould have had no appearance of a Court here: but Sir, we mu≈øt prefer the di≈øcharge of our duty unto God, and unto the Kingdom, before any other re≈øpect what≈øoever: and although at this time many of us, if not all of us, are ≈øeverely threatned by ≈øome of your party, what they intend to do. Sir, we do here declare, that we ≈øhall not decline, or forbear the doing of our duty in the admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice even to you, according to the merit of your offence, although God ≈øhould permit tho≈øe men to effect all that bloody de≈øign in hand again≈øt us. Sir, we will ≈øay, and we will declare it, as tho≈øe Children in the fiery Furnace, that would not wor≈øhip the golden Image that Nebuchadnezzar had ≈øet up, That their God was able to deliver them from that danger that they were neer unto; but yet if he would not do it, yet, notwith≈øtanding that, they would not fall down and wor≈øhip the Image: we ≈øhall thus apply it: That though we ≈øhould not be delivered from tho≈øe bloody hands and hearts that con≈øpire the overthrow of the Kingdom in general, of us in particular, for acting in this great work of Ju≈øtice, though we ≈øhould peri≈øh in the work, yet by Gods grace, and by Gods ≈øtrength, we will go on with it: And this is all our Re≈øolutions. Sir, I ≈øay for your ≈øelf, we do heartily wi≈øh and de≈øire, that God would be plea≈øed to give you a ≈øence of your ≈øins, that you would ≈øee wherein you have done ami≈øs, that you may cry unto him, that God would deliver you from bloodguiltine≈øs. A good King was once guilty of that particular thing, and was clear otherwi≈øe, ≈øaving in the matter of ∆≤riah. Truly Sir, the Story tells us, that he was a repentant King, and it ≈øignifies
enough that he had dyed for it, but that God was plea≈øed to accept of him, and to give him his pardon: Thou ≈øhalt not dye, but the Child ≈øhall dye, thou ha≈øt given cau≈øe to the enemies of God to bla≈øpheme.

p.q: I would de≈øire only one word before you give ≈øentence, and that is, That you would hear me concerning tho≈øe great imputations that you have laid to my charge.

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you mu≈øt give me leave to go on, for I am not far from your Sentence, and your time is now pa≈øt.

p.q: But I ≈øhall de≈øire you will hear me a few words to you, for truly whatever Sentence you will put upon me, in re≈øpect of tho≈øe heavy imputations I ≈øee by your ≈øpeech you have put upon me, that I, Sir, it is very true that ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, I mu≈øt put you in mind, Truly Sir, I would not willingly at this time, e≈øpecially, interrupt you in any thing you have to ≈øay, that is proper for us to admit of; but Sir, you have not owned us a Court, and you look upon us as a ≈øort of people met together, and we know what Language we receive from your party.

p.q: I know nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Pre≈ø.
sp.p:
You di≈øavow us as a Court, and therefore for you to addre≈øs your ≈øelf to us, not to acknowledge us as a Court to judge of what You ≈øay, it is not to be permitted; and the truth is, all along from the fir≈øt time, You were plea≈øed to di≈øavow and di≈øown us, the Court needed not to have heard You one word; for unle≈øs they be acknowledged a Court, and engaged, it is not proper for you to ≈øpeak: Sir, we have given you too much liberty already, and admitted of too much delay, and we may not admit of any further; were it proper for us to do, we ≈øhould hear You freely, and we ≈øhould not have declined to
have heard You at large, what you could have ≈øaid or proved on your behalf, whether for totally excu≈øing or for in part excu≈øing tho≈øe great and heinous charges that in whole or in part are laid upon You. But Sir, I ≈øhall trouble You no longer, Your ≈øins are ≈øo large a dimen≈øion, that if you do but ≈øeriou≈øly think of them they will drive you to a ≈øad con≈øideration, they may improve in you a ≈øad and ≈øerious repentance. And that the Court doth heartily wi≈øh, that You may be ≈øo penitent for what You have done ami≈øs, that God may have mercy at lea≈øtwi≈øe upon your better part. Truly Sir, for the other, it is our parts and duties to do that that the Law pre≈øcribes, we are not here Jus dare, but Jus dicere; We cannot be unmindful of what the Scriptures tell us, For to acquit the guilty is of equal abomination as to condemn the innocent; we may not acquit the guilty; what Sentence the Law affirms to a Traitor, Tyrant, a Murtherer, and a publick Enemy to the Countrey, that Sentence you are now to hear read unto you, and that is the Sentence of the Court
The Lord Pre≈øident commands the Sentence to be read. Make an O Yes, and command ≈øilence while the Sentence is read.
O Yes made, ≈øilence commanded.
The Clerk read the Sentence, which was drawn up in parchment.

Whereas the Commons of England in Parliament have appointed them an high Court of Ju≈øtice for the Trying of Charles Stuart King of England, before whom he had been three times convented, and at fir≈øt time a charge of high Trea≈øon, and other crimes and mi≈ødemeanors was read in the behalf of the Kingdom of England, &c.
Here the Clerk read the Charge.

Which Charge being read unto him as afore≈øaid, He the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, was required to give his
An≈øwer, but he refu≈øed ≈øo to do, and ≈øo expre≈øt the ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages at his Tryal in refu≈øing to an≈øwer.

For all which Trea≈øons and Crimes, this Court doth adjudge, That the ≈øaid Charles Stuart, as a Tyrant, Traytor, Murtherer, and a publique Enemy, ≈øhall be put to Death, by the ≈øevering his Head from his Body.
sp.stage: After the Sentence read, the Lord Pre≈øident ≈øaid,
sp.p: This Sentence now read and publi≈øhed, it is the Act, Sentence, Judgment, and Re≈øolution of the whole Court.
Here the Court ≈øtood up, and a≈ø≈øenting to what the Pre≈øident ≈øaid.

p.q: Will you hear me a word Sir?

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: Sir, you are not to be heard after the Sentence.

p.q: No Sir?

sp.speaker: Pre≈øident.
sp.p: No Sir, by your favour Sir: Guard withdraw your Pri≈øoner.

sp.speaker: King.

q.p: By your favour Sir, I may ≈øpeak after the ≈øentence ever.

sp.p: By your favour (hold) the ≈øentence Sir‚Äî

q.p: I am not ≈øuffered for to ≈øpeak, expect what Ju≈øtice other people will have.

div.p: O Yes, All manner of per≈øons that have any thing el≈øe to do, are to depart at this time, and to give their attendance in the Painted Chamber, to which place this Court doth forthwith adjourn it ≈øelf.
Then the Court ro≈øe, and the King went with his Guard to Sir Robert Cottons, and from thence to White-Hall.

list.head: The Names of tho≈øe Per≈øons that were pre≈øent at the Sentencing of the KING to Death.

p.q: Ordered that Sir Hardre≈øs Waller, Coll. Harri≈øon, Com. General Ireton, Coll. Dean, and Coll. Okey, are appointed a Committee to con≈øider of the Time and Place for the Execution of the King, according to his Sentence given by the high Court of Ju≈øtice.

div.p: Upon report made from the Committee for con≈øidering of the Time and Place of the Executing of the Judgement again≈øt the King: that the ≈øaid Committee have re≈øolved that the open Street before White-hall is a fit place; And that the ≈øaid Committee conceive it fit, that the King be there Executed the morrow, the King having already notice thereof; The Court approved thereof, and ordered a Warrant to be drawn for that purpo≈øe, which Warrant was accordingly drawn and agreed unto; and ordered to be ingro≈ø≈øed, which was done, and Signed and Sealed accordingly, as followeth.

body.head: At the High Court of Ju≈øtice for the Trying and Judging of Charles Stuart King of England, January 29, 1648.
body.p:
WHereas Charles Stuart King of England, is, and ≈øtandeth Convicted, Attainted and Condemned of high Trea≈øon, and other high Crimes, and Sentence upon Saturday la≈øt was pronounced again≈øt
him by this Court, to be put to death by the ≈øevering of his head from his body; of which Sentence, Execution yet remains to be done: The≈øe are therefore to will and require you to ≈øee the ≈øaid Sentence Executed in the open ≈øtreet before White-Hall, upon the morrow, being the 30th day of this in≈øtant month of January, between the hours of Ten in the morning, and Five in the afternoon of the ≈øame day, with full effect; And for ≈øo doing, this ≈øhall be your ≈øufficient Warrant. And the≈øe are to require all Officers and Souldiers, and other the good people of this Nation of England, to be a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto you in this ≈øervice.

closer.dateline: Given under our Hands and Seals.
