body.trailer: To Coll. Francis Hacker, Coll. Huncks, and Lieuten. Coll. Phray, and to every of them:

closer.signed: Sealed and ≈øub≈øcribed by J. Brad≈øhaw, O, Cromwell, Hen. Ireton, Har. Waller, Jo. Li≈øle, Val. Walton, Tho. Gray, Ed. Whaley, Mich. Live≈øey, Jo. Okey, Jo. Danvers, Tho. Maleverer, Wil. Goffe, Tho. Pride, Tho. Harri≈øon, Jo. Hew≈øon, Ri. Dean, Robert Tichborn, Ow. Roe, Jo. Bark≈øtead, G. Fleetwood, Gil. Milington, Tho. Horton, W. Say, W. Con≈øtable, Miles Corbet, Jo. Ven, Hen. Martin. &c.

div.p: The Commi≈ø≈øioners met, and ordered, That Mr. Mar≈øhall, Mr. Nye, Mr. Caryll, Mr. Salway, and Mr. Dell, be de≈øired to attend the King, to admini≈øter to him tho≈øe Spiritual helps as ≈øhould be ≈øuitable to his pre≈øent condition, and Lieutenant Collonel Goffe is de≈øired forthwith to repair unto them for that purpo≈øe.
Who did ≈øo, but after informed the Court, That the King being acquainted therewith, refu≈øed to confer with them, expre≈ø≈øing that he would not be troubled with them.
Ordered, That the Scaffold upon which the King is to be executed, be covered with Black.

The Warrant for executing the King being accordingly delivered to tho≈øe parties to whom the ≈øame was directed, Execution was done upon him according to the tenour of the Warrant about two of the Clock in the Afternoon of the ≈øaid 30. of January.

After Sentence, The King being hurried from their Bar, as he pa≈ø≈øed down the ≈øtairs, the common Souldiers (laying a≈øide all Reverence to Soveraignty) ≈øcoffed at him, ca≈øting the ≈ømoak of their ≈øtinking Tobacco in his face (no Smell more offen≈øive to him) and flinging their foul pipes at his feet; But one more in≈øolent than the re≈øt, defiled his venerable Face with his ≈øpittle, for his Maje≈øty was ob≈øerved with much patience to wipe it off with his Handkerchief, and as he pa≈ø≈øed, hearing them cry out Ju≈øtice, Ju≈øtice, Poor ≈øoul (≈øaid he) for a piece if money, they would doe ≈øo for their Commanders. That Night being Saturday, January 27. the King lodged at White-Hall; that evening a Member of the Army (acquainted the Committee) with the de≈øires of the King, that ≈øeeing they had pa≈ø≈øed Sentence of Death upon him, and the time of his Execution might be nigh, that he might ≈øee his Children, and receive the Sacrament, and that Dr. Juxon Bi≈øhop of London, might be admitted to pray with him in his private Chamber; both which were granted.

The next day, being Sunday, January 28. the King was attended by his Guard, to Saint James's, where the Bi≈øhop of London preached privately before him; his Text was in Rom. 2.16. In the day when God ≈øhall judge the ≈øecrets of all men by Je≈øus Chri≈øt, according to my Go≈øpel.

Monday Jan. 29. His Children were permitted to come to him, where pa≈ø≈øed this following Di≈øcour≈øe, as it was ≈øet down in writing by his Daughter the Lady Elizabeth (which Lady Elizabeth ≈øome months after, being confined to Carisbrough-Ca≈øtle in the I≈øle of Wight, died there with grief for the ≈øufferings of her Dear Father.)

p.q: His Children being come to meet him, He fir≈øt gave his Ble≈ø≈øing to the Lady Elizabeth, and bad her to remember to tell her Brother James, whenever ≈øhe ≈øhould ≈øee him, that it was his Fathers la≈øt de≈øire that he ≈øhould no more look upon Charles as his elde≈øt Brother only, but be obedient unto him as his Soveraign; and that they ≈øhould love one another, and forgive their Fathers Enemies. Then ≈øaid the King to her, Sweet-heart you'l forget this: No (≈øaid ≈øhe) I ≈øhall never forget it while≈øt I live; and pouring forth abundance of tears, promi≈øed him to write down the particulars.

div.p: Then the King taking the Duke of Gloce≈øter upon his knee, ≈øaid, Sweet-heart, now they will cut off thy Fathers head (upon which words the Child looking very ≈øtedfa≈øtly on him,) Mark child what I ≈øay, They will cut off my head, and perhaps make thee a King: But mark what I ≈øay, you mu≈øt not be a King, ≈øo long as your brothers, Charles and James, do live; for they will cut off your Brothers heads (when they can catch them) and cut off thy head too at la≈øt: and therefore I charge you do not be made a King by them. At which the child ≈øighing ≈øaid, I will be torn in pieces fir≈øt: which falling ≈øo unexpectedly from one ≈øo young, it made the King rejoyce exceedingly.

Tue≈øday Jan. 30. (The Fatal Day) He was about Ten of the Clock brought from his Pallace at Saint
James's to White-Hall, marched on foot (guarded with a Regiment of foot Souldiers) through the Park, with their Colours flying, and Drums beating, his private Guard of Partizans about him, Dr. Juxon Bi≈øhop of London on one ≈øide, and Collon. Tomlin≈øon on the other, both bare-headed, bidding them go fa≈øter, ≈øaying That he now went before them to ≈øtrive for an heavenly Crown with le≈øs ≈øolicitude, than he had oftentimes bid his Souldiers to fight for an Earthly Diadem. Being come to the end of the Park, he a≈øcends the Staris leading to the long Gallery in White-Hall, and ≈øo into the Cabinet Chamber, where he formerly u≈øed to Lodge; there his Maje≈øty with the Bi≈øhop of London continued for ≈øome time in Devotion, and received the ble≈ø≈øed Sacrament from the hand of the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop; at which time he read for the ≈øecond Le≈ø≈øon, the 27. Chapter of Saint Matthews Go≈øpel, which contained the Hi≈øtory of the Death and Pa≈ø≈øion of our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviour; the Communion ended, his Maje≈øty thanked the Bi≈øhop for ≈øelecting ≈øo ≈øea≈øonable and comfortable a portion of Scripture. The Bi≈øhop mode≈øtly replied, No thanks were due to him, for it was the Chapter appointed by the Rubrick of the Church for the ≈øecond morning Le≈ø≈øon for that day being Jan. 30. Here the King continued at his Devotion, refu≈øing to dine, onely about Twelve of the Clock, he eat a bit of bread, and drank a Gla≈øs of Claret, from thence about one a Clock he was accompanied by Dr. Juxon and Coll. Thomlin≈øon, and other Officers formerly appointed to attend him, and the private Guard of Partizans, with Mu≈øketeers on each ≈øide, through the Banquetting-hou≈øe, adjoyning to which the Scaffold was erected, between White-hall Gate, and the Gate leading into the Gallery from Saint James's: The
Scaffold was hung round with Black, the Floor covered with black Bayes, and the Ax and Block laid in the middle of the Scaffold. There were divers Companies of Foot of Collonel Prides Regiment, and ≈øeveral Troops of Hor≈øe placed on the one ≈øide of the Scaffold toward Kings-≈øtreet, and on the other ≈øide toward Charing-Cro≈øs, and the multitudes of people that came to be Spectators very great. The King being come upon the Scaffold, it was expected he would ≈øay ≈øomewhat to the people, the which he did.

But becau≈øe we have no other Relation of what his Maje≈øty then ≈øpake, ≈øave what was taken in ≈øhort hand on the Scaffold by three ≈øeveral Gentlemen, who were very exqui≈øite in that Art; nor had his Maje≈øty any Copy (being ≈øurprized and ha≈øtened by tho≈øe who attended him to the Scaffold,) ≈øave only a few heads in a little ≈øcrip of Paper, which after his death, the Souldiers took from the Bi≈øhop of London, to whom he gave it: Therefore the Reader mu≈øt be content with this Copy, which was by them upon joynt comparing of their Copies publi≈øhed, ≈øome few words being altered to make the ≈øence perfect.

The King being come upon the Scaffold, and looking about him upon the people, who were kept off by Troops of Hor≈øe, ≈øo that they could not come near to hear him, omitted what he had purpo≈øed to have ≈øpoken to them (as 'tis thought) and turning him≈øelf to the Soldiers and Officers (the In≈øtruments of the Regicide) ≈øpake to them to this effect‚ñ™

body.head: The King being come upon the Scaffold, look'd very carne≈øtly upon the Block, and asked Coll. Hacker if there were no higher: and then ≈øpake thus (directing his Speech chiefly to Coll. Thomlin≈øon.)

q.p:
I Shall be very little heard of any body here, I ≈øhall therefore ≈øpeak a word unto you here: indeed I could hold my peace very well, if I did not think that holding my peace would make ≈øome men think, that I did ≈øubmit to the Guilt as well as to the Puni≈øhment; but I think it is my duty to God fir≈øt, and to my Country, for to clear my ≈øelf both as an hone≈øt Man, a good King, and a good Chri≈øtian. I ≈øhall begin fir≈øt with my Innocency; In troth, I think it not very needful for me to in≈øi≈øt long upon this, for all the world knows that I never did begin a War with the two hou≈øes of Parliament, and I call God to witne≈øs, to whom I mu≈øt ≈øhortly make an account. That I never did intend for to encroach upon their Priviledges, they began upon me; it is the Militia they began upon, they confe≈øt that the Militia was mine, but they thought it fit for to have it from me: and to be ≈øhort, if any body will look to the dates of Commi≈ø≈øions, of their Commi≈ø≈øions and mine, and likewi≈øe to the Declarations, will ≈øee clearly that they began the≈øe unhappy troubles, not I: ≈øo that as to the guilt of the≈øe enormous Crimes that are laid again≈øt me, I hope in God that God will clear me of; I will not, I am in charity: God
forbid that I ≈øhould lay it upon the two Hou≈øes of Parliament, there is no nece≈ø≈øity of either, I hope they are free of this guilt: for I do believe that ill in≈øtruments between them and me, has been the chief cau≈øe of all this blood≈øhed: ≈øo that by way of ≈øpeaking, as I find my ≈øelf clear of this, I hope (and pray God) that they may too: yet for all this, God forbid that I ≈øhould be ≈øo ill a Chri≈øtian as not to ≈øay that Gods judgments are ju≈øt upon me: Many times he does pay Ju≈øtice by an unju≈øt Sentence, that is ordinary. I will only ≈øay this, That unju≈øt Sentence Strafford. that I ≈øuffered for to take effect, is puni≈øhed now by an unju≈øt Sentence upon me: So far I have ≈øaid, to ≈øhew you that I am an Innocent man.

Now for to ≈øhew you that I am a good Chri≈øtian: I hope there is ( Strafford. Pointing to Dr. Juxon,) a good man that will bear me witne≈øs, That I have forgiven all the world, and even tho≈øe in particular that have been the chief cau≈øers of my death; who they are, God knows, I do not de≈øire to know, I pray God forgive them. But this is not all, my Charity mu≈øt go further, I wi≈øh that they may repent, for indeed they have committed a great ≈øin in that particular: I pray God with St. Stephen, that this be not laid to their charge, nay not only ≈øo, but that they may take the right way to the peace of the Kingdom; for my Charity commands me, not only to forgive particular men, but my Charity commands me to endeavour to the la≈øt ga≈øp the Peace of the Kingdom. So (Sir) I do wi≈øh with all my Soul (and I do hope there is ≈øome here Turning to ≈øome Gentlemen that wrote. will carry it
further) that they may endeavour the Peace of the Kingdom.

Now (Sirs) I mu≈øt ≈øhew you both how you are out of the way, and will put you in the way: Fir≈øt, you are out of the way, for certainly all the way you ever have had yet, as I could find by any thing, is in the way of Conque≈øt; certainly this is an ill way: for Conque≈øt (Sir) in my opinion is never ju≈øt, except there be a good ju≈øt Cau≈øe, either for matter of wrong, or ju≈øt Title, and then if you goe beyond it, the fir≈øt quarrel that you have to it, is it that makes it unju≈øt at the end that was ju≈øt at fir≈øt: But if it be only matter of Conque≈øt, then it is a great Robbery, as a Pirate ≈øaid to Alexander, that he was the great Robber, he was but a petty Robber: and ≈øo, Sir, I doe think the way that you are in, is much out of the way. Now, Sir, for to put you in one way, believe it, you will never do right, nor God will never pro≈øper you, until you give God his due, the King his due (that is, my Succe≈ø≈øors) and the People their due: I am as much for them as any of you: You mu≈øt give God his due, by regulating rightly his Church, (according to his Scriptures) which is now out of order: For to ≈øet you in a way particularly, now I cannot, but only this, A National Synod freely called, freely debating among them≈øelves, mu≈øt ≈øettle this; when that every Opinion is freely and clearly heard.

For the King, indeed I will not‚Äî (Then turning to a Gentleman that touched the Ax, ≈øaid, Hurt not the Ax, that may hurt Meaning if he did blunt the edge. me.) For the King, the Laws of the Land will clearly in≈øtruct you for that; therefore, becau≈øe it concerns my own particular, I only give you a touch of it.

For the people: and truly I de≈øire their Liberty and freedom as much as any body who≈øoever, but I mu≈øt tell you, that their Liberty and freedom con≈øi≈øts in having of Government, tho≈øe Laws by which their Life and their Goods may be mo≈øt their own. It is not for having ≈øhare in Government, (Sir) that is nothing pertaining to them: A Subject and a Soveraign are clean different things, and therefore until they do that, I mean, That you do put the people in that Liberty, as I ≈øay, certainly they will never enjoy them≈øelves.

Sir, It was for this that now I am come here: If I would have given way to an Arbitrarie way, for to have all Laws changed according to the power of the Sword, I needed not to have come here; and therefore I tell you (and I pray God it be not laid to your charge) that I am the Martyr of the people.

Introth Sirs, I ≈øhall not hold you much longer, for I will onely ≈øay this to you, that in truth I could have de≈øired ≈øome little time longer, becau≈øe I would have put this that I have ≈øaid in a little more order, and a little better dige≈øted than I have done, and therefore I hope you will excu≈øe me.
I have delivered my Con≈øcience, I pray God that you doe take tho≈øe cour≈øes that are be≈øt for the good of the Kingdom, and your own ≈øalvations.

p.hi: Will your Maje≈øty (though it may be very well known, your Maje≈øties affections to Religion, yet it may be expected that you ≈øhould) ≈øay ≈øomewhat for the worlds ≈øatisfaction.

p.q:
I thank you very heartily (my Lord) for that I had almo≈øt forgotten it. Introth Sirs, My Con≈øcience in Religion I think is very well known to all the world, and therefore I declare before you
all, That I die a Chri≈øtian, according to the profe≈ø≈øion of the Church of England, as I found it left me by my Father, and this hone≈øt man
Pointing to Dr. Juxon. I think will witne≈øs it. Then turning to the Officers ≈øaid, Sirs, excu≈øe me for this ≈øame, I have a good cau≈øe, and I have a gracious God, I will ≈øay no more. Then turning to Colonel Hacker, he ≈øaid, Take care they doe not put me to pain, and Sir, this, and it plea≈øe you. But then a Gentleman coming near the Ax, the King ≈øaid, Take heed of the Ax, pray take heed of the Ax. Then the King ≈øpeaking to the Executioner, ≈øaid, I ≈øhall ≈øay but very ≈øhort Prayers, and when I thru≈øt out my hands‚Äî

div.p: Then the King called to Doctor Juxon for his Night-cap, and having put it on, he ≈øaid to the Executioner, Does my hair trouble you? who de≈øired him to put it all under his Cap, which the King did accordingly by the help of the Executioner and the Bi≈øhop: then the King turning to Doctor Juxon, ≈øaid, I have a good Cau≈øe, and a gracious God on my ≈øide.

sp.speaker: Doctor Juxon.
sp.p: There is but one Stage more, this Stage is turbulent and trouble≈øome, it is a ≈øhort one: But you may con≈øider, it will ≈øoon carry you a very great way: it will carry you from Earth to Heaven; and there you ≈øhall find a great deal of cordial joy and comfort.

p.hi: I goe from a corruptible to an incorruptible Crown; where no di≈øturbance can be, no di≈øturbance in the world.

sp.speaker: Doctor Juxon.
sp.p: You are exchanged from a Temporal to an Eternal Crown, a good exchange.

The King then ≈øaid to the Executioner, Is my hair well? Then the King took off his Cloak and his George, giving his George to Doctor Juxon, ≈øaying,
Remember (* It is thought for to give it to the Prince.) Then the King put off his Doublet, and being in his Wa≈øtcoat, put his Cloak on again, then looking upon the Block, ≈øaid to the Executioner, You mu≈øt ≈øet it fa≈øt.

sp.speaker: Executioner.
sp.p: It is fa≈øt, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: When I put my hands out this way, ≈øtretching them out, them‚Äî

div.p: After that, having ≈øaid two or three words (as he ≈øtood) to him≈øelf, with hands and eyes lift up; Immediately ≈øtooping down, laid his Neck upon the Block: and then the Executioner again putting his hair under his Cap, the King ≈øaid (thinking he had been going to ≈øtrike) Stay for the ≈øign.

sp.speaker: Executioner.
sp.p: Yes, I will and it plea≈øe your Maje≈øty.

div.p: After the Regicides had committed this Horrid and nefarious Act, the prevailing Power con≈øi≈øting of a patcht number of the Hou≈øe of Commons, and the chief Officers of the Army, combined together, and ≈øeeing how ≈øucce≈øsfully and unoppo≈øed they had effected this ≈øo unparalel'd a Deed, to which they knew the generality of the Nation were utterly aver≈øe, and as far as they dur≈øt, ≈øhew'd their ab≈øolute di≈ølike; They in the next place fall upon the alteration of the Government, thinking to make ≈øure work by ≈øubverting the Ancient Monarchy of this Realm, and in≈øtead thereof introducing that which they called a Free State, or Common-wealth. For con≈øtituting of which the fir≈øt thing they did, was to Vote and publi≈øh by Proclamation, That whereas ≈øeveral pretences might be made to the Crown, &c. to the apparent hazard of the publick Peace, no Per≈øon what≈øoever ≈øhould pre≈øume to proclaim or any way promote Charles Stuart, Son of the ≈øaid Charles late King of England, or any other per≈øon to be King or chief Magi≈øtrate, &c. by colour of Inheritance, or any other claim what≈øoever, without the free Con≈øent of the People in Parliament; fir≈øt ≈øignified by a particular Act for that purpo≈øe, any Law or Cu≈øtom to the contrary notwith≈øtanding; and who≈øoever ≈øhould contrary to this Order proclaim, &c. ≈øhall be adjudged a Traytor, and ≈øuffer accordingly.

This proceeding was founded upon a Maxim which they had taken up, and agreed on among them≈øelves, namely, That all Power and Authority is Originally in the People: But well knowing that their
Councils had ≈øoon been confounded, and them≈øelves interrupted in the cour≈øe they had begun, if they had incorporated again with tho≈øe of their Members which had been forcibly kept out by the Army, they Re≈øolve and decree, 1. That all tho≈øe Members who had a≈ø≈øented to the Vote of Decemb. 5. concerning the Kings Conce≈ø≈øions (for that was the occa≈øion of their ≈øeclu≈øion) ≈øhould never be readmitted, and that tho≈øe that Voted in the Negative, ≈øhould pre≈øently enter their ≈øaid di≈ø≈øent, or before they were to be admitted.

And together with the fortune of Monarchy was involved that of the Hou≈øe of Peers, who having ≈øent to de≈øire a Conference about ≈øetling the Government, in regard the Judges Commi≈ø≈øions were determined by the Kings Death, in≈øtead of an An≈øwer to their Me≈ø≈øage, the Junto of the Commons upon debate Voted, the Lords Hou≈øe to be u≈øele≈øs and dangerous, and therefore to be laid a≈øide, as in like manner they declared the Kingly Office to be unnece≈ø≈øary and Burthen≈øom, and therefore fit to be aboli≈øhed; only they allowed the Lords the Priviledge of being capable to be cho≈øen Burge≈ø≈øes into the Hou≈øe of Commons; But the Lords were ≈øo highly incen≈øed thereat, that there was ≈øuddenly publi≈øhed a Declaration in the name of all the Peers and Barons of the Realm, wherein they prote≈øt again≈øt the Proceedings of the Commons. And a while after ≈øome of the Kings friends in de≈øpite of all Votes, Acts, and Orders to the contrary, promoted a Proclamation, in the name of all the Nobility, Gentry, and Commonalty of the Kingdom, for proclaiming Charles our pre≈øent Soveraign to be King of England.

But little could unarmed Declarations prevail again≈øt the reigning Power of an Armed faction, who now a≈ø≈øumed new En≈øigns of Soveraignty, cancelling the Old, and cau≈øed all Writs, Commi≈ø≈øions, and
In≈øtruments of publick Concernment, to be i≈ø≈øued out under a new Stile and Te≈øt, that is of, The Keepers of the Liberties of England by Authority of Parliament. They ordered the old Great Seal to be broken, and a new one to be made, with the Arms of England and Ireland on one ≈øide, and this In≈øcription, The Great Seal of England; and on the other ≈øide the Hou≈øe of Commons with this In≈øcription, In the fir≈øt Year of Freedom by Gods ble≈ø≈øing re≈øtored, 1648. and appointed the Money to bear the Arms of England and Ireland, with this Motto, God with us; and the Great Seal was intru≈øted with three Commi≈ø≈øioners: They likewi≈øe cau≈øed the Kings Arms to be pulled down every where, and the Kings Picture in the Old Exchange they cau≈øed to be defaced, and the following In≈øcription to be be ≈øet behind it in Golden Letters: Exit Tyrannus Regum ultimus, Anno Libertatis Angliae Re≈øtitutae Primo, Anno 1648. Jan. 30.

They next proceed to erect another Illegal High Court of Ju≈øtice, wherein they brought to Tryall D. Hamilton taken at the fight at Pre≈øton, the E. of Holland at King≈øton Fight, and the L. Capell and L. Goring taken at the Seige of Colche≈øter; The three fir≈øt were Condemned and beheaded at the Palaceyard at We≈øtmin≈øter; After this the L. Fairfax having laid down his Commi≈ø≈øion, the Parliament made Oliver Cromwell their General, who a while after was ≈øent into Ireland, where he proved very ≈øucce≈øsfull.

His Maje≈øty was now in France, and hoped to get aid there, but found none; but the Junto proceeded to make Sale of the King and Queens Lands, and made a formal Act for aboli≈øhing Kingly Government and di≈øinheriting the Roval I≈ø≈øue, and ≈øeting up a Republick or Free State; This Act Alderman Reynard≈øon was commanded to proclaim in the City, which he refu≈øing, was committed to the Tower, with three Aldermen
more; and a new Lord Maior was cho≈øen by a Common-Hall, who attended with ≈øeveral other Aldermen as complyant as him≈øelf, readily obeyed the Commands of his Ma≈øters, and proclaimed their Edict in ≈øeveral places of the City.

A while after, His Maje≈øty was ≈øolemnly Proclaimed in Scotland, and after great debate among them there, they at length agree on ≈øome Propo≈øitions to be ≈øent to the King, who was then in the I≈øle of Jer≈øey, and Mr. Windram Laird of Libberton was appointed Me≈ø≈øenger; who bringing them to the King, they were ≈øtiffly debated on each ≈øide; but at la≈øt Breda in Holland was appointed for the place of a Solemn Treaty, where Commi≈ø≈øioners from the E≈øtates and Kirk met the King, and delivered their Propo≈øitions: During which Treaty, the Marque≈øs of Montro≈øs was ≈øeized in Scotland, and for oppo≈øing the Kirk Party, was condemned and Executed upon a Gibbet near fifty foot high, with all imaginable Contempt; which His Maje≈øty having an Account of, was much troubled, and the Treaty had like to have been broken off, but at length through the nece≈ø≈øity of Affairs was concluded, and being carryed to Edenburgh, after much debate it was re≈øolved, another Me≈ø≈øage ≈øhould be ≈øent to invite the King over; but the Parliament here in England having notice of all the≈øe Proceedings in Scotland, prepared an Army thereupon to invade Scotland, under the command of their General Oliver Cromwell.

About this time General Blake their Admiral, took, ≈øunk and burnt mo≈øt of Prince Ruperts Fleet, which was a great damage to the Kings Affairs. And now the King being arrived at Spey in the North of Scotland, ≈øome Lords were ≈øent down to accompany him to Edenburgh: As he came along he was entertained with the general Joy of all the People, and at Aberdeen he was pre≈øented with 1500 Pounds, which thing was
ill taken by the Committee of E≈øtates, and Kirk; and therefore they ≈øent an Injunction to prohibit other Places from doing the like; The King being now come to Edenburgh was again Proclaimed King, July 15. 1650. but his Coronation was deferred by rea≈øon of the then Troubles, ≈øince the Engli≈øh Army was upon the Borders, and the Scots now began to think how to defend them≈øelves, and therefore marched under the Command of Montgomery and ≈øet upon the Engli≈øh at Mu≈øcleborough, but were wor≈øted by them, and at Dunbar the Engli≈øh wholly routed them, taking the pa≈øs there.

At the ≈øame time the Scots were divided among them≈øelves into three Parties, but the King returning with Montgomery to St. John≈øtons they were all reconciled, and the King on Jan. 1. 1650. was Crowned at Scone; and ≈øoon after ≈øet up his Standard at Aberdeen, re≈øolving to be him≈øelf Generali≈ø≈øimo of the Scotch Army; About which time Sir Hen. Hyde was beheaded at London for his Loyalty; and not long after Captain Brown Bu≈øhell received the like Doom, for performing ≈øome ≈øignall ≈øervices to the King; the King began to fortifie Sterlang, and the Engli≈øh drew near it: and Cromwell perceiving he could not draw the Scots to a Field Battel, ≈øuddenly tran≈øported over Fyfe 1600 foot, and four Troops of Hor≈øe, who with the help of Lambert and Okey, routed the Scots under Sir John Brown, taking him and ≈øeveral other Per≈øons of Quality Pri≈øoners, killing 2000 on the place, and taking about 120 Pri≈øoners; not long after Mr. Gibbons and Mr. Love were Beheaded on Tower-hill upon the di≈øcovery of a Plot in England again≈øt the Parliament by the Presbyterians.

The King ≈øeeing the Engli≈øh prevail ≈øo fa≈øt, thought it be≈øt to quit Scotland, and ≈øo Marched for England, July 30. 1651. which Cromwell ob≈øerving, ≈øent Lambert after him with a ≈øelect Party of Hor≈øe: The Kings Army being now in England, the Parliament cau≈øed numerous Forces to be rai≈øed in mo≈øt Counties in England, and his Maje≈øty marched on to Worce≈øter and fortified it: In the mean time Maj. General Lambert gained the pa≈øs at ∆≤pton, by a de≈øperate attempt, in cau≈ø≈øing ≈øome of his Troopers to ≈øwim the River on Hor≈øeback, carrying their Pi≈øtols and Hol≈øters in their hands, to ≈øave them from wet: whereby they put Maj. Gen. Ma≈ø≈øey and his men to the Retreat, ≈øo that the Kings Party was forced to quit the Town, and leave the pa≈øs to the Parliamentarians, who quickly made a Bridge over the River; and Cromwell joining with the re≈øt of the Forces again≈øt the King, after ≈øome Sallies out of the Town again≈øt them, at length the King in the Front of his men, ≈øallied out of Town on Sept. 3. 1651. and ≈øo valianty charged Cromwells Life-Guard, that they were forced to retire, till ≈øeconded by fre≈øh Forces, they put the Kings Party to the Retreat; and the King had his Hor≈øe twice ≈øhot under him, and not able to
rally again, they were forced to fly into the Town, where Cromwells Party entered Pell Mell with them, and then the Cry went, Save the King, Save the King.

The King ≈øeeing all lo≈øt, with ≈øome of his Nobles and Servants, e≈øcaped with much difficulty to a Farmers hou≈øe in Stafford-≈øhire, where he di≈ørobed him≈øelf, and for want of Sci≈ø≈øers had his Hair out off with a Knife; and ≈øo with the Company of one Friend (who brought him Provi≈øion towards night) he betook him≈øelf to a Wood, where he made an Oak his Palace; the Souldiers hunting about for him, and a thou≈øand Pound promi≈øed as a Reward to tho≈øe that could take him; It is ≈øuppo≈øed there were about three thou≈øand ≈ølain at Worce≈øter, and ≈øeven hundred taken Pri≈øoners, and not long after the E. of Derby who was one of them, was Beheaded at Bolton in Lanca≈øhire.

His Maje≈øty through many dangers and difficulties arrived at la≈øt ≈øafely at Paris in France; And a while after Oliver Cromwell, April 20. 1653. Di≈ø≈øolved the long Parliament, which had ≈øate Twelve years, ≈øix months and ≈øeventeen days. In this year and the next, there were five bloody Engagements at Sea again≈øt the Dutch, in mo≈øt of which the Engli≈øh were Victorious. Oliver Cromwell called another Junto this year, which was termed the Little Parliament, who ≈øate ≈øome ≈øhort time, and then delivered back their Power to him from whom they had received it; And December 16. 1653. Cromwell was Sworn Lord Protector of England, Scotland and Ireland, &c. And ≈øo the Government was now again in a ≈øingle Per≈øon, and in April after, the Protector concluded a Peace with the Dutch, who≈øe aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance the King had ≈øtrongly ≈øollicited again≈øt him.

His Maje≈øty after this ≈øought a Reconciliation between France and Spain, and hoping thereby to further his own Intere≈øt, he left France, and departed for Germany, accompanied with his Cou≈øin Prince Rupert; about which time Cromwell had di≈øcovered a Plot in England again≈øt his Authority, and Collonel Gerrard and Mr. Vowell ≈øuffered for the ≈øame at Tower-Hill; Scotland began likewi≈øe to ≈øtir again, the Earl of Glencarn, Monro, and Middleton having gotten ≈øome Forces together, intended to have pro≈øecuted the Kings Cau≈øe, but they were routed by General Monk and Collonel Morgan.

According to the Treaty with France, Cromwell ≈øent over ≈øome Forces to aid the French in his Wars again≈øt Flanders, and the Engli≈øh were to have Dunkirk in con≈øideration thereof, which upon taking of it was accordingly delivered. In the ≈øame year 1656. Cromwell by a Parliament garbled to his mind, was in≈øtalled L. Protector in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall: and a while after, another Plot was di≈øcovered; Sir Henry Slingsby, Dr. Hewet, Mr. A≈øton, and Mr. Stacy, ≈øuffered Death upon the ≈øame Account, the two fir≈øt being beheaded, and the other Drawn, Hanged and Quartered, being charged to be concerned therein.

Upon Sept. 3. 1658. O. Cromwell departed this life in Whitehall, and lay in State in Somer ≈øet-hou≈øe till Nov. 23. following, when he was buried with great Pomp in We≈øtmin≈øter Abby‚ñ™ After whom his Son Richard Succeeded, but was ≈øoon thru≈øt out of his Protector≈øhip by Fleetwood and Lambert, who with the re≈øt of the Army called the Long Parliament again; after. which ≈øeveral Gentlemen in Che≈øhire, under the conduct of Sir George Booth ro≈øe for defence of their Priviledges, but were defeated by Lambert; who ≈øoon after turned out this remnant of the Long Parliament again, and erected a Government which they called the Committee of Safety. All which Revolutions ≈øtill advanced the Kings Cau≈øe; Lambert now Marches North as far as New-Ga≈øtle to fight again≈øt General Monk, but his men were unwilling to engage; and in the mean time the remainder of the Long Parliament had again gotten together, and di≈ø≈øolved the Committee of Safety, and then invited General Monk to march with his Army to London, which he did accordingly, and was received with Joy, and ≈øoon after he procured the Di≈ø≈øolution of that Long Parliament; and he calling another upon April 25. 1660. who being ≈øate, unanimou≈øly Voted the re≈øtoration of his Maje≈øty to his Kingdoms, and accordingly upon May 29. following the King accompanied with the Dukes of York and Gloce≈øter, and attended with ≈øeveral Lords and Gentlemen, arrived at Dover, where he was met by divers Noble Per≈øonages, and among the re≈øt General Monk, who was dignified with the George and Garter.

In October following, ≈øeveral of the Regicides of the late King were Tryed in the Old Baily, and ten of them Executed at Charing-Cro≈øs; that is, Thomas Harri≈øon, John Carew, Adrian Scroop, John Jones, Gregory Clement, Thomas Scot, John Cook, Hugh Peters, Francis Hacker, and Daniel Axtell.

Mary Prince≈øs of Orange coming over to Vi≈øit the King her Brother, fell ≈øick of the Small Pox and dyed; and in January after, one Vennor a Wine-cooper, and ≈øome others in whom he had infu≈øed Enthu≈øia≈øtick Principles, put them≈øelves in Arms, and came into the City, but being oppo≈øed, they killed 22 of his Maje≈øties Subjects, and about as many of them were ≈ølain, and the re≈øt were taken and di≈øper≈øed; eleven of whom, and Vennor their leader, were executed in ≈øeveral places in the City.

In the beginning of the next year Prince Henry D. of Gloce≈øter dyed, and upon April 23. following, being St. George's day, His Maje≈øty K. Charles the 2. was Crowned at We≈øtmin≈øter, with great ≈øplendor and Solemnity; having the day before made a Magnificent Pa≈ø≈øage from the Tower through the City of London (where four curious Pageants were erected,) to Whitehall. And here we ≈øhall conclude this ab≈øtract of ≈øo many various affairs, wi≈øhing all happine≈øs to his Maje≈øty, and the pre≈øervation of the Prote≈øtant Religion forever.
